text: My first time and there was no wait, so plus. Wait staff are friendly & accommodating; the menu is simple and easy to read; price is reasonable less than $10 for a regular size bowl of ramen. i would come back here.

Let me start by disclosing that in no way shape or form am I a "ramen connoisseur" a "ramen expert" and I'm pretty sure that I can't tell you the difference in the noodles.  I am however a lover of all things food, and especially soups.  I love..love...love...love.love.Monta Chaya.  I also love (the same amount of times) the original Monta in Chinatown.  What I love as much as the first set of loves is that its literally 5 minutes from my house now.  I love how everyone greets you when you walk in and leave, I love the shoyu ramen, I love the fried rice...I however don't love the shisito peppers...the sauce is nasty (in my opinion).  The peppers will not keep me from coming back weekly.  I hate pork...if you didn't know pigs don't sweat...well never mind that's for another day...so I order it with chicken broth minus the pork.  Yummy!!  I love it so much that I'm eating soup in the 110+ degree weather.  When its as good as Monta it doesn't matter if its the surface of the sun, its still freaking good.

Second time at this location, had a free assorted appetizers which between the the chicken and the calmari you can't go wrong. Went with the Miso Ramen.   I do have to say Joseph our server was very informative of everything on the menu, I swear if you ever were lost this is the guy you'd want to get directions from!!!! He explained fully anything we asked with explicit detail, like you could ask him "how do boil water" and he would make that sound interesting!!
Excellent Price, pork belly bowl is epic!

The food here is awesome and really cheap considering the quality of the food is excellent. I try to go here about once a week. Also the workers are pretty awesome. Especially Joe because he went to the same high school my mom went to in Hawaii lol.

I like the calamari, it was crispy and taste really match up with the soup which I think it was the tempura soup. For Ramen, it was neutral and not so different from other ramen place. So, I would give a 4 stars as i was so so for this restaurant.
Spicy tonkutsu with extra egg and karaage. Very good combination, they just need a bigger space, this place is always pack with people.

We love the original Monta Ramen and were excited to come here since the original location usually has 30-60 minute wait times.    We were already repeat customers of the original Monta on Spring Mountain, so we ordered the usual Tonkatsu ramen bowls at this location.  Overall the food was good and tasted the same as the original.  The reason for 2 stars however came when my gf discovered a bug in her soup (after finishing all the ramen).  It was a small black beetle - we're just really happy it wasn't a cockroach which would have been 100x worse.  When we notified the server, she was more stressed out than she was concerned (probably about trying to think about how to handle the situation when there were already 4 bowls of eaten ramen on our table of 4).  She took the bowl away and one of the cooks came out to apologize.  She then said that the bug must have fallen into the bowl while it was on the counter waiting to be served - perhaps as a way to dodge the fact that it was probably in the soup pot and all 4 bowls of our ramen were most likely affected (and the whole restaurant's served ramen for that matter).  Anyways, we didn't argue it and she ended up making the 1 bowl of ramen (but not all 4), and our appetizer free of charge.    Not a great experience (and we didn't like the way the server handled the problem) but we'll probably be back every now and then and just hope this instance was a rare fluke.  P.S.  Other than the bug, the ramen honestly tasted fine (food is 5 stars).  Tonkatsu is definitely our favorite since its the creamier soup and not as salty as the Shoyo version.  They always cook their noodles perfectly, and the meat is super-fall-apart-tender and melts in your mouth.
This is without a doubt the best ramen I've had so far in Vegas. The staff are extremely friendly and the food is amazing. I recommend this for everyone!

On our recent trip to Vegas from the New England, we were craving ramen.  Having lived in Hawaii and Los Angeles, and frequenters of Ippudo in New York, you can consider us ramen fiends.    FOOD - We ordered tonkotsu ramen and tonkotsu-shoyu ramen (it's NOT "tonKATsu," people!), gyoza, kimchi fried rice, pork belly bowl, and mini mentaiko bowl.  Yes, a lot of food for 3, but again, we're fatties!  I could not finish my ramen (this NEVER happens!), because the broth was too oily and too salty.  It was saltier and oilier than any kotteri broth I've ever had, really inedible.  The noodles were perfectly cooked (though we ordered katamen - firm noodles - so that's a confounder), though.  I was sad that I couldn't eat more of the noodles because the oily broth was just too much of a turn off.  The side dishes, though, were SUPER good.  The gyoza was steamed and fried perfectly, so I was glad.  The kimchi fried rice was very tasty and the kick of sour kimchi was really good.  The pork belly bowl was pretty good, but I still LOVE the one from Daikokuya in LA.  The mentaiko bowl was also good, per my husband, as I don't particularly enjoy mentaiko.  AMBIANCE - par for the course for a ramen shop.    SERVICE - attentive and appropriate to assure quick turnovers during rush time!  lots of enthusiastic greetings like most ramen shops.  There was a reasonable wait (about 20 minutes) when we went at lunch time.  VALUE - decently priced!  didn't break the bank like Ippudo does :P  PARKING - ample parking outside!  Overall, ramen in LA is still the best on the west coast!

How can the place earn 4 stars? Five stars for delicious food N decent price!! You know what,give one star for waitress service,if u don't really like ur job,just do something else what can make u happy please!!!

This is my new favorite Japanese Noddle House! I love their misu ramen and egg! Rice and that spicy green pepper that they have omg soo delicious!!! The calamari is very unique favored- definitely recommend this place! Affordable price as well! GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE! :) Very friendly staff!
This place is SO good! The service was quick and the staff is friendly. We ordered ramen, gyoza and kimchi fried rice which was all great! They even serve some beers. Can't wait to go back :)

I recently ate here. At first, I was feeling great about the place. The restaurant had really good energy. The service was fast. The menu was really small. I ordered and the food was good. Nothing exceptional. But then I saw one of the cooks chewing as he was making a salad. I continued to watch him and sure enough he was popping lettuce into his mouth. He was eating part of the salad he was preparing for a customer. This really grossed me out. Shortly after eating here I got a stomach ache. I could only help but wonder if it was because of the poor health standards of this cook. He was a Hispanic male in his 30 s. I won't be returning any time soon.

Love their ramen and fried rice. Price is not cheap but totally worth it! Soup is a bit salty but I guess it's the broth. You can tell they spend hours to make the broth. The seasonings for the fried rice is so good that stays in my mouth after I leave the restaurant.

Good ramen, but overpriced sides (eg eggs, notice, etc). I often go here just for the pork belly bowl and the chasu buns. Gyozas are okay and the tonkatsu shoyu ramen is the best out of the other choices for me. I love this place though. Better than Chinatown's because this place is spacious, has friendly staff, and great service. Plus, it's close to my house so that's a plus!

We've been here twice and their ramen hits the spot! I was in the mood for noodles after watching Mind of a Chef on Netflix and their ramen was so satisfying. I'm so glad it's fall again so I can go back for more!

It is now 8:58pm and at home. Put in a take out order at 7:36pm for a Pork Belly Bowl and Mini Mentaiko. Gentlemen that answered took my name and number down and said it would be ready in 25 mins. I entered the restaurant at 7:50pm. 2 servers on the floor asked if I was here for to dine in or pickup, I said pickup. They didn't even ask for my name, didn't bother me at the time thinking they knew what it was. I waited and left at 8:10, I work in the industry as well and this is actually the first time a restaurant forgot my order. It's a shame because the food is good, maybe I'll just dine in instead of order take out. I don't really yelp but in this situation I just had to. Thanks for wasting my time.

Awesome ramen. I wish they had a few more options on the menu but sometimes simplicity is what makes the brand stand out. It truly is the "in and out" of Japanese style noodle dishes with its simple, yet "tackle the craving" type of menu. The service was good. Price was very fair for the amount of servings you get. (I couldn't finish my entire bowl and it was a $7 bowl) and the chatsu bans, omg so yummy. Also the fried rice was very authentic, not the cheap rendition of fast-food-Chinese kind that is the norm these days. (People actually think that is how fried rice is supposed to be) but that's an argument for another day. This place is totally worth revisiting when noodle soup sounds good.

I really love this restaurant! Its my first time going to this location but I've been to the one in Chinatown multiple times. This is seriously my favorite ramen place in town. Their ramen is delicious, and also their rice bowls. I recommend trying their pork belly bowl, or the shoyu ramen w/ the black garlic to top it off. I also saw they now have a new choice of red ramen? But I'm not sure, that'd be pretty cool though. Their service is the same as in Chinatown, pretty good. All the mon places are ALWAYS busy, so make sure you're going on a good day. Overall, I'd defintely come back! The food is yummy.

I read the reviews and went to  Monta Ramen on Eastern today,   It was a big disappointment.  My friend said the other Monta on Spring Mountain Road was too dirty and being shut down by Health District, we should pick another restaurant, I think I should have listened.    I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with garlic,  it looks tasty on the photo which they put up on the wall.  However, when  the server put the bowl in front of me, oh, it was totally different from the photo,  it looks like a layer of dust or dirt on top of the ramen,  It only came with 2 thin slices of pork with a lot of fat.  It does not taste good at all, in fact, that was the worst ramen I ever have.   The ramen was bad but the service is OK.   I don't think I will go back to this ramen restaurant anymore.
good but monta ramen is still my fav! plus this place it too far for my taste...

Still the best ramen in Las Vegas, and not as slammed as the main location. My fave is the kuro ramen, extra egg and butter. Beyond delicious, plus the staff is friendly and accommodating to special requests.
BOMB ramen, probably the best I've had. The broth was so flavorful. We really enjoyed the spicy miso ramen, the pork belly bowl, and the crispy rice. Our server Joe was especially awesome!
Everything here is layered with awesome flavors. And the wine selection is pretty solid as well. If you're looking to take someone off the strip for some great food, this should be considered.

Just an OK ramen place. The broth is a bit too thick and the fatty meat will melt in the broth, which makes the whole bowl more oily. Plus, service is really slow here. Not sure it's the problem of front or back of house. Hopefully there are better ramen restaurants in LV.

Horrible service. My waitress didn't listen to my order when I asked for things I'm allergic to not to be in my food. She was rude towards me when I asked questions about the food. They take forever just to bring my table the two bowls of white rice we were missing. And she continues to walk back and forth without acknowledging that we were missing two bowls of rice. Worst. Place. To. Eat.

Huge fan, love this place I'm almost always satisfied with my service unless I come during the day, The service is terrible. The servers that are usually here at night Are such sweethearts! Then there's usually just two women who look about 30 here during the day a lot of the time that are so rude. It makes me sad because I'm such a fan of this place.

unfriendly staff, would not recommend this place, service is poor, food is okay, the actual noodle itself is horrible, maybe because they forgot to serve it in a timely manner, i hate when the restroom are dirty, makes me feel like the whole place is filthy including the food

This is an amazing low price ramen noodle shop..  I will definitely be back.  A bit small and wait time is long, but we'll worth the wait.  I loved the ramen and gyoza.  Great atmosphere to just sit and chill with friends or alone to enjoy a great bowl of soup.
What can I say, it's comfort food. It's cold outside! I keep coming back because it's the best ramen in town! My favorite at least :)

Good tonkotsu ramen, tried the new  kuro ramen but preferred the tonkotsu shio ramen. Also tried the crispy sushi with spicy tuna, will pass on that next time. Spicy tuna rather bland. Very similar to the Spring Mtn shop sans long lines .  We still prefer the Spring Mtn venue, however.

Monta Chaya is my all time favorite place for comfort food. The menu is simple and there's something for everyone. I've tried almost every dish on the menu and have never been disappointed. The quick, efficient, and friendly service makes returning so easy.

Nothing special. I have had better ramen. Looks appetizing but flavor is flat. So not get the pork belly buns. They are not that great either. I would pass on this place. Quite expensive for something that is bland.   Service is also not so great. I didn't get a spoon and had to ask for it 3 times for my ramen. Still didn't get it. Also they did not give us any refills until we paid.

Tried to go yesterday, is under renovation till 3/31/2017.  No advance notice and we were just there 2 weeks ago  Love their fast service expect for the karaage, last one on the table to eat.  Food is great!

Good ramen for good price! Feels like im in korea again..lolz..musta try the TONKOtSU ShOYU RAmeN..$6.95 not bad price...  Place is alil bit small yet food is great..i just wish they will expand their resto ....so if u wanna b here come early coz its a long wait to be seated...where in u will make much hungry..lolz..^_^

This place is bomb dot com! My husband and I have been here twice so far, and both times the food was stellar and the atmosphere is awesome. We sat at the bar both visits and it's fun to watch them in action making all the dishes! This place is definitely a go to place for us from now on  Can't wait to go back and try something new!

They last time I got to go prefer they messed up a lot but I thought I'd give them another chance and I'm so glad I did. The only thing I wish for was for the ramen to go to be the same amount as dine in. It's a bit less. And I wish they have the spices on the table to go.

Insult to Japan and Japanese food. Salty, flavorless Top Ramen. Ordered spicy, actually received regular but, charged additionally for spicy. Condiments: pink pickled ginger, strange garlic mixture; both from a package opened who knows when, random ingredients thrown together to create a "spicy" topping, old sesame seeds, etc. A steamed bun with a small piece of pork+iceberg lettuce!? Staff yelling to kitchen from across the small restaurant. Awkward! Also, rumor has it their other location was closed by the health department. So sad.  First and possibly last time here.

Ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen and added extra chasu and flavored egg. Soup base was good, noodle had a good firmness, however the spicy paste addition to make it spicy felt a little lethargic in the effort department. Flavored egg is worth the extra cost. Karage was ok, kind of soggy. Pork Bun was okay, lacked flavor, sort of bland. Per coming from LA, I have higher standards for ramen. Waitress was kind and diligent. Green tea came out of a can for 1.75. Came here because I was craving ramen in Vegas, it was satisfactory

Ramen was delicious, and customer service on point! Went in an hour before closing, it was busy but we were seated immediately. The servers are very nice and accommodating. Reasonable pricing, will def. return!
Food is good. Everyone else in the restaurant had gotten their order but they forgot ours and our waitress kept telling us that it was coming clearly knowing it was missed.

Let's start with beverages. What is up with hot tea being served from a can? Is this a Vegas thing? If so, very tacky Let's get to the ramen...  Being under the weather, I thought a nice hot bowl would be a good soothing satisfying meal.  Unfortunately on the contrary here which makes me ask "How does it have a 4 star rating?   I ordered the Black Garlic Oil to be spicy. What a fail! What I thought was going to be a nice bold flavored broth, looks like dirty sink water and taste like gritty salt water. Not impressive to say the least. Spicy Top Ramen has more flavor. I don't care for spicy food that kills my tastebuds but this doesn't even come close to having any heat that I find myself generously sprinkling tougarashi. I asked the waitress how spicy was this to be? She replies Very spicy. I tell her otherwise and she just shrugs which then determines her tip and the final point of giving this place one star.   Although  cozy and somewhat clean (the only qualities that redeemed itself to one star) it hardly is worth a visit. You're better off spending your $10 -12 elsewhere.

Update as of late 2015:    They now allow you to customize the saltiness of your order. Just let the server know. So much better.   My original July 205 review:  It's a nice place but practically all their food is excessively SALTY so if you have hypertension like me - you should stay away if you can from this place.  My sons love this place and occasionally I join them - the one dish that's medium salty is the pork belly bowl.  All the noodles are super salty and can really raise your blood pressure. Beware.  All drinks are served in cans so don't expect any refills.

I was craving ramen so we went to  Monta Chaya on Eastern.  The reviews were really good so we just had to try it.  We ordered the tonkatsu ramen and pork belly bowl.  Both dishes were sooooo full of oil and pork fat.  We picked through our ramen, did not drink the broth.   The broth is like a thick gravy with lots of oil.  I don't think it's the good kind of fat either.  It's probably pork fat I'm guessing.  Now for the pork belly bowl.  You can't really see the oil in the pork belly bowl because the rice soaks it up.  Ask the server for a side of the sauce that goes in the pork belly bowl and you will see what I mean.  The pork belly bowl was kind of bland so we asked for a side of sauce.  There is about 1/2" layer of pure melted, saturated fat on top of the sauce.  I'm not a health nut but I try to watch what I eat and this stuff is totally off the charts.  I've been to other ramen houses in Las Vegas and they are no where as greasy as this place.  If you like good ramen, try Sora Ramen on Spring Mountain.  Very authentic Japanese ramen $6.95 and you can get a mini curry bowl (delicious) for $2.65.  Oh, and the service was excellent and the waittress was awesome so that was the only good thing about Monta Chaya.  But I will not be back to this place.

If anyone has been to the Monta on Spring Mountain know how busy and delicious it is... I have great news; this location is just as good but half the traffic.    The layout it pretty much the same with the bar seating and the L shape tables except there a little more walking area and space between tables.  The menu is exactly the same down to the prices. Also when you order here they do not use paper they use a mini IPad and it goes straight to the POS system.   Overall just as good as the original but less traffic and a lot closer to my house :)

Monta, now closer to home. Gyoza is good, noodles are good, the whole thing is great.  Getting the mixed brother is nice, but in summer time the hiyashi chuka can't be beat. Such a great variety of food, side dishes and always consistently good quality.  Parking is ample, space is still limited. Go in off peak hours for best results. It's conveniently right next to Japan Creek, so you can walk next door, buy similar ingredients and make ramen at home. Then cry into your bowl, as it fails to taste even a third as good as what you just had from Monta.

TL;DR  Food Taste: 5 Food Quantity: 5 Service: 4 Price: $$ (bowl of ramen with extra meat and an appetizer/side dish puts you at about 18-20 with tax and tip, no EtOH) Value: 4.5  Apparently this place is related to the Monta down in Chinatown. While I had frequented the Chinatown location on several occasions, it was becoming quite tedious to drive out there for a ramen fix. Then I found out they opened up a branch store in Henderson, and happiness befell me. Then I found out that they had more culinary experiments at this location, and bliss tickled my tongue.  Ramen: Several varieties. most are familiar to Monta-goers. Shoyu (soy sauce), Tonkotsu, Shoyu-Tonkotsu, and Miso. There are the addition of Kuro/Black (Tonkotsu + black garlic oil) and Red (Tonkotsu + red hot spicy whatevers).  Overall, the broths are less salty than the Chinatown location (makes it less authentic, but certainly more palatable if you like to finish the soup.), otherwise most are the same except for the addition of the black and red ramen.   The Black ramen gets its name and color from the roasted garlic oil. Gives the soup a speckly black appearance, and gives the ramen a slightly bitter taste. Either way, if you like garlic with a hint of bitter, this is an excellent ramen.  The Red ramen is just angry spicy. Think of it as your Tonkotsu ramen + Sriracha. Probably a match made in heaven for some people. I have no problems with it.  Appetizer: Crispy Rice with spicy tuna topping. One word: delicious. The crunch of the sushi rice topped with the pleasantly spicy tuna is probably the most amazing thing ever. If you came here and just got 3 orders of this and had nothing else, I wouldn't blame you at all. (Note: tuna is raw.)  The other appetizers aren't so bad either, but that Crispy rice.......*drool*  Conclusion: Hooray! A ramen place close to home with other goodies!
Really good noodles. The staff is friendly and the dinning room is clean. Two bowls of noodles, two appetizers and two sodas came out too be $27...not bad for how good it is.

Service was great and food was delicious! It was my first time going to a place for authentic ramen so I was kind of nervous as to if I was going to like it or not, and I loved it! A little small, but the staff and food totally make up for it! As soon as you walk through the door they all greet you! I'll definitely be back soon!

Darn it i hate this place for being so far away from the house on a positive note wonderful and yummy i had the kimichi fried rice (raised on it so im slightly picky) was wonderful just the right amount of heat and the flavor was great prices low food quality high a place to come to

Came in at 6:30 on a Monday night. Minimal wait for a table, simple menu, quick service, and yummy food. My kids, whom are normally very picky, loved everything. This was a first time visit for us, but won't be the last. I had the miso ramen: added corn, eggs, and nori. Next time I'm getting extra eggs - they are SO GOOD!!!   Saw a table next to us with 2 orders of potstickers. They weren't on the menu, but we would have ordered them had they of been.
Reasonable price, very good and tasty ramen. I recommend the tonkotsu ramen and fried rice.
My favorite spot for Ramen! If you live in henderson don't waste your time driving to China town.  This spot has it all. We have always had to wait but they get people in and out fast !

Came in late, about 10:15p, but the service and food were still great! The 6 of us were sat in minutes. The Shoyu Ramen was good, but I didn't like the pork slices (fatty). I also ordered the Spicy Fried Rice (I think it was called that) and that was an awesome appetizer, thinking back, it was easily my favorite food of the entire meal. Had two kids with us, and the server told us we can order just the plain noodles without the broth (not on the menu), which they enjoyed. We'll be back.
Monta sent to Henderson their better sister, Monta Chaya, with the best location in town,(still with small parking lot)  Monta Chaya is beautiful japanese ramen shop closes to us.
Yum! I wish to come here more often but they need more tables. The food is delicious will come back again soon!

If your from Japan or want to have a bowl of Ramen and feel like you went to Japan, this is the spot!  I think their best Ramen is Miso Ramen with Extra Chashu. The broth is rich and flavorful and their chashu is delicate and yummy.  I no longer need to drive to Spring Mtn. to have Ramen. ARIGATO!!!

They had really nice waiters and the ramen was superb. The soup reminded me of like a Japanese woman's tears of happiness when she found out she was reuniting with a loved one. Also, the bamboo shots are poppin.

The best soup I've ever had, seriously. Small establishment with fast and attentive service.  They specialize in Tonkatsu soup.  I get the one with thin Ramen noodle, pork broth, pork meat, mushroom and my additional ingredients (egg, corn and a side order of pork belly with rice)  It's sooooo good. Anyone I've brought with me loves it as well.

Diclaimer: I'm not a ramen expert since I have not had ramen from Japan.  Prior to Monta, I only have Cup O'noodles and Top Ramen Instant Noodles experience.   This eatery serves  the best ramen I've had in Las Vegas (I've also tried Ramen Sora but did not write a review).  The first time I tried Monta was at their Las Vegas location off Spring Mountain 3 years ago.  Since then, I have new respect for ramen and visit very often, especially in the cold months of winter (It definitely hits the spot).   I've tried all 4 ramen broths (Shoyu,Tonkatsu, Shoyu-Tonkatsu, and Miso) and my favorite is the Shoyu-Tonkatsu with shredded green onion or mustard leaves.  The broth is thick, milky and flavorful.  The ramen is firm yet tender.   During the hot summers, my wife loves the cold noodle with yuzu sauce... just noodles,  with a ponzu type (citrus) dressing.   My boys 9 and 11 enjoy it very much as well.  There are more options down on Spring mountain, but this is an excellent option for those in Henderson.

Genuine.  A much abused term in Vegas.  In this rare case, absolutely true.  I haven't had a better ramen since Japan, and it is not for the lack of trying in many large cities. And unlike some Japanese houses, no huge bill, no wait line, no feeling uncomfortable in presence of a respected chef.   I'm working my way through the menu, one lunch at the time...
Bomb ramen and I don't have to drive all the way to Chinatown?? Yaaaasss! The gyoza and ramen is delicious and CHEAP! Monta is always a good choice!

I had no idea what true ramen was suppose to taste up until my first visit to Monta two years ago. The restaurant since has changed my taste buds completely and raised my standards for the Japanese art of ramen. I have visited Monta already ten times since and I have no intentions of stopping.  Upon entering and leaving Monta you're greeted by both the waiting staff and the kitchen. The dining room is small which generally leads to some sort of wait but the ramen is worth the wait. My favorite is the miso ramen which is tonkotsu ramen pork bone broth with a miso base. Standard ramen toppings are two pieces of chashu pork, bamboo shoots and sliced black mushrooms. The chashu pork are divine slices of pork belly with just the right amount of fat to felt in your mouth. You can also choose from a variety of other toppings that you can add for a little extra. Aside from ramen the restaurant has some other dishes like fried rice, gyoza, and pork belly buns. The fried rice is my favorite to get alongside ramen. Something about it is just so delicious.   If you're looking to try ramen in Las Vegas do not waste your time and head to Monta. Exceptional quality ramen coupled with very affordable prices make this a must-go place to eat.

Awesome spot! My usual order is the porkbelly bowl and tonkatsu ramen. Sometimes I'll order the crispy tuna or the shishito peppers. My order is always consistent and great tasting. The staff is friendly but this restaurant tends to get busy quick at their peak times. I would suggest going during off peak times. My spot for ramen everytime!

I always loved this place.  I eat here quite often and the staff remembers me even if it's been a while.  the food is great and is my number one Ramen destimation in town.  I love the Tonktatsu-Shoyu blend and the fried rice is to absolutely die for!
This is my favorite ramen shop.  I am so glad they're now in Henderson.

Went here for lunch the other day with my friend. Service was so fast! Ryan, the server was super friendly and nice, not to mention he was so cute! The food came out really really quick and was easy to customize. It was my friends first time and even though the menu is small, Ryan gave us excellent recommendations. We will definitely be back!

On a rainy day, ramen is a necessity to stay warm and Monta is the perfect choice! I like monta Chaya (the Henderson location on eastern) better than the monta in Chinatown because it's bigger, there's never a wait, the staff is friendlier, and there's a bigger selection of appetizers!  My favorites: green tea, shishitsu peppers, and miso ramen.   the shishitsu peppers are flash fried, offering js the right amount of crisp and soft center to every bite. The sauce they glaze over the peppers is sweet and complements the slight hint of spiciness from the peppers.  But what monta is known for is their miso ramen, and hands down, this is the best tasting miso broth in Vegas. It's light and not too salty. The pork is so tender that it js melts in your mouth. Add in some egg and seaweed, and my ramen experience is mouthwatering perfection.
I really like Monta Chaya. I am surprised that I have not left a review yet. This location is more spacious than the original location. Best ramen in town. Everything is good.

Monta Chaya is a very good casual ramen place in the Henderson area. If you like the Monta on the other side of town but don't want to make the drive, Monta Chaya is a good alternative.  If you have a ramen craving, you can get the tonkatsu (pork broth) ramen, shoyu ("soy sauce" broth) ramen, or a combination of both for $6.95, and an extra helping of ramen without soup is $1.50 (kaedama). If it's your carb day, the ramen is a good choice. The broth is very thick and flavorful. You can taste the hours of work put into extracting the marrow from the pork, and you'll have to control yourself from drinking all of the soup (especially if you're watching your sodium).  If you're looking for a more protein-heavy meal, you should try the pork belly bowl (regular size is $5.75). The pork is marinated and there's a good helping of it to satisfy your craving. The rice is nicely steamed, a rarity in Vegas, and complements the pork belly very well, balancing the flavors for a delicious meal.  The restaurant is crowded and can get loud at times, but the wait staff is very friendly and attentive. There can be a 15-30 minute wait if you're there during busy hours, but the food is worth the wait.  I'd recommend anyone in the area craving good ramen to check out Monta Chaya!
I love Japanese food!  This place is just great and their specialty is ramen.  And I have had ramen at other locations and none are as good as what this place serves!!!

Ramen so close. Delicious noodles are here. Must Try the gyoza.  That's my haiku, because the special crafting of Monta's ramen deserves more culture than just an empty, barbaric review. I was worried this new location would deliver less qualities, because sequels almost always suck. Worry not, just as good as the original!  I'm very picky about my gyoza, and Monta has consistently been the best. Same with Monta Chaya, still the best around!  I can't wait for my hiyashi chuka fix now, expect imminent return.
I love Monta and finally I don't have to drive to Chinatown anymore.  My favorite, Cold Noodles with Yuzu. Everybody should try them!  Draft beer for the win.

After doing some business at AT&T next door, we wanted to fill our tummies and relax with some tasty ramen.   Walked in at around 2:25p, low and behold they close at 2:30.  Yipes.  Hostess/Waitress lets us know we need to order IMMEDIATELY.  We feel ya lady...so sorry!  However, after only looking at the menu for less than 1min, she is hustling us to order.  After not being ready just yet, she comes back hustling us to order again - but this time with notepad and pen IN-YO-FACE.  No bueno.    We finally order some gyoza, pork belly bowl and of course some ramen (Kuro).  Everything was delicious (4.5 stars), just make sure you are in for "Kurume" ramen which is the thicker and more flavorful broth.   Overall, we did not appreciate being rushed.  Would have rather been denied than felt like we had to hurry.  Totally unexpected from a restaurant with normally gracious employees.  However, the food made up for it and we will be back sometime...probably a long time but we will be back!

Quick service, delicious ramen, friendly staff, good portions for price. Pork is melt in your mouth good! It's small but only 3 tables were occupied. By the time we got our meals, the whole place was filled (except a few bar seats). We were in and out in about 20 minutes, we were hungry and they had super fast service. Not a place to sit and chat for hours, more of a quick fix.

Hooked on their Tonkotsu ramen. It is in the same plaza as QQ BOBA, so it's perfect as Chara Monta has best authentic japanese ramen in town, and QQ boba has best Taiwanese style fresh milk teas in town!

It's really hard finding Asian food that's not in China Town. I've gone to Monta Chaya exactly 3 times.  Each time, I've been very underwhelmed. It was good, but just mediocre to me. It loosely fills that ramen craving I have from time to time, since its the closest restaurant to me.   I've had the black garlic, regular tonkatsu, and spicy miso ramen. Add egg.   I was a ramen fiend for some time and explored the noodle houses of LA -- this would stack somewhere in the middle. Not the best, but not the worst.   The flavors are there, noodles are al dente and chewy, soft boiled egg is perfect.... I guess my only gripe is that the broth is TOO rich for me. Now, I understand some people love the richness and fattyness... and some seek it, then you'll love this! But for me, it was just too much and a bit overly salty -- made my stomach feel unsettling a bit. I have had ramen which tasted rich but didn't FEEL rich... I actually had to add some vinegar into the broth to try and cut the fat.   All in all. This is A-Ok.

Japanese food is one of my favorites. However, I've never been a Japanese ramen fan (I prefer udon). So why am I giving Monta, a ramen place, such a high rating? I go there for their deee-licious fried rice, pork belly bowel and chasu buns, which I'm addicted to. It's great they're on Eastern Ave. now. I did try their ramen a while back on Spring Mountain, but it didn't change my mind about ramen. Looking forward to getting some more chasu buns!

Hit or miss with this ramen house. I am a little biased because I have had better ramen than this. However, their flavors are average. I am used to real ramen cooked by adorable Japanese chefs in the back of their shop (awesome example santouka ramen in Orange County is who ramen shops should aspire to- Zagat rated) like santouka in California. One huge complaint is their pork belly, lots of flavor and melts in your mouth BUT had bone fragments- that's a lawsuit waiting to happen when you chip a tooth. Their staff is friendly but always in a rush. And honestly I didn't taste any difference between their clear broths and milky. This place is good, if you need a ramen fix.

As a long-time patron of the Spring Mountain location, I was elated to see they were opening a location on my side of town. I was hopeful that quality wouldn't dwindle like it does with other restaurants opening multiple locations. I was not disappointed! I ordered my usual Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen! It tasted like genuine Monta ramen. Yes!!!! It was nice to see they added a few more options to the menu while keeping in the simplistic Monta fashion. I look forward to trying the new offerings very soon. Gyoza and Kimche were great as expected.   It appears that there are a few more tables available than at their first location which is good. They spared no expense with the interior. We got there just as they were opening the shop and the place filled fast. If the waiting list sheet is any indication, I assume there is a wait here as well so be ready to relax. Browse Japan Creek next door and enjoy the cultural exchange.

I was excited to try their Veggie Ramen. Ive been to their other location on Spring Mtn. And really not the best ramen but i wanted to try the Veggie Ramen. I went in and sat at the counter but I was told told get back and sign in. No big deal, 2 minutes later it's ok to seat at the same counter. Took about 5 min to take the order.  8 min later, server said No Veggie Ramen and I should call first before coming next time. Just wasted 15 min waiting plus driving here to try their only Veggie Ramen that they don't have.  Hope others have better experience.

The service was outstanding.  It was clean and comfortable inside.    I knew going in there that its a noodle/ramen house.  Even knowing that, I was disappointed in the noodles themselves.  I got a salad and ate some gyoza--which were both delicious.    The deal with the noodles -- the broth wasn't flavorful and I didn't care for the texture.  Also, and this was my biggest peeve, was that I ordered extra slices of pork on top of the noodles.  They were paper thin, flavorless, and disintegrated upon contact with chopsticks.
Great place for a bowl of ramen.  If you are on the east side of Vegas, this is the place. Service is quick and pleasant. Noodles are cooked to perfection. Broth is excellent. Enjoy.

The hype is real, their ramen is amazing. Get the tonkotsu and ask for extra chashu. Get the chashu buns as well. Very busy place, be prepared to wait if it's lunch or dinner time and you have a big party. Oh and right next door is the amazing Japan Creek Japanese grocery so I like to get my groceries there too.

This is my favorite Ramen noodle bar in Las Vegas!  Period!  Best food, Best Service, Reasonably cheap, clean, and good location.  Highly recommend!  Order the black Garlic oil infused Ramen noodle bowl which is real tasty,  gyoza, and the kimchee fried rice with pork.   Also good vegetarian offerings here.

This is the best ramen place in all of Las Vegas. We love it.   I was very tempted to try the cold noodle today being that it's over 100...but the miso ramen is just too good. Maybe next time I'll venture out of my comfort zone.   Miso ramen about 7 bucks, add egg for an additional 1.5 and you have perfection.   Always quick seating, welcoming service and delicious food :)   Oh and if it's your first time, don't be alarmed when they all yell at you when you come and leave. I don't know what it means, but it's kind of nice to have everyone acknowledge you when you come and go!

Placed was packed but we were able to sit within 5 mins.   I honestly didn't like the flavor of the ramen i ordered, bland. But my friend's soup was better and little bit spicy. I know pork has fats but our meat is mostly fats.   I also didnt like the rice cake appetizer i ordered, i had rice cakes before but not as tough to chew as this one although i liked the flavor of its toppings
Love this place to death! Kimchi fried rice is my favorite dish, the pork is to die for

I'll keep it short and sweet (just like Monta) . This place is spot on.  You can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  I've tried nearly everything and haven't been disappointed.  The staff is always friendly and always busting their behinds to keep everyone happy.  There is usually a wait, sometimes hefty, but I look at that as a compliment to the establishment.  You gotta go here, I promise the wait is worth it!

Monta Chaya....  You might wonder if the quality is as good as the original one.  The answer is YES.  It's actually to our Salon Luxy Nail Salon.  We are regular there, more like it's almost my 2nd kitchen LOL.  Monta Chaya offers more Appetizers than the original Monta.  5 Stars!!

A lot of the people I talk to (about ramen at least) either really like or don't like Monta. It is a convenient restaurant because they have multiple locations, but I'm not the biggest fan. What I had was their tonkotsu shoyu ramen with thick noodles; personally, their broth is a tad on the saltier side and not as creamy as I would like it to be. The flavors in it are mediocre, and there is nothing memorable about it. Though I do credit them for making their noodles well, where they have a nice bite to them.

This is the best ramen I've ever had. It is so rich and savory and delicious. I've heard their fried rice is really good too, but I can't resist getting the ramen every time I've been here. I've had the Tonkotsu, Tonkotsu Shoyu, and the Miso... I think the Tonkotsu is my favorite but they're all really delicious. Definitely add the marinated egg! Yum!

Wasn't my favorite place for ramen to eat. It is super busy and small place. The waitress are in a rush to get you in and out, I asked a question about the egg, waitress had an attitude and replied, no they half cooked. The cooks are organized and seem to have a great system down. I had the Tonkotsu. I would like to try another dish.

I love this place and go whenever I can. I always get the miso, calamari, and dikon salad. The miso is a little salty, but that's why I love it so much. The place is small but cozy and the staff is always nice.

Great place for Monta Ramen and you don't have to hightail it to the Monta on Spring Mountain, if you need a ramen fix.  I normally order the tonkatsu with spring onions for an add on and a side of Kimchi. I've never had a bad bowl of ramen here, it's always great. I'm sure that's the reason it can get crowded. I think the longest I have waited was 15 minutes. I normally go at noon and there are two of us, so we get seated right away. If you can, opt to sit at the bar as there are usually open seats there.  The restaurant is pretty narrow, think NY size, but the seating is worked to where you won't be sitting on top of people. The service is fast so you won't wait long after you order. That comes in handy, especially if you are super hungry. The servers are nice and attentive, no problem there.

This place was a pleasant surprise. Food was good -- the ramen was not overly salty like all the other places I've tried (especially at shoku ramen and also ramen sora). Great flavor without mounds of salt. Got the Karaage (fried chicken) which was just ok- not great but loaded that chili oil on it and I finished my plate. The shishito peppers were yummy too. Service was friendly but I felt rushed even though we were there past the dinner hour and no one was waiting for a table. Ambiance was nice (which is saying a lot for vegas). Will return.

I love ramen!!! Both Monta chaya and the Monta in Chinatown are probably my favorite ramen spots in Vegas. I've had ramen sora, tetsu, fukumimi but Monta has the richest and tastiest broth of them all. The chashu pork is also very delicious. I like to order the kuro ramen which has a garlic based broth with thick wavy noodles...very very good. The broth does start to taste salty towards the end but the flavor just does not disappoint. The chaya location in Henderson is much more comfortable and spacy compared to the Chinatown spot. Monta always hits the spot! :)

Thoroughly disappointed. I heard so many good things about the place and I just did not like it at all. I couldn't finish my bowl. The only part I liked about the shoyu ramen was the egg that I added. My friend also had to drown his miso ramen in some spicy sauce. After searching and finally finding a place that has chicken broth I am left speechless. It took a lot out of me to write past the "thoroughly disappointed" part.
Delicious, quick, clean, fresh and cheap. Everything I want in a Ramen place. The best ramen in Henderson.

It's pretty tasty ramen and all the other things are pretty good too. The hot tea is served in cans, which is interesting. Service is usually on point and the kimchee is also yummy. It's not a terribly comfortable restaurant, though. I'm in opinion, it could use some cushions on the benches and perhaps add a bench (and heater, if it's cold) outside for people waiting so that people don't wait on top of other people.
This is likely to become a regular favorite for me any my sons. Good food, great price... wish they had some more seating.

Finally checked this place out. I came once with a friend for lunch but there was a 30min wait so we ended up going somewhere else. It took me awhile to come back because I'm not very familiar with these Japanese noodle restaurants. Had it once in Hawaii but it wasn't anything special to me. I had a 5 star rating going on this review before the food came. EXCELLENT service. The waitress was very informative and helped me figure out what I wanted. The soup was alright but again nothing special to me. Maybe because I grew up eating top ramen 5 days a week  The pot stickers had a funny taste to them so I only ate 2. I would order the soup again but not the pot stickers. It tasted fine but I had to go get tacos after I ate there because the bowl of soup wasn't very filling. Very small nice little spot. No wonder it's always packed though, there's only room for about 20 people in there at a time. Would be a 2 or 3 star rating if it weren't for that great service.

Came here during dinner, ordered tonkotus ramen, miso ramen and fried calamari. Service was mediocre, food was not bad, bit salty. Overall experience was okay.   Good -ramen soup was very creamy. -corn tastes good with soup. -better than their original location.   Not so good -charges 1 dollar for Sriracha. -server was not friendly. -fried calamari became soggy due to sauces on the bottom, ramen soup is bit too salty.

This place is delish! If you are craving good ramen, you should definitely check them out. Their kimchi fried rice is so fresh and yummy, and I definitely recommend the spicy tonkotsu. Service is fast and friendly and the spot has a nice relaxing ambiance. Definitely a hidden gem as I did not know about this place before a friend suggested and I searched yelp reviews. It's sometimes hard to find a good ramen or sushi spot outside of Chinatown, but this one is definitely the beez kneez.
Very good ramen, and fried rice. We always ask for less salt in the ramen because it's very salty for our taste. Excellent service. A+
This was my old ramen spot. It was always good every time I came here.

This is the closest ramen place to my home so my father and I go for a good fill of ramen and crispy rice. Usually I would get the miso ramen with extra egg but lately I've been seriously digging the pork belly bowl! The staff is very friendly and provide good service too.

My favorite ramen place to go that's closest to my house. The casual ambiance in the place is awesome and the staff is super attentive.   My only request is that you add some chicken options to the menu. I'm not huge on pork but it still doesn't change my love for this place! If you are ever near by, stop by and grab an awesome bowl of ramen.

My husband and I love this place! We crave the ramen and it's pretty much our fav food place in Henderson. We always order to go so I'm not sure about the quality of service inside the restaurant but the staff is always friendly when I'm there to pick up. Our food is always ready within 15-20 min. Shoyu Ramen, gyoza and Kimchi fried rice is our go to meal. Every time the noodles are perfectly cooked, the pork is tender and the flavor of the bamboo shoots and green onions are perfection. The gyoza and fried rice never disappoint either, amazing flavors everytime. My husband ordered the chasu bowl this last time and wow so good!! I tell all my friends about this place and we will definitely continue to frequent Monta Chaya.

Small but fabulous place! Finally found the Ramen place we miss. You should come early so you will not have to wait for quite a while. I love the Miso Ramen here. Very tasty broth. Enjoyed the chashu bowl too.

Let me preface this review by saying that I am a bit of a ramen connoisseur (if there ever was one), so if you are not too picky with ramen, don't take this review to heart.  Frankly, I was not impressed with the ramen here.  I ordered the shoyu ramen and had high expectations, as one of my friends said she LOVED the ramen here in Las Vegas.  The ramen was mediocre -- nothing worth raving over, but also nothing to complain about.  The value was fair, the amount of noodles and chashu was reasonable, and the broth was tasty.  You absolutely must add the nitamago to your ramen -- that was my favorite part!  I also ordered the gyoza, a side order of fried rice, and the crispy rice spicy tuna roll.  The gyoza was extremely fresh, however, I wasn't really a fan of it because it was a little soggy.  Be prepared to mix your own gyoza sauce, which is typical at a lot of ramen restaurants, but it can throw off unsuspecting guests sometimes.  The fried rice was DELICIOUS!  I enjoyed absolutely every grain of it, as I loved the sauce and the texture.  The crispy rice spicy tuna roll was also pretty good, as the fish tasted extremely fresh!  Everything we ordered was a great value for the price we paid.  The service was pretty great here!  We arrived for an early dinner - around 5:30 and were seated immediately.  The server was quick, warm, and accurate.  We even ordered the crispy rice roll as an add-on to our initial order, and it came in a timely manner.  Everyone was very friendly in this restaurant!  All in all, I would probably not recommend this restaurant to a friend because the ramen was nothing special -- maybe an effective hangover cure, but nothing more.  The other items I ordered were delicious, but the main dish was underwhelming.  This is the first ramen restaurant I have tried in Las Vegas, so I will probably be trying out some of the other ramen restaurants before returning to this one.

Best ramen in US. I lived in LA, Philadelphia, Cleveland, San Antonio but this place is the best so far. I was in Vegas for my business trip, I went there two days in a row. Both times I ordered tonkotsu shouyu ramen. I guess there are a lot of Japanese people live in Vegas. The ramen wasn't Americanized. It was very authentic.

This has got to be the best Ramen house I've been to so far.  I'm from California's Bay Area and we have plenty ramen houses there but none compare to the broth and noodle ratio in terms of flavour, chewiness, seasoning...i can just go on.   The place is small so be prepared to wait but it's so worth it.  I haven't had the fried rice so much so I can't speak for that but the ramen, the gyoza, the kaarage are all very very very good. As far as I'm concerned, this place is worth the drive from San Jose.

had very high expectations for this place since it's so highly rated, but i was rather disappointed.  had the tonkatsu ramen. so the depth of flavor of the broth is excellent. my issue, however, is how salty the broth was. why?? why so salty? i really have issues with ramen places where i can't finish the broth because it's too salty. i think if they can half the amount of salt they put in the broth, it'd be perfect. if they ever offer a low sodium version, i'll be back.

You know a place is going to be amazing when there is a line out the door. Once seated, this place did not disappoint from start to finish. The service was fast and the food was spectacular. To start I got shoshito peppers and pork buns. The pork buns were to die for, so good I ordered another round!!! The peppers were played with a sauce drizzled over them, at first I wasn't thrilled about this, but once I cleaned the plate off, it was clear I loved the dish. For the soup I ordered the Shoyu Ramen, Basic chicken broth with big noodles. I kept mine basic and only added pork and medium boiled eggs. Very simple, but very tasty. I can't wait to come back and try more items!!!!

Just had the veggie ramen. Soy milk based soup with corn, leek, tomato, radish sprouts and noodles. Pretty weird... But I LIKED it! I wish they offered tofu as an add-in.  Unfortunately I don't eat pork anymore but the ramen looked and smelled legit.

Yessss! Excited to find a ramen spot that isn't in Chinatown. Miso & tonkotsu ramen are both great choices. The crispy rice (spicy tuna) in town. Chicken karaage is light and not oily. Gyoza is flavorful and fired to order. Ask for Joseph- truly a great server who is passionate about great and attentive service.

You know that "ramen-life" (I just made that up!) is definitely good when you take that first delicious spoonful of Tonkatsu Ramen from Monta Chaya. The creamy silky texture combined with the almost overpowering combination of flavors that dance across your tongue for hours to come. It's nearly indescribable and therefore, if you are reading this, you are now bound and committed by all the power of Yelp, to try it yourself!  An essential part of the experience is the formal Japanese greeting when you enter, the decor, the tradition of the experience, and the formal goodbye when you leave. This is not soup in a bowl. THIS IS RAMEN. The real thing. The tradition. The excellence. The secrecy of the recipe and the multi-day preparation technique. The fact that no two purveyors off his delicious meal have the same approach, the same ingredients, the same exact technique. True ramen is a unique life event that must be experienced to understand and appreciate.   But, will we ever truly understand? Doubtful. Let's just agree to enjoy.

Ok,  I really really wanted to like this place.  I got the shoyu tonkatsu ramen and pork belly rice.  The pork in the ramen was awesome.  Now,  the broth was way too salty. Sorry!  I really was sad I didn't like it because so many peeps do. The pork belly rice was too saucy but the flavor was good.  Just in case I do really like the ramen at santouka. I mention this in case you question my review.

I can't count the amount of times I have eaten at this place. It is small and intimate, but they always seem to have seating available. Service is always prompt and very friendly. I always order the Shoyu Ramen with corn. I have cravings for this. I have tried mixing in some of the different condiments they have at the table, but I always go back to the basic. So delicious and filling. My husband's staple is the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen, he loves it. This place always gets it right, and we will continue to frequent here.

Yuck Yuck and another Yuck.  Two weeks ago, we decided to try this place out, but was unable to get in.  It was packed.  Figure Pack = good food.  Well, not necessarily.  We tried again today and were seated promptly.  My mom and I ordered a Gyzoga and each bowl of the Tonktasu.  Here is my review of the Ramen Tonktasu soup:  1.  Soup was bad bad bad.  I gave some to my 2 yr daughter who loves soup and she shook her head and did not want it.  It smells bad!  2.  Ramen noodles.  This is like Ramen from the bag.  Personally, I like the Ramen from the bag better.  3.  3 slices of pork??  seriously.  Hardly any meat.  It was 3 thin slice of fatty pork.  Yuck.  hello???  Verdict.  I would never recommend this to ANYONE.  It is not worth the wait.  I rather have a bowl of Pho that would cost about 7 bucks.  The Pho would have better noodles, better tasting soup, and more meat.  This place is a huge disappointment.

Love love love this place.  Only wish they had more seating.  When choosing between an expensive dinner or Monta Chaya, we chose this small noodle house.  The broth is why I keep coming back.  Everything we have had is excellent. I'm always sure to get the kimchi.

I've eaten at Monta Chaya over 15 times. Today on a cool rainy Vegas day I opted to get the Chashu Buns which I have had in the past & were excellent. Today they were very sadly disappointing. I super thin slice of pork on the bun with a tiny piece of lettuce that didn't even cover the pork. Sauce on it didn't seem to be what it used to be either. Sadly disappointed I paid $5 for that as it wasn't worth it.

First time eating at Monta Chaya today for lunch and I was pleasantly surprised!   First off the establishment - wayyy better than the original Monta! Restaurant is clean and more spacious, however I can see this place possibly getting a bit tight during busy times. There's also more parking space in this location.   The food - my mom and I ordered Tonkotsu ramen (her order was less salty, which i liked way better..!) and a small pork belly bowl. Both were very yummy and taste similar to the broth at the original Monta. However, you still can't choose how you want the noodles cooked (reason for minus one star).  Servers were attentive and quick to refill our drinks.   I'm definitely going to make repeat visits at this place! :)

They NEVER answer the phone!! NEVER!!!  Called for 20 minutes to place a to go order.. Finally went down to place the order, tried asking the waitress how long of a wait it would be for a to go order " her response was uh I Don't know... " then she walked away AND NEVER came back to take our TO GO order.. They have Completely lost our business!!

It was our first time here as we were visiting Vegas. We came right when they opened for lunch and were one of the first people, it quickly filled up fast. The service was good, food came out fast. We ordered kaarage, Chashu buns, two tonkatsu ramens with eggs and extra Chashu pork belly on the side. The appetizers were good. The ramen not so much...sadly. The broth is salty, the more you ate it the saltier it seemed. I also felt like the broth wasn't hot enough, I like my soups hot. The good thing was that the Chashu was very soft and tender which we loved! If they made their broth less salty and more creamy it would of been great!

This little Japanese Ramen house was packed and we had to wait 15 minutes for a table at lunch. The ramen was excellent and very filling. The gyoza is also very good. You do have to make your own sauces to dip it though. I'd recommend a bit of the soy sauce, a splash of vinegar, the hot oil and a spoonful of the minced garlic. Delicious! Also, don't forget to add a spoonful of garlic to the ramen! It can be a bit salty, so drink plenty of water.

Craving pork belly?  Is it a Friday night and you need your Monta fix but don't want to travel across town to Spring Mountain?  Oh yes, it's true!  Monta Chaya opened last week and it's just like home (aka Spring Mountain).  Well, kinda.  It's even better with new menu items!  No spoiler alert... you've got to visit to check it out for yourself.  As far as your favorite menu items - yep, they're there!  My favorite is the pork belly bowl - it was beautifully prepared with tender, juicy pork belly over slightly sticky white rice served with pickled ginger.  Succulent.  The guys did their regular thing:  miso ramen with egg, chashu prok, and nori and tonkotsu ramen with egg and I can't remember what else.  We were all stuffed and well fed and well taken care of in our East-side Monta.  We're so glad you're here!

The ramen scene continues to grow. Yes Monta Chaya, Monta's sister restaurant is the latest joint to open up. I've never tried their restaurant in Chinatown but I know it's very popular with both locals and tourists. So I was excited that they opened here in Henderson.   From the parking lot you won't be able to spot it but It's located between Japan Creek and Golds Gym in the strip mall on the corner of Eastern/Serene.  The sign for their storefront will be up soon according to one of the servers I spoke to.   As with the other noodle houses, this place has  table service. Your hostess will seat you at a table or counter. I chose their counter on this visit. Their furnishings reminded me of West Elm type stuff. The dark woods used makes the place look more stylish and gives it a more upscale feel. The seating arrangement didn't feel too crowded.  My server said they were so busy right before I came and that the lunch crowd had just left.  Server gave me 2 menus one with noodle  dishes and entrees and another that Monta Chaya serves exclusively. So you know I just had to try something off the Chaya Dishes menu.  I chose Chashu Bans (bahns). This one was glazed pork belly slice in a steamed bun. They come as 2 appetizer sized portions.  The Tonkatsu Ramen I ordered is just broth and noodles. I chose to customize with add ons they had. So there is an additional charge for them.  So keep in mind your order can add up.   There was little wait from the time my order was taken to when I was served. When my order for the Tonkotsu Ramen came up, oh boy, I wasn't expecting such a huge bowl packed with noodles. My extras that I added were soft boiled egg and corn so my bowl was pretty full.   The noodle soup was really good. The pork had just enough fat, the broth was savory. I personally thought it was just a tad salty and not as rich in flavor as the Tonkotsu broth over at the noodle house on Tropicana.  Still I enjoyed my bowl of ramen.  I asked if there is a smaller portion since this was way too much noodles for me.  My server said I can just request 1/2 noodles more broth next time. They still charge you the same price.   Service here was spot on. Everyone was friendly and polite. The staff here is prepared and ready for the rush hour crowd. I'm lovin the ramen craze and welcome another one here on this side of town!

Monta Chaya is like the younger, sexier sister of Monta Ramen. Anything Monta Ramen can do, Chaya can do better.  I stopped here during the week of grand opening with my home skillet Molly T. The restaurant is much more open and spacious than its sister restaurant. The decor is simple yet modern and tasteful. The stools at the bar no longer anally penetrate your behind; they now have larger stools with rectangular cushions on top.  In addition to the standard ramen menu offered at Monta Ramen, here they offer you additional "Chaya" menu consisting of various appetizers ranging from chicken karaage to daikon salad to chasu buns to several other things in between.   The ramen menu is identical including the add on options. I went with my tried and true Tonkotsu Shoyu (soy and pork bone based broth) ramen with extra corn. The taste was every bit as good as the original location's. The noodles were cooked well and had great texture, the broth was milky and packing flavor, two pieces of chashu were solid quality and not overly fatty, and the standards that included dried seaweed, green onion, and kikurage mushroom completed the great taste.   I saw one of the cooks from the original location working in the kitchen, so it is no surprise that the taste seems consistent. The service was okay, toward the end the waitress kept hovering behind us as to hurry us along. The prices are reasonable...I think my bowl came to $7.45 with the add on. Definitley great value for both quality and quntity of ramen.
Excellent ramen and overall menu. Good service. Very consistent quality. My go to ramen spot!
Monta Chaya's ramen is my favorite.  The fried rice is so good.  It's hard to order takeout on a busy evening.
Perfect spot for lunch when you need some warming broth to fight a cold. You can add some seaweed or kimchee for a nice little touch.  Very reasonably priced.
Black garlic oil ramen is the bomb....much better than the north location....little to no wait...broth is silky and rich...awesome

Finally tried the "real ramen" that everyone raves about and loved it! I had the  Shoyu Ramen. It was basically glorified ramen noodles that you can buy from the store, but better because it was fresh and had veggies on top. The portion sizes were very filling and the service was very friendly and quick.  My favorite thing about the restaurant is they played my favorite 90s music!

Love this place! Excellent cooked noodles, clean place, tasteful decor, fast service, great portions, and reasonable prices!! I am so happy my friend took me here to eat. Will be frequenting this place- a LOT!

The food was great however the service was very slow.. I just ate here a couple minutes ago and had to wait more than 20 minutes to get our food. Not only my table but about 5 tables were waiting on their food along with a line of people waiting to eat. Maybe it's just rush hour. But if that's the case, if you're wanting to eat something right away, don't go here at that time.

I ate at Monta Chaya the other week. It was about 35 minutes before closing and the place was still packed and it wasn't even the weekend.  Service was great. Despite being crowded we were seated really quickly. The servers were quick to take our orders.  I had ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen. It included mushrooms, scallions, a hard boiled egg and charsui. It was delicious! What made the dish so great was the pork broth. It was so flavorful and balanced.  Prices were comparable to other Ramen shops. I will definitely come back to try other dishes.

I'm so glad they have a monta here in henderson!! I usually get the tonkatsu ramen and added an egg. Very delish as always! Service was great and we received our food in the right amount of time. We also sat at the bar, which was cool to see them cooking all the food. Yum yum yum!!
So good! I was never into ramen until I found this place! Sooo so good I recommend everyone go here! Delicious and its so cheap! A must try if you're in the area!

Great little location in Henderson for authentic Japanese Ramen. The Tonkotsu ramen with boiled egg and extra pork belly is my favorite. This location is pretty clean and the service is very fast. The staff is very friendly and food prices are very reasonable.

Monta Chaya is my go to spot for ramen in the Vegas Valley.  The staff is friendly, the interior is decorated well, it's clean and the food is good.  Honestly though the main reason this place is my go to is because it is located close to my house. Other ramen places I also like to go to are a bit of a drive for me. As for the ramen itself, I get the Tonkotsu Ramen and sometimes I will get the spicy version where they add a little bit of spicy sauce for you to stir into the ramen.  The ramen here is quality and what you expect ramen to be. The soup is strong, concentrated, fatty and a bit salty. It isn't the best that I've had in town but I do just happen to keep coming back. I personally prefer the thin wavy noodles, and the pork they serve here is well cooked but isn't gonna blow your socks off. It's just a solid and well balanced bowl of ramen where one aspect of it doesn't outshine any of the others. I have had a few of the appetizers and they are pretty standard. Calamari, pot stickers and fried rice are all good and worth paying for but won't be the reason you come back. People go for the ramen for sure. I come to this place because the ramen is solid and the staff are on point. If I am willing to drive a bit further though, I will going elsewhere for ramen that night.

Very good!!!!!!  The crispy rice was my FAV!!!!  The soup was large and warm and way better then ones i have tried before.... i got mine spicy and was well worth it, even though i had to add a lot more of the spices provided on the table to get it to a temp that i emjoyed.  Will be back!!!!

Saw someone share a post on Facebook and we were on our way home from the doctor so we stopped in. WOW. I am not a big fan of Ramen so we ordered some other dishes.  The Chashu Buns, were awesome. Best Gyoza best I have had. Not doughy at all. Daikon salad was light and refreshing. Crispy rice with creamy spiced tuna not real spicy, perfect and my favorite. Karaage, Japanese fried  chicken yummie, not greasy. This place will be a regular place for us.

I love the Monta Ramen on Spring Mountain.   Friends told me about the location on Eastern.  I went Friday night and it was as good as the Spring Mountain location.  A bit bigger and not quit as fast.... but, the food was spot on.  If you can't make to Spring Mountain for your ramen fix.  Hit Eastern!

Very good ramen, excellent wait staff. It's small, yes, but definitely worth it. I really liked our waiter, he was funny, chatty but not overbearing, just a cool dude sharing his noodle love with us. He also poured a perfect pint, respect. The ramen is tasty, I did not find it overly salty, and it's reasonably priced. I ordered tonkatsu with egg added, and they have chili oil at the table, and this was a winning combo. I didn't need extra noodles, got full on the standard order. A must try in the area, heck, a must try in the Valley.

Excellent service....Joe totally was a huge part of this hole experience....It is my first time eating Ramon.....I am so lucky I waited for the best....The gyoza are absolutely perfection... Tender....Well seasoned.... The Ramon is rich...Full of flavor.....You can taste the bone marrow.... Unbelievable..... Highly recommend this place
Delicious food, cool little place, friendly staff, open kitchen and clean. Will be back for sure! Thank you
Man this place is fucking good!!! The cooks are really cool to talk to. And Joseph is the best waiter in the world . Sandro makes the best ramen , definitely check this place out (X

Ramen broth and noodles were mediocre. The Takara fried rice tasted unusual--threw it away. I would not recommend this place. If you want authentic really good ramen, you should go to Ramen Sora. The noodles are flown in from Japan and the broth is very rich and delicious. The fried rice and gyoza are also extremely good.

4.5 stars.  Only because my Tonkotsu broth was too salty.  We ate at the Monta in Chinatown last yr and this place opened about 1 yr ago.  I prefer this place because there's better parking as it is located in a small mall area and the facility is nicer. We came for a late lunch at 2PM and avoided the lunch crowd.  Got seated immediately.  Service is nicer here too.  We shared a large pork belly rice.  My cholesterol was probably off the roof eating this dish but it was so good with lots of pork belly. I added corn, egg to my Tonkotsu which was also good but found the broth to be too salty and couldn't enjoy it.  Hubby added an egg to his Tonkotsu ramen. Our lunch bill came to $31 which isn't too bad for 3 dishes.  He took the leftover pork belly rice home and had it for breakfast the next day and didn't share!

Yup, the best ramen joint hand down. I seriously dont go anywhere else when I want to eat ramen because they are so consistently great! Although sometimes there may be a long wait to get into this small restaurant, its worth it! My favorite part about it is that it isnt too salty here. I've gone to many ramen places and the broth would come out way too salty for my liking, and I know ramen is naturally a salty dish, but Monta makes it just right! The service is always really good and I always leave full and satisfied. I've tried the shoyu, tonkotsu and the kuro ramens and each were very flavorful! Recommend them all. I also love adding corn and and nori to my order, plus a side of their yummy fried rice!! :)

We decided to go here on a whim because we were across the street, but I'm glad we found this place! :)   If you've been in the LA area and have been to Shin Sen Gumi Ramen....the layout of this place is EXACTLY the same...only in a larger space. I had the Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen and my dad had the Miso Ramen and both of us thought the broth was super salty :( gotta knock a star for that. Portion and food quality wise, everything was great! I'll definitely come here again! Shop was clean, prices are great, and menu is super simple. We also ordered the Spicy Tuna on Crispy Rice and they made that fresh for us too :)   Service could use big improvement though. There were only 2 tables, including us, when we stopped in and service was still super slow with 2 (wtf?!) servers.
Monta Chaya needs to finish remodeling their kitchen....I'm going through ramen withdraws.

I love ramen, like I really really like this stuff. Growing up in Southern California I was lucky to have exceptional ramen within 40 minutes of me. That being said as the weather gets cooler you have no idea how much I appreciate having a wonderful ramen restaurant near me. I have been to many ramen restaurants in Las Vegas and this is by far my favorite. The broth here is perfect. The noodles are always perfectly cooked, and their sides and condiments are great. Service here is always so patient and kind, which is appreciated since they are always packed (another tell-tale sign of a good restaurant). The wait can be long so come prepared to put your name on a list and then either grab a boboa near by, poke into the Japanese market (which is also wonderful), or hook yourself up to your smart phone/device. They also have some delicious starters such as their shishito peppers and crispy rice with spicy tuna. I took a few co-workers here, and they easily accommodated the vegetarian in our group.

The first time I pulled up to Monta Chaya there was a line out the door.  This is the sign of good food.  And so I stuck it out.   Once inside we were seated at the bar and immediately given friendly service.  I had the Spicy Tonkatsu ramen with extra pork and an egg added.  The broth was delicious.  And the spice was perfect.  This is two utensil food, you'll need to be handy with chopsticks and a spoon to fully enjoy its delicious, messy, slurpy goodness.  They also have several small salads and appetizers to choose from if you bring someone with you who isn't into ramen.  But I'd recommend encouraging them to try it - this isn't Top Ramen.  It isn't watery soup.  It is some of the most flavorful broth and meat you'll taste.  I used to hear people saying, "Ramen is life".  I never understood it.  At least that is until I set foot into traditional style ramen houses like this one.  Monta Chaya is a cozy and beautifully designed ramen house tucked into a strip mall.  The atmosphere is very authentic, despite the strip-mall location.  Head inside and expect to sit arm to arm with fellow ramen-eaters because this place is usually busy and for good reason!  Highly recommended due to quality, authenticity, and location.
Food was bomb! Don't forget to toss some minced garlic on your fried rice!! Holy moly.

I waiver between 3 and 4 stars for this spot. It's in a strip next to a Japanese market. It's tiny. It's also a popular spot. So be prepared for a wait if you are coming for dinner. (Tip: Arrive before 6:30pm.)  Everything seemed very authentic, which was nice. The menu is kept simple, mostly ramen and fried rice, plus a few other small plate options.  We started with a salad that had a nice dressing, but was rather unremarkable. We then had the pork ramen and kimchi friend rice. They also have a soy ramen, a chicken ramen, and a pork/chicken combo ramen. They also have spicy and black garlic options. I liked how the broth here was a bit thicker than other ramen places. The pork also seemed to be better. The kimchi fried rice looked nothing like the picture on the menu and wasn't spicy at all. But it was some tasty friend rice. Portions were large enough to share. Prices are quite reasonable.   Service was seriously lacking. Think you might want water later or another beer? Better order it at the very start. Your server will only come to table twice - one time to take your order (order everything at once) and one time to bring the check (you will feel rushed). Or so was the case on the day we went.  I would probably have still given this place 4 stars for the authenticity and tastiness. However, my friend and I spent all night with some seriously grumbly tummies. And holy gas! We both had some major loud and smelly terrible farts! So while it might be some tasty ramen, it's not totally worth the after effects. I don't particularly like to enjoy my ramen that way. And we didn't have that experience with other ramen places.

Monta has a special place in my heart for being the best japanese ramen in vegas.  The only I didnt like about the original location on Spring Mountain is that there is always a wait. Then one day while browsing through yelp I noticed that Monta had indeed opened one on my side of the town.  From what I can tell the broth taste the same as the original location and there is never a line.  I have been here multiple times at different hours and never had to wait.    The place is just as small as the original location but the decor is nicer since it is newer.

Great ramen in several varieties.  Friendly and fast service.  Not terribly impressed with the other menu choices, so four stars vs five.    Smaller restaurant and it gets very crowded so arrive early or be prepared to wait 15 minutes or so.     Recommended.

This was closed for a few weeks back in March for remodeling. Now I come in, it looks exactly the same with no difference than before...Not even a speck of paint. What the heck?   Again another salty bowl of Tonkatsu. At $6.95 just two thin slice of pork belly meat and a whole bowl of noodle. Yesire, you would have to add $1.50 for an egg. That's $8.40 plus tax. If you want spicy tonkatsu than it would be $7.95. I have always wondered if I order tonkatsu then request some chili, will they give it to me? Add black garlic it will be $7.95 but some restaurant they have free garlic paste. Why can't I order a regular bowl than you me garlic paste and chili as condiments?

I have tried the hot ramen and the cold noodles here and they are delicious. The prices are just right and the service is always impeccable. It is as if they took Monta Ramen and placed it right in the middle of Henderson. The appetizers are not too bad, we tried the crispy rice and that one, I could live without since the flavor was overpowered by the spicy tuna and the texture was strange as it was getting stuck in my teeth.

Their ramen is very good! They go head to head against Daikokuya (in LA) as my favorite ramen place.   I love adding extra pork slices to it. But you can add much more items if you like. My friend tends to load hers up like crazy.   Their kimchi fried rice is also really delicious! I tend to get sick of the pork belly bowl much quicker than the other dishes but still good regardless.

This is one of my favorite ramen houses in town. They have delicious food at great prices! My wife and I both ate ramen with an appetizer for under 25$! What a steal!  We started with karrage appetizer, it was a bit plain. I wish they had some sort of dipping sauce to go with it. I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen, it was very good but to be totally honest it wasn't even close to being spicy. The ramen itself was very delicious cooked to perfection.
