My wife had the miso ramen, and she too enjoyed it.   This is a very good ramen place, expect to wait to be seated as its always busy, as soon as the door opened at 5 it was already full. If you're around the area stop in for some ramen, you will not be disappointed.
Love this place. Great service, great food!!  We come so often the waiter recognizes us. If you want great ramen at a good price come here.

Yum!! With a line always out the door I often wonder why they choose to close between 2:30-5pm. I would bet if they stayed open they would have solid business throughout and people like myself, who can't take long lunch breaks, would eat here all the time. I'd eat here every day if I could get in and out in 30min! Onto the food... The ramen is on point!! The chashu is rich and buttery, the noodles taste fresh and have nice bite to them, the tonkatsu broth is creamy, rich, and so flavorful. Some of the best ramen I've ever had. Service is quick and very friendly. The chashu buns were a hit with my kids. The sauce was a little spicy for my younger child but fine for the older.  If you're looking for great ramen, Monta is a no-brainer.

Wow!   Nice find!  We ordered several dishes, as we do when we try a new restaurant.   Every dish was fresh, hot and delicious.   The staff was professional yet friendly.  The place itself was clean and efficient.  When we walked in the place was full so we sat at the counter.   Great place as our order was passed  to us as it was cooked.  Suuuuper!   Recommend for excellent food and at a reasonable priced.

This is by far one of my favorite ramen place in town.    In term of ambience and service, I would give a 5 stars. The decor is nice, staffs are friendly and humble. For foods, the calamari is so great, i believed the dipping is the same one using with shrimp tempura which was really go along well. The Tonkatsu ramen is tasty. The soup is so smooth and blended. The portion is a little too less for me, but it is okay. Overall, i was really impressed with this place and i will be back!

Previous to Monta Chaya, my expertise in the ramen area was limited to Maruchan-branded ramen - the kind that comes in a small package for a very reasonable price at your local grocery story or convenience stop.  Now, while I consider myself very proficient with the Maruchan ramen and have become a master of its varied cooking styles, Monta Chaya certainly brings real, honest, Japanese ramen to the table.  I've now been to this place twice with the same friends and each time was a great experience.  Both times I ordered the shoyu ramen and it did not disappoint.  The broth is simply delicious and is not greasy.  The pork... oh, the pork.  It's a little slice of oink heaven - it literally melts in your mouth.  Nitamago was the extra choice for both because it is so extraordinarily delicious.  Go ahead and try it - you'll love it.  (Well, unless you don't like eggs.  Then don't.)  The first time I ordered extra green onions, which wasn't the best choice.  It hid the ramen and didn't mix in well due to taking up too much space.  The second time I added the nori seaweed sheets and that mixed in a bit better.  I stirred them about and let them absorb some of the delicious broth and it was indeed a delicious mixture.  We ordered the crispy rice the first time we visited and it was also tasty!  My last visit I was really tempted to order the fried rice, but it just seems wrong to do that at a ramen shop.  Maybe I'd feel less bad if I got it to go.  My noodles on my second visit were seriously al dente, almost to the point where it was unenjoyable.  I stirred my bowl a bit and just dealt with it since everything else was so yummy.  The service seems a little hit and miss, especially for as tiny as this place is.  Servers are always nice, though.  Had a bit of a complication with my last visit but ended up getting it sorted out.  Bonus for being next to Japan Creek Market!
So good!!!! My husband and I have come here twice in less than a week. We have fallen in love with their pork belly bowl. It reminds me a lot of a yoshinoya beef bowl but way better! :)

i must say that this monta, on the southeast side of town, is a million times better than the original monta. it's so surprising that 2 businesses run by the same owners could be so very different. one of the things that i find most aggravating about businesses in inconsistency.  dining here is actually quite enjoyable. the service is always very pleasant, even during busy times. one never feels rushed to hurry up and eat, unlike the other monta where it feels as though you're putting them out just by walking through the door. i have a few dietary restrictions but the servers here are always so accommodating which is refreshing.  the soup and noodles are still not piping hot here which i find to be the only consistent thing across the two monta's. the noodles are still not my favorite and the soup is still WAY too salty for my taste. the cold noodles, however, i'm a huge fan of.  if i lived closer, i would definitely dine here more frequently. it's a solid ramen shop with good service.

An excellent place to have a delicious bowl of ramen. They also have many other tasty dishes to choose from if you're not necessarily in the mood for noodles.  There will often be a wait around meal times, but if you are a little patient the servers are friendly and prompt. You will have a good time here.
This place is amazing !! If your looking for a quick sit down place to eat for lunch this is the place the food is so delicious best calamari different but yummy !!

Still too date my first Ramen experience in Vegas was at Monta Ramen so going too Monta Chaya brought back found memories. I hardly go too Monta not out of dislike just not someone generally likes too wait. When you have Ramen Sora right down the road not as busy and just as good if not better. Few and far between see Monta. Monta Chaya brought back all the things I first love about getting me some ramen just like back home in da islands. The shoyu ramen broth LOVE it! I love the depth of flavor and the noodles are awesome. The gyoza now that is something sorely MISS. By far all the Ramen places in town been too few but truthfully not all. Monta gyoza is league by itself. I think its cooked too right on and the filling had so much flavor. I also had the kim chee fred rice as side. It was ono. Just had right balance with the kim chee not spicy at all but well rounded with the vegetables and the sauce. I am just happy that Vegas is blessed too add another great Ramen place in town. Now with so many locations not part of town in that find some good Ramen.  The biggest bonus about this location and if ever need my Monta fix for sure this is location I would go before the original. The food is the same at both locations. Just SO much nicer at Monta Chaya for obvious reason its brand new, LOT more spacious seating from tables too seating at the bar, and like the decor inside very much modern asian theme. The staff was friendly especially since went with my asian persuasian crew five of us in all. They did great job of staying on top of our drinks and everything coming out in timing matter. So if in the area need your Ramen fix Monta Chaya is place too get some!!!

Waaaay better than their original Spring Mountain location which can be attributed to a larger seating area, zero crowds and better service. You won't have to wait 45 min for a table here and your food will be out soon after the order goes in, especially because the servers here take your order with a tablet type device.  I've been to this location a couple times now and as always with Monta I typically get a Tonkotsu ramen or pork belly bowl. The broth in the ramen seems much better here than what I remember with the Chinatown location since it isn't as salty. The chasu pork is always juicy and buttery tasting and I wish they would give more than 2 pieces. The pork belly bowl is perhaps the best non-ramen option here since the pork is also juicy and full of flavor. They also have fried rice, gyoza and other goodies on the menu if you're not a ramen lover.  Everything on the menu is around the $7-8 range which makes this place very reasonable and affordable. Like other reviews have stated, you probably don't get as many toppings in your ramen as other spots around town, but at Monta's price point this is probably the best ramen you'll find.

My first time at this location.   I ordered Tonkotsu with thick noodles and added egg and corn.  I did not care for the seaweed that comes with it.  The soup was overall better than the one I had at the spring mountain location.  It was still too salty for my palette. I've had really amazing ramen... This just isn't one of them for me.

Finally, Monta has opened up on my side of town; no longer do I have to traverse the I-15 and hazard Desert Inn Road with all the wonky crazies that can't drive for squat, all just to gamble on whether I'll be seated immediately (22 seats) or get to wait outside with the throng of addicts like I'm outside a methadone clinic in the Tenderloin...  And to be quite frank, with ALL the Ramen joints popping up like hedgehogs in town, I'm almost over it....almost.  My first love is Monta, and I have a sweet spot for the food and the people who have been terribly authentic and hospitable. I have never had a bad experience there, and the food is on point!  And it's is soo damn close, I could stop by here almost everyday which is all too tempting.  It's right beside my Japanese food store, Japan Creek, (same owners) which happens to be right next to my gym!  Talk about pure evilness...  As of right now, there's no signage, so you'll just have to remember that it's next to Japan Creek; the most awesome Japanese food store in Vegas.  Albeit compact, they have the best produce for Japanese dishes, as well as Sushi grade fish, Pork and Beef sliced for Sukiyaki or Shabu Shabu.  All just another way to sidetrack me off my clean diet, but really, I only really workout so that I can eat the things I love....it's a build/destroy existential quagmire that I secretly believe adds an insensible depth of character...or I'm just difficult and stupid-whatevs...  As you walk in, it's definitely an airier, well designed space, more than the original- a Monta 2.0 if you will... With some nice design elements and a little more decoration, you still have the central Noodle Bar where all the action happens, with just a few more tables than its predecessor.  What's different is the enlarged waiting area right in the front that's effectively blocked off, there's nothing more annoying than trying to eat while you have the eyes of hungry customers drilling evil death eyes at your back for your seat.  My evil side takes over;  I take even more leisurely time to finish, carrying a long conversations about roman shades and Twilight... Yeah, I'm that guy... hate me but the anticipation makes the food taste much better, so I'm doing you a HUGE favor!  At Monta Chaya, the menu is little more expansive, along with your tradition Gyoza, there's actually an appetizer or two not traditionally served in a Ramen shop: you have some fried Calamari Rings, Chicken Karage and some Salads too.  An expanded menu is a welcome addition to the simple menu.  I always order a plate of Gyoza, and it's as much a mark of the restaurant as the Ramen.  I like to put a little Soy, hot Chili Oil and grated Garlic into my little sauce place and dip these suckers in and pop them whole.  I was surprised that they came out broken up, I usually expect them to be stuck together, as well, there wasn't that crispy, almost burnt crust that make that satisfying oral contrast with the juicy filling.  But the quality was excellent, just a little execution mishap.  As it has gotten really warm, I have a cut off for Ramen (it just gets my body temp. so hot I sweat like I took a shower with my clothes on).  But luckily, Monta serves up my favorite Summertime dish: the Hiyashi Chuka (Cold Chinese) - a broth-less dish, you have cold Chinese Egg Noodles with a choice of Sesame or Yuzu (Japanese Lime) Sauce with Toppings of: Chasu Pork, Tomatoes, Cucumbers, Bean Sprouts, Shredded Cooked Egg, Kikurage (Wood Ear Mushrooms) and Memma (Bamboo Shoots).  This dish is perfect on a hot day, when you just want to eat something cool yet filling.  I love Sesame sauce like a beast, it's my go to for just about everything; dipping sauce, salad dressing you name it.  At first you may look at this dish and think, what the hell? Why am I eating a salad with these odd non salad ingredients?  And this isn't really Chinese is it?  Well, yes and no, kind of a Chinese/Japanese hybrid that, well, if you kinda of crave after you've had it a couple of times.    As usual, Monta Chaya did not disappoint, I loved the service and the food is always on par.  I will have to try the Ramen soon, I just have to hope for a cold night, which is rare for us in April!!   Ratings (Out of Five Stars) Food:          5 Ambience:  5 Service:      5

This Monta is slightly bigger than the one on Spring Mountain, and seems to have a bit more items on their menu (They have pork bao! I might try that next time). However, the taste/flavor of their ramen doesn't meet my expectations after being a regular at Monta Spring Mountain.   Don't get me wrong, it was still good, but not great. I would've given this place 4 stars... but, during my quest to devour all the ramen, i bit into something hard. Upon further inspection, it seemed to be a wood chip? It was dark brown in color, so it couldn't have come from my chopsticks (your typical wooden tan disposable chopsticks). My best guess is it was from a wooden ladle when they were dishing out the broth? I guess I shall never know. It was towards the end of my meal, so I just left it as is.

Monta ramen on spring mountain is by far the best ramen in town and I was excited to see that they have expanded. My favorite part about monta was that the menu was short and each dish was made with the highest quality and taste. With that being said I decided to make a stop to the new branch and I noticed they had added a few more items to the menu so I decided to try the pork bun. The pork was dry, smushed between lettuce, ketchup, and mayo. Needless to say it was gross, so I waited for my ramen but wasn't impressed. The broth was lacking in flavor, and the egg was way over cooked. I will definitely be sticking to my favorite monta spot in china town.
Delicious...  Small and quaint! Friendly and helpful staff.  Great menu with quality food. Pork belly bowl was amazing! Ramen is so yummy...

I'm giving this 4 stars because of past visits and how good it's been.   Today it was kind of a miss for us. We get the tonkotsu shoyu which normally is so good. But this time the broth was kinda greasy and tasted funny. The pork had a weird flavor to it as well.  The fried rice is always soo good. Does it have crack in it? The pork and onions just so easy to eat. I wish the portion was bigger because it's so good.  Just because today the flavor was a little different in our soups. We will continue to come here we love this place.

"Irasshaimase!" - oh yeah, this is going to be some good ramen, I have a good feeling about this one.  The greetings are loud and welcoming from the entire staff of Monta Chaya. After doing a search for ramen on Yelp, I narrowed things down to a few and this was my first choice based on the menu.  The menu is simple and true to a few styles of authentic Japanese ramen - Tonkatsu, Shoyu or Miso. What truly drew me in was the claim of homemade Tonkatsu - pork bone soup simmered for hours.  We ordered one Tonkatsu with a seasoned egg and my wife the Spicy Tonkatsu with corn. So a small pork belly on rice.  Tonkatsu was spot on! Thick rich savory broth with thin ramen noodles and traditional Japanese ramen garnishes. The seasoned egg is awesome, runny with a firm delectable outer white and adds the perfect additional element to the soup.   The spicy Tonkatsu was not really spicy, more of a chili flavor. My wife agreed that the corn was not a good choice to add. I think the corn would be better on the miso.   Hello pork belly! The pork belly on rice was so good that we both agreed that it would make a stellar stand alone meal. The pork is soft and savory, the fatty juices flavoring the rice underneath and the pickled ginger on top the perfect compliment.  On the table is the full spread of condiments to make your ramen your own. I love the chili oil, sesame and chili powder with a dash of vinegar.  Slurp loudly to show appreciation for your ramen as done in Japan!   On the way out the door, the staff erupts in an enthusiastic "Arigato Gozimashta!!!"  We will be back, the miso looks amazing :)  Aloha!

I really love their ramen when I order it less salty (say usume). I get the miso ramen usume style and add chasu pork and takana leaves. I also get a side of kimchi which tastes really good with the ramen. As an appetizer, I like the crispy rice which is topped with tuna tartar. The only con I would say is their pork is very fatty.

So you're craving some ramen from Monta but don't feel like driving all the way to Chinatown or waiting a long time just to get in. Well good news Monta fans. They opened up another location and the wait isn't as crazy as the original location.  The location seems far especially if you're not in the area but really for the long waiting time at the original location you could still drive to this location, eat, and leave in less time, actually I did that once even stopped by the original location before I was told the wait was over an hour.  The menu are made up of a variety of ramen and non-ramen items. I haven't had any of their non-ramen items, cause it's a ramen place. For the ramen you start with one of 4 base ramen selections (tonkotsu, shoyu, tonkotsu shoyu, and miso) and then add extra items to it if you wanted (extra pork, egg, nori, corn, etc.) for an extra charge. The base ramen selections aren't priced to bad but adding more extras really does add up. Plus they have a $10 minimum for credit card so you might have to added extra items. I thought the shoyu and tonkotsu shoyu are very salt to my liking and so I don't ever order them anymore but the tonkotsu and miso with a lot of extra items added :) They even have a spicy tonkotsu and another ramen that is shown off the regular menu. Some might say taste are different from here and the original location but to me they taste about the same to me, even might like it here more.  Just in case you were wondering, here, I order my tonkotsu or miso ramen with extra pork, egg, corn, and some spices and shoyu I add in myself from the table. Not bad. It's a decent substitute when I can't make it to my favorite ramen place and if I added more it would be to much for a bowl of ramen.   The interior is nice and spacious compared to the original location. The parking situation here is a lot better also. Customer service and speed, besides the initial waiting time to get seated, is about the same.   I'm not a huge fan of Monta in general but I'll enjoy a bowl here now and then. A lot of people love Monta and say they're the best. I don't know about that. They're good but enough for a 3.5 from me.
Visit Monta often and each time is just as good as the last. In todays time its hard to find a place that is consistently good. If consistency is key then Monta is your place.

This place has the best ramen in town. I have gone on a search for the best and I always end up back here. You can add to the noodles too. I usually add corn and kimchi. I also like that they can make any of them spicy. I have to be in the mood for the spicy though because it is crazy spicy. If you want the soup a little spicy, they can also put it on the side for you.
Good ramen. This location is right near my house so it is a lot more convenient that monta in Chinatown. They get 5 stars on their charsu buns alone. They will change your life

Monta Chaya has food as amazing as Chinatown sister property Monta Ramen, but without the long lines and drive to Spring Mountain Road. They greet you when you walk in, similar to a sushi bar. Clean, friendly. Delicious ramen broth/noodles/meat. My favorite is the Tonkotsu. One nitpick: I wish they would serve fountain drinks/fresh tea instead of canned cola and tea.

A few days ago we walked in exactly 1 minute before close. They still seated us and took our order no problem. Working in the food industry I know that's not a nice thing to do so we decided to take our food to go. They were quick, friendly, and the food was great!
Very good noodles i don't do pork asked for chicken but none was in the dish still great meal

Our go-to-ramen place. Affordable and yummy! Pick-up/take out customer service is also good. The only thing is this place is small and easily gets packed that's why we haven't attempted eating in yet. Plus the release of pickup order takes awhile. Even if you call ahead you still have to wait for them to prepare your order. Regardless I still like Monta Chaya and I will continue to order pickup from them.
This is not an actual review but monta Chaya is closed due to construction until 3/31/17   imagine the pain I was in... NO RAMEN  FOR ME

I came here a few nights ago, and it was a really cute small restaurant. It was a bit busy, I ordered the spicy shoyu ramen and added meat. it was very soggy and mostly fat. The broth was yummy and I think they messed up my order because it wasn't spicy at all. Overall, it's a good ramen place but I wouldnt come back.
The ramen here is decent. Sometime the broth is a hit or miss. It can be very good one day and it can be very salty the next.

Small place... have to wait sometimes if you're there during busy hours.  Wait staff is super attentive most of the time.    Now for the ramen. Ramen is solid except for the Tonkotsu. I find it to be too thick of broth for my taste and makes me nauseous after I eat it. Some people like it like that.  I know Tonkotsu is supposed to be thick but this place does it thicker than most others I have tried. So due to that I do Shoyu when we eat here and it's great every time.    Gyoza is ok. Fried rice is on point. I wasn't a fan of the crispy rice but others seem to love it.  Overall this is a solid ramen joint and I'm glad it's right by my house when I crave ramen.

This was seriously the best. Food was amazing. The pork literally melted in your mouth. I added the egg to my ramen and the yoke made the broth even better. The staff was great. Fast, friendly, and courteous.
Pretty good Shoyu Ramen soup with the hot chili oil.  Gyoza Dumplings and calamari were tasty. Highly recommend this ramen restaurant!  It was busy, so be prepared for quite a wait.

I've had the opportunity to enjoy Monta Chaya five times now and can confirm that it is my favorite noodle restaurant.  Always delicious with generous ingredients, I enjoy stopping by for lunch and sitting at the counter.
Five stars for what it is - Simple menu, good food, clean.  Good service and friendly waitstaff.

There's something soothing about having ramen on a cold night like tonight. For the first time, this place isn't as packed as it always is though we still had to wait a couple of minutes to have a seat available.   Their chicken karaage appetizer came in huge pieces but their presentation was a little plain. Other places would serve it with a little ginger salad on the side but theirs didn't. It was literally just the chicken, a little tomato, a shishito pepper and a lemon wedge. It tasted good which is why I always order it!   My best friend and I basically ordered the same thing, mine with many substitutes. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen is my favorite! I'm personally not a fan on the bamboo so I had them take those out and substitute my thin noodles to the thick kind. I recommend you to get the thick noodles because it's more filling and it doesn't break as easily.  Not too expensive either. Our ramen was about $7-8 each and the karaage was $4-5. Not a bad price for a good dinner.  My servers name was Joe. He's super cookyyyyy! I love how he shares stories of himself and chats with you. He even told this guy next to me a tip about his beer. He said that if the bubbles or fizz was thicker than his thumb, it's not a good pour? I think that's what I heard. I'm not even sure what that means since I don't drink beer but it sounds like an expert tip. Great customer service!
Best Ramen I've tasted! The service was also great! Gyoza were incredible! So were pork belly!

Update number 2- I know this is my second up date and I'm a bad bad girl for doing so. BUT I had to let you guys know about this. I know most of you should have heard/seen the "new" menu for monta, and it is now out. They have a "spicy" ramen and a "black garlic" ramen. I came here for lunch and got the tonkatsu shoyu with the black garlic oil on the side.    OH MY GODS!!! Okay, I didn't use all of it because, I didn't want to over power the taste of the actual soup, but it added such a depth of flavor. For most who don't know what black garlic taste like it has a sweet, carmalized type taste and it still has a garlicy finish, it's so good and I recommend it :).
Delicious Ramen, the best I've ever had. =) Their cripsy rice sushi is also delicious. =) It's so neat to sit at the bar and watch all the hard work that goes into preparing the delightful food. =)
Best ramen in Vegas! I use to live in Japan and this place reminds me of home. Great food and great service! Try the Tonkotsu Ramen and Pork belly bowl!

2minutes from my house . This place will get you full for 6 bucks but taste better then all the other"ramen" places out there. Wish I could just live here and just eat all day and night and morning ...sorry getting carried away ,you get my drift

Soup on a cold winter's night is just what the body needs.  I'd give Monta Chaya a solid 4.5 stars.  It's just like the original Monta over on Spring Mountain, but with a bigger space.  The food is great, the people are super sweet and friendly, and the prices are cheap!    That being said, they get super busy, especially during this time of year--expect a bit of a wait during peak eating hours.  At times, they can use a few more people serving--it's THAT busy.  Big parties are welcome, but with so many people coming in, it can take a little longer to get a big party seated together.  Just a thought to keep in mind.  Ordering to-go is also another great option.  They can cook it for you or you can prepare it at home for fresh tasting ramen in the comfort of your own home ;)
This was the first time I tried ramen. I'm hooked!!!! You need to try the spicy with kimchi added. Sticky rice was awesome.

I will go to Monta Chaya probably every time I go to Vegas from now on.  A ton of interesting dishes as well as some good strong staple dishes.  We got the cold noodles without meat (delicious), the mustard greens fried rice (awesome), and a salad that I honestly can't remember right now.    All the ramen dishes around us looked great and since this place is open pretty late (11pm) it was pretty packed at night.

Tried this place hoping it would be as good as Sora Ramen but I was very disappointed. The broth to me tasted a little burnt. Their spicy miso was basically just the miso broth with a spicy taste almost like a Korean paste? It was not as satisfying as I had hoped.  If you have never tried Sora Ramen, you should. Their broth is far better. Their customer service is fantastic. I don't think I'd try Monta again. It was just disappointing.

Ordered to go, spicy miso ramen with extra chasu & corn, chasu bao, & gyoza. All was excellent. Killer bao... it was a small dining area, with very little space  for to go people to wait. There was a waiting list, but it's worth the wait. I think Fukamini tan tan men ramen is superior but the apps were by far better. I highly recommend. Food was 4 1/2 but rounded down for tiny dining area & wait.

There was 9 parties before us. I was concerned about the time after waiting for 20 min to get my 16 year old to her job. We placed our order to go. Our table got called after we placed our to go order,  I asked "Yuki" the hostess to shift our order to dine in since our table came up- "your order is getting bagged now." We waited 12 more minutes- yes we are freaks we were on a time frame so we were timing every second, 12 min, after yuki says your order is getting bagged our to go order was finally ready! 3 more tables were seated in that 12 min. Why did you not just let us sit yuki when I had 2 children with me, when our table came up and we had ample amount of time to receive our food that had not even been bagged yet.  When I asked for yukis name the 2 other servers did not want to give it.  I do not care how good the food is. If the service is not good, nothing else matters.

Monta is me and my boyfriends favorite ramen place. We love it so much we couldn't find a better place here, LA, or in San Diego! We love it so much that we actually came here for our first date! I got so excited when I heard that they're opening up a second location. My boyfriend was recording on this side of town so we decided to go in after! It was next to a Denny's so it's pretty easy to find.   The place is small, just like Monta on Spring Mountain but it is bigger than it at the same time. But you don't feel as crowded in there. I'd say a table or two more. But then again I can't really complain because that's traditional in Japan. Their menu is actually bigger than Monta on Spring Mountain's!!! More ramen choices (but who needs it?) and more appetizers! We decided to get the ramen this time and next time, we're going to try all the new appetizers! I got miso with butter. Their miso is my favorite. It's also only $6.95... I think I spend more on myself at Mcdonalds!!! And the butter makes it creamier. It's my favorite ramen ever! I'll always be a Monta customer. I can't wait to come back for appetizers!!!   I love the items they put on the side as well. They have garlic, ginger, vinegar, soy sauce, garlic powder, and more! You put in as much as you want too so it's not too salty or saltless.   I seriously appreciate the owner for Monta. He owns my favorite ramen place and also my favorite sushi place Goyemon!   Tip: I love taking the leftover broth home and putting it in my food (like top ramen or udon.) Sooo good!
Monta Chaya is our favorite ramen joint in Henderson.  It rivals the ramen spots in Chinatown and you can't beat the price.  Love this place!

How I missed you Tonkotsu!  I want to hug you and squeeze you and call you George.  And boy am I glad you are available with less waiting time and more food options!!!  HELLO MONTA CHAYA!  I'm sorry folks but to me there is no debate, Monta has the most amazing ramen in Vegas!  When my bowl arrived with those very thin fatty slices of pork, wood ear mushrooms, bamboo shoots, scallions, an almost cooked egg and thin soft strands of noodles... my heart skipped a beat.  I looked down on it lovingly like it was my newborn babe... it was perfect.  And the broth... sigh... I am going to crave this broth every time I am sick. Or cold. Or hungover. Or pregnant. Or missing some good ol' comfort food.    We arrived in the Henderson location at 8pm and waited 10minutes for a table (both the Henderson and Chinatown locations are real tiny).  Hubby who is unfortunately not a ramen fan enjoyed his pork belly rice bowl immensely.  And I almost had a foodgasm with the chicken karaage dipped in the garlic puree (how do they make this???!!!).  The chicken was so moist and crispy and savory, while the garlic puree added a little tang to it. The skinny strips of marinated daikon offered refreshing relief in between the rich spoonfuls of ramen.  Perfect scores all around from food to ambiance to pricing to alcoholic drinks available to great service.  Wish you were next door Monta Chaya! (or maybe I should move?)
Best ramen restaurant in Vegas in my opinion. Always get additional nori and egg on your ramen. They also have a very friendly staff and the restaurant is nice and clean.

Love this place. I come for the ramen stay for the bao.   I love their ramen. Their broth isn't too salty and fatty. Their prices are decent and pretty cheap. The wait staff is very friendly and very attentive. They always make sure glasses are filled with drinks and the tables are cleaned from any accumulated debris. The atmosphere is very casual. Monta Chaya is set up like a traditional Japanese restaurant. Simple and clean. One of my favorite aspects (besides the food) is that the wait staff takes your order on Ipad minis. Super Kawaii I must say.lol

This may be a small place, but it has one of the best foods out here in Las Vegas! They have more on their menu than their original counterpart on Spring Mountain, and it's a bit more spacey as well. I have never tasted their ramen, since I always order their fried rice, rice bowls, cold noodles, and one of the appetizers. They gave my taste buds the feeling of a champion eater! Their condiments and sauce were incredibly unique and gave extra taste to my buds. This is about 30 minutes away from home, but I go here just to experience how their food is never ending delicious! Friendly staff as well, and their cooks are informative as well. I like how they take their orders from an IPad, plus their waitresses are cute hehe :D. I have never tasted any food similar to theirs because they probably have their own unique ingredients. And the price is a little on the cheap side.  I recommend this to everyone, whether you're a fan of Japanese foods or not, because this will transform your taste buds forever.

Ramen was delicious! I only wish the soup was hotter! Everything was fresh! Service was great! The ambiance of the place was good as well. Not a very large location! Definitely coming back here trying other items on the menu!

Came back a few days ago when it was cold outside and I needed my hot soup fix.  Ordered the Kuro "Black Garlic Oil" Ramen.   It's a very strong garlic flavor, your soup comes out black.  If you like the taste of Garlic (like I do) this is a really good soup.  I didn't even have to add anything to it.     Also got the crispy rice that everyone else here mentioned.  I liked it a lot.  It kind of satisfies a mini-sushi craving you might have.     Still a great location, I've yet to see this place full.  Which is a good thing for me.  When I want my ramen, I want it now! =)
Great Ramen at great prices! Also, try the: crispy rice, daikon salad, and get an Asahi on draft.

I can't get enough of their pork belly bowl! Best place in town for an amazing price. I feel like I come here at least twice or three times a month. Ramen would be 4/5 rating. Staff is nice especially funny young guy who's like a comedian and pours the Asahi draft to the brim. Perfection!!! (His brother taught him well)

We had the spicy miso ramen (extra nori/seaweed) and the tonkotsu (pork) ramen and side is gyoza....as the ramen was good as usual and always consistent but the gyoza was just "ok"...needed more nira (Japanese Chive) and more cabbage for the crunch consistency and texture.  Service is nice and friendly and very efficient with a lot of energy and smiles and follow-up service so I tipped the girls some extra cash.  This place is always good and clean and consistent and the service on point so thank you and arigato :)

Spicy Miso Ramen is awesome. Crispy rice is great and pork belly and fried rice is delicious! Great place to go during slow hours. Not too many tables so you'll be waiting for at least 30 minutes for a table but quick for the bar area.

3 words.  PORK. BELLY. BOWL.   End of review.   Ok, just kidding. This is my first time here at this location but have been to the Spring Mountain one numerous times. I must confess, I have only had one of their ramen bowls and that was a Spicy Tonkatsu Bowl while my wife got the small Pork Belly Bowl. Once I tasted her Pork Bowl, I had to get one. Good thing they have a small size because while I was waiting for my order, I literally finished my wife's Pork Bowl. So of course I gave her my order when it got there. Yes, I still finished my bowl as well.  Whats so fancy about the Pork Belly Bowl you say? Well, its basically thick cut bacon that I think has been marinated in some kind of soy sauce and just grilled enough for to be cooked but not to the point that it gets crispy. They put it on top of a bowl of rice accompanied by shredded green onion and pickled ginger. I usually throw some sesame seeds and a mixture of red pepper flakes on top of there that is provided in shakers right on your table. This gives your dish even more good flavor.   As mentioned earlier, there are two sizes, Small ($3.95) and Regular ($5.75). I usually get the regular and most of the time it fills me up. On those times that I am really hungry, I have them add a side of Chasu Pork ($2.50) on top of it. If you refer to my pic, the Pork Chasu is basically 4 thinly sliced pieces of Pork Chop that is cooked the same way as the pork belly.   I like this location slightly better than the one in Chinatown because its almost twice as big so waiting is not as long. Of course the thing that takes it down to a 4 is that its way further away from my house. So whenever I am in the area, Pork Belly in my belly is a real possibility.   In closing, sorry if you are looking for a great review for ramen. Yes, its still available and you can still order it. Did I mention just how good the Pork Belly Bowl is?  Yelp 2014 365 Review Challenge #116 "Get in my belly you Pork Belly!"

Yes, YES YES!!!  Im trying to start a yes chant.   There's a reason I never miss Monta when I am in Las Vegas, it is that damn good.  It rivals legendary Ramen spots in LA (Little Tokyo) like Shin Sen Gumi, Orochon, and Diakokuya.    I have always gone to the Monta Ramen location, and I figured i'd try the Chaya location.  Right off the bat, better decor, and better parking and just enough little differences in the menu to separate it from the Monta Ramen location.  Get an order of the Fried Rice on the side, its a must and really completes the experience!   Hits:     Different Ramen options, Fried Rice, and topping Cons:   Long wait times (worth the wait though)
Best ramen in town for sure! cheap, quick, filling, and great service! In such a good area, overall just a fantastic restaurant

That was really good! Got the standard ramen noodles with pork, corn and green onions. All of it was really good and made my night. I'm pretty sure I'll be visiting this spot often especially since it's right down the street from the house. This is one of those spots that if you're really in the mood for great ramen noodles you might drive across town to get these here. I would avoid going with a group since it's the size of my closet but ordering out you're good to go! Plus I like to take mine home and warm it up in another pot so it's real warm when it's time to eat instead of luke-warm.
Best ramen at the best prices. There is a couple new things on the menu check it out!

I'm a novice when it comes to ramen, but it was as good as advertised. I loved the silky smooth and rich broth of the tonkotsu ramen ($6.95) and the 2 slices of pork were so tender you barely need to chew.  The chashu buns ($5) weren't bad. I loved the pork and the mild spiciness of the sauce, but wasn't crazy about the cold, wet lettuce.   Seating is somewhat limited so avoid peak dining hours unless you're willing to wait. Prices are a bargain for what you get and if you're planning on paying with a credit card there's a minimum order of $10.  4.5 Stars

Came here after a workout. Definitely has pretty good ramen. Just a bit too oily for my taste buds, but that's me personally. Other people may enjoy the oily part. I would give it 5 stars but the service was just too slow. The wait took a while and then it took another for 15 minutes to get my food. With that said, I will still go back because it's convenient and right next to the gym.

Summerlin-ers have every right to be jealous, since the newly opened Monta Chaya in Henderson is every bit as good as the flagship Monta, thereby negating the need to make the drive to Spring Mountain.  If  Monta Chaya is the sister restaurant to Monta, I would liken the former to Monta-ca (er...I mean Monica) Cruz, Penelope Cruz's younger and less famous sister, who is every bit as beautiful with perhaps more charm and flare for style (she's a fashion designer and world class flamenco dancer).  This comes in the form of a more spacious interior with higher ceilings, located next door to the adorable  Japan Creek Market (borrowing a page from Fukumimi Ramen which also has an adjacent Japanese market next door), and the additional flight of "chaya" appetizers consisting of the following: *chicken karaage *flash-fried shishito peppers *daikon salad with shredded egg,rice crackers, seaweed, and Wafu dressing *fried calamari in broth  *chasu buns (similar to Ippudo in Manhattan) *Hakusai salad (napa cabbage, crispy chili threads, crunchy noodles, sesame dressing)  Ramen and standard appetizers appears identical to the original location, and I went with the Hiyashi Chuka, which appears primarily during the warm months at Monta, so not sure if they plan on keeping this as a permanent item.  The Hikyashi Chuka is a cold ramen without broth which I liken to a bizarro version of the Korean bibimbap (hear me out) Rather than piping hot rice, assortment of julienned veggies, bulgogi, red chili paste, and fried egg mixed together in the Korean dish, you have nice firm cold noodles topped with julienned scrambled egg, cucumbers, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, sprouts, marinated pork belly, sweet pickled radish, tomato, and a dollop of Japanese mustard on the side and your choice of sesame or yuzu dressing.  Deciding to feel a bit more untraditional, I went with yuzu and the dish was a refreshing mixture of textures, colors, and interplay of sweet spicy salty and sour.  Word of caution: unless you want to simulate biological warfare on your sinuses, do not mix the entire portion of japanese mustard into the mix.  Just use the end of your chopstick and do a light schmear into each bite to get that little hit much like you would for wasabi on sushi.        A wonderful addition to the ever-expanding ramen scene in Las Vegas and which will hopefully keep Shoku Ramen nearby on its toes so that the victors in the battle for ramen supremacy in Henderson will ultimately be diners like ourselves.

Excellent ramen! Possibly the best ramen I've had in the US. Small restaurant, almost always a wait unless you go alone and snag a seat at the bar.   Tonkotsu Shoyu broth is a mix of chicken and Tonkotsu -which I think is the best broth they have. Full flavored, creamy but not too rich. It's served with thin ramen noodles but I prefer the thicker ramen noodles.   The Tonkotsu broth alone is just a touch too rich for me -- and the Kuro Ramen, which is Tonkotsu with black garlic is sooooo heavy and rich you practically chew the broth. I had to use mouthwash every hour after eating just to get that intense salty-umami taste out.   I recommend adding on additional chashu (4 pieces for $2.50) and egg ($1.50).

I always get the crispy rice and kimchi fried rice (yuuummm) along with ramen (usually the black garlic kuro). My new favorite thing to do is add some of the spicy oil provided on the table/bar to the fried rice (so good!). My fiance and I tend to go in at good times with very little to no wait and we always leave satisfied.
Amazing service and this is a legit noodle spot. The food was quickly prepared and still packed a punch. It can get busy quick so calling ahead probably isn't a bad idea.

As a fukumimi fan i'll admit monta is pretty good. But not better than fukumimi karage or chicken ramen. Also the people @ fukumimi are much more nice and accommodating to altering the menu.  As a giant fat ass that I am I try to avoid ramen.  Calamari is really good here too.

To be honest I used to hate monta.  But when they opened this location I've been going ever since. Plus, it's close to my place and my gym. But the only problem is... They don't have any desserts (sucks!)  but the service is really good & food.

Amazing. The fried rice might be better than the ramen... no, not better. As good as the ramen. There's a wait every time you go, but it's never long and well worth it. Do yourself a favor and run to this restaurant. You'll be an instant ramen fan.

Great place! Both the ramen and the appetizers are pretty good! Only thing that would make this place better would be a BIGGER space. It's kind of small (both Vegas locations), so it's limited seating which basically means there's almost always a decent wait time. So I only suggest this place if you're not on a time constraint!

The noodles are not that good and the service is terrible. Showed up and the person working there greeted us with "Who are you?". Too many other options to ever go back. I'd rather eat my $1 Ichiban ramen

This is one of my favorite place to go for ramen. I even think that it is better then the original one on Spring Mountain.  The wait is not as long and they offer more items on their menu. My husband loves the garlic ramen.  It's so garlicky which is perfect! I also really like the daikon salad and their gyoza.

I love this location especially because of the stellar service and more spacious than the Spring Mountain locations.  Joe is always such an awesome server; very personable, helpful, and attentive! Not to mention hilarious. I've tried everything on the menu, to be honest. I usually get the Shoyu Ramen with a side of spicy and nori. Another great one is the Tonkatsu Shoyu! I am looking to try the Garlic ramen next. The karaage is delicious, as well as the pork Chashu buns! Everything is awesome! Thanks Joe for always being such a great server. :)
After they closed it for 3 months I didn't see any changes in the interior. I noticed the noodle bowl they are using is now smaller so the portion is smaller too.

When I'm sick, I'm a baby. A baby who wants Ramen.   I caught a cold my GF and wanted something warm and broth like. Monta Chaya popped up on my Yelp app and within few minutes my order was placed and I was in swimming in Ramen. I normally get nervous about getting Ramen to go, this one of those foods you need eat quickly while it's still piping hot, if not, it could thicken up and be gross. This was not the case with Monta, they smartly keep everything separate to avoid a very mushy...  everything.    I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen, which the broth is made from boiling pork bones. This was pretty damn good. Crunchy veggies and was seasoned very well and not over salty. Which is a common ramen mistake. Ha, That rhymes.   I ordered an side of extra side pork for the ramen and some gyoza. The pork was super fatty and could have been cooked a tad longer, but still a great addition to the ramen. The fried gyoza had great flavor and were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Just like I like em'!   Solid take out spot and the food was ready in about fifteen minutes, from phone call to pick up.

Our family loves this place. Food is good, prices are fair, and customer service has always been great. Only gave 4 stars because space is so small, there is usually a wait (though short), and for some reason they have split hours: open in morning, then close, then reopen. I went one day and was turned  away because they were about to close, only to reopen a few hours later. Odd.

The food here is always mmwah! Delicious! I'm not a huge ramen fan in general (too filling!) so I usually get the Mini Mentaiko Bowl and homemade potstickers or fried rice. The Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen broth that my boyfriend usually orders is excellent though :D   This Monta doesn't have a wait either. Definitely coming to this location from now on.

Japanese Comfort Food  On a cold night a few weeks ago, I needed some hot soup to warm me up, and this place did it just right.    Now... it's a tiny place... sits like 32 people, I think.  And on a cold Saturday night at 6:15pm there was a wait.   You walk in... write your name on the clipboard and hang out until one of the staff calls your name. Our wait was 35 minutes.  We were seated at the bar where we could see what our neighbors ordered and check out the action in the kitchen.  They turn food out quick in this place.  We were fed and out the door in like 25 minutes.... and we were NOT rushed at all.  At least, I didn't feel rushed. I had a warm tummy full of comfort food so I was a happy camper.  What We Ordered: * Hot Green Tea - this came in a can.  Can't say that I enjoyed it and wouldn't order it again.  It tasted 'ok'.  Not like what I was expecting, and the can definitely threw me.  * Tonkotsu Ramen - I thought this was "creamy". * Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen - This was lighter than the Tonkotsu.  I'd order this one again.  Both had lots of noodles, but the broth could be a bit hotter.  It was perfect when it was served but cooled fairly quickly... so I guess you have to eat it fast to keep it hot.  All of the ramens are pretty basic and then you have "add-ins" to make your ramen heartier or whatever.  I was happy with the basic ramen.  I wanted noodles and a comforting broth.  I got just that!  Pricing is fairly inexpensive.... I mean compared to most sit-down restaurants.  Compared to a Pho place... this place is few dollars more but not much.

So...there's this ramen place near me in SLC that I frequent maybe once or twice a month...and this place blows them out of the water. Like...without even breaking a sweat.  When we got there, it was packed (which seems to be a common theme), but we were seated fairly quickly (maybe a 10 minute wait?). And the best part, we got seated at the bar, which means I got a perfect view of the kitchen (I really love watching their operation--and this place has a well-oiled operation, let me tell you). Didn't take long for our server to come by for our drink order--super talkative (almost too much so), but super friendly. **Note: get the Calpico, you won't regret it.  I ordered the black garlic ramen and my boyfriend got the spicy tonkatsu, and we ordered the takana fried rice...and they were all FAB. Now...I read in a previous review how disappointed they were that the black garlic wasn't spicy--I'd like to clarify that reading the menu, I'm not sure where they got the idea it'd be spicy to begin with. The broth is really rich, and REALLY garlicky (hence the name), but not spicy. If you want spicy, I'd go with the spicy tonkatsu--one, it's in the name, and two, it's delightful. And don't get me started on that fried rice...holy crap, was that good.  If you're waiting for your food, take a moment to appreciate what's going on in that kitchen--it's mesmerizing. They had a packed house that night, and not one person back there was slacking. Every single one of them were on fire, our food came out surprisingly fast, and our orders never got screwed up. And the service? Wow. Near the end of our meal, our server accidentally knocked a Sharpie off and into my side plate of rice, and immediately ordered us a whole new order. Now, I wasn't going to say no because that stuff is delicious...but he totally went above and beyond with that, and it was greatly appreciated.  All in all, this place is amazing. It was a packed house, but with how friendly and efficient that place is, you wouldn't even notice. If we were back in our usual ramen place, we would've sat there for half an hour just waiting for our food, the service would've been sloppy, and you'd totally notice. So if anyone at Monta Chaya wants to have a chat, I'd love for you to open one up in Utah! :D

We were here for lunch on our last day of our vacation. I think the one I had was called Black Garlic Ramen.  I was pretty good.  Nothing fantastic.  Although I really enjoyed the gyoza that had a strong ginger flavor that I liked.

Great place. It was cheap , tasty, and good size portions. How can you not like a restaurant that serves beer for $2-2.95. There was a bit of a wait so we opted to sit at the counter , good move on our part. Fun watching them cook and prepare the food. Started off with calamari as an appetizer, that was ok if it wasn't for the Japanese broth it would of been super dry. The ramen was excellent , salty and plenty of meat. This was a good find, hidden in a shopping center and right off on Eastern. I'll be back for sure .

This place is BOMB. I've never had better ramen that this place! The staff is always welcoming and friendly. This restaurant is very popular so if you go at a busy time, you can usually expect a wait. I seriously have an addiction to their tonkotsu shoyu. So good!

I must say, I had to update my review to give Monta a 5 star! I really under estimated this amazing joint.  I've been back for the pork belly bowl 3 times last week! 3 times and I didn't even realize it!!! I couldn't wait to try the ramen so I went back  to order the tonkotsu ramen today. Walked in at 4:00 pm with only 1 couple sitting in one corner, by 4:15 pm the place was completely full. I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen, a pork broth base, milky and thicker than the other broths on the menu. The broth base comes with thin noodles, ginger, scallions..for 6.95 and additional charge for topping. I opted for pork chashu, and flavored eggs. I've had the best ramen in LA, I've been to an LA ramen festival and surprisingly, Monta is as good!!! All the components on this dish was cooked perfectly!!! Seasoned just right!!! They also pay attention to details which is a big plus. The ramen bowl looks like it came out of a food magazine except my ramen bowl didn't look like one after I've moved my spoon around too many times (lol) scoping what's underneath the soup. Someone  from the next table ordered shredded scallions topping towering the bowl and it was just too pretty to eat. I truly enjoyed my meal. My Asian comfort food!  Wow! Loving this place! OVERALL: fast service, affordable and delicious! a must try!!!

No dislikes. Simple but good. Pork belly is really good. One Of the best in Vegas. Ramen is inexpensive compared to other places but better. The service is awesome. Always greeted when walking in or leaving. Servers are always helpful and they make sure the tables are free of trash or empty plates. I would recommend this spot to anyone looking for ramen, pork belly, even fried rice.  Great location. Next to golds gym so I can get a good solid workout in and go eat after. ...which I haven't done yet, which is a good thing.

Excellent excellent food and great service! My mother and I had their pork sandwiches as a starter; the buns they used were very fresh and airy with so much flavor! Then we tried the kimchi fried rice which was SOOO delicious and had extra kimchi on the side. And of course their ramen was to die for! We each got a bowl to ourselves. To top it off, the food came within 5-10 minutes. The portion sizes are big and it wasn't expensive at all. With all of that we paid under 30 bucks. We are definitely making our 20 minute trip back here for our next noodle craving ^_^

After watching Ramen Girl a few weeks ago I've been having an insane Ramen craving.  Hey now.....Stop laughing.  Are you a Ramen fan?  Who on earth doesn't like Brittany Murphy?!  It's been a while since I've hit up Monta and they've added a few new selections like their Spicy Tonkatsu and their Black Garlic Oil Tonkatsu Ramen.  I ordered the Black Garlic and it added a new depth of rich flavor to the already flavorful tonkatsu broth.   I'm always a sucker for the kaedama - extra noodles. It's $1.50 and even after I'm full I just have to give in for the value.   I end up paying for it after I leave and especially on a work day.  There were also some new vegetarian options like their daikon salad which was really light, not over dressed and was a perfect compliment to my hearty bowl.   We also got an order of the shishito peppers which were delicious.

My man and I have been on a two state ramen journey. We have visited several placed, all found through the assistance of Yelpers.  Monta Chaya is the best in my opinion.  The only negative thing that I can say is that the temperature of the broth could be a little hotter. Everything else is perfect.  My spicy miso ramen with corn is so good that I don't care that I have to wait thirty minutes for a table.  I can also overlook the following that other Yelpers cannot: Seating so close you can smell the food of the people at the next table. Not so great customer service from wait staff. Blast of cold wind every time someone opens the door.  I have also tried the gyoza and was not impressed, but the ramen is so good that I will not deduct stars from my review.  Five stars because I am in love with spicy miso ramen.

Yes the ramen is amazing like everyone says it is. The hidden gem here for me though is the cold noodles. A lot of Japanese restaurants only serve these types of noodles in the summer so it's nice to get it year round here. I've only had the sesame dressing but it is so much lighter than the heavy hot ramen options. I also really love their karaage, takana fried rice, and the crispy rice. Everything is amazing but seriously give the cold noodles a try. I don't think I've ever seen anyone else in the place order them.
I love Monta. The calamari is delicious. The pork belly bowl is to die for. And I love the tonkotsu ramen is yum yum yum!! Can't wait for them to reopen!
I love their pork belly bowl and their chashu bans are delish! The service is always nice, I love this place. 5 out of 5
Best ramen place in town. They have great customer service too.  Highly recommend it to everyone

I admit that I was one of the faithful that stood in line for a seat at the Spring Mtn location.  So I was ecstatic when they opened a place on my side of town. Tried it a couple of weeks ago, not too long after it opened. The tonkatsu ramen was way too salty. I'll chalk it up to opening hiccups... And will definitely try again. However, since discovering Fukumimi's, it's going to be hard for me to stray.
The ramen was too salty for my taste. I can't tell if the ingredients were tasty.  The saltiness masked or overwhelmed everything.  Too bad.  Nice place and good service.
The noodles. You guys.  These noodles. Insane.  Thanks for the dude at Spring training for the suggestion.  Heck ya.  Go Dodgers!

Good place with quick service.  My husband and I each ordered a bowl of ramen with two add-ons each, an appetizer and one beer and the bill was $28 which I thought was pretty decent. We will definitely come back but continue to seek out a better ramen house.

Hands down one of my favorite places to grab a meal on Eastern!  Service is always good and fast. Food is consistently delicious! Prices cannot be beat. Best place to eat something satisfying, especially after 10pm when most restaurants on Eastern close.   My favorites are the miso ramen with egg and their chashu bowls and buns are delicious!

My favorite go-to ramen in the city.  This location is much less crowded than the Spring Mountain one...it's larger and also further from the strip.    My usual order  consists of the tonkotsu ramen with wavy noodles and the daikon salad as an appetizer.  The tonkotsu broth is rich, flavorful and filling...everything a good tonkotsu should be.  If I'm hungry, I order kaedama -- extra noodles -- for just $1.50 more, so make sure to save some broth of you're in the mood for extra.  The daikon salad is a personal favorite.  Light, refreshing, tasty...a perfect starter.    Also delicious...the pork belly bowl...filled with melt-in-your-mouth pork, the mentaiko (cod roe) bowl, the fried rice, and the chashu buns.    Life is too short for packaged ramen!  Head over to Monta-chaya and treat yourself!

Such a little hidden secret! I'd rather come here than drive up to china town!!  The pork buns had so much flavor and the meat was super juicy. I had the black garlic ramen, it was so flavorful and delicious I could eat it daily!  Portions are huge and decently priced so it worth a quick trip even if your on a budget.  They just need more seating :)

Feeling a little under the weather and my better half was craving porky belly so monta it is. She ordered pork belly and chasu bowls. I went with gyoza, crispy rice, shishitou peppers and a bowl of spicy ramen in hopes that it'd clear my stuffy nose. Everything came out right away and service was efficient. Food was delicious and comforting.

This place is ok for ramen. The broth is flavorful but packed with something that made me super thirsty at night - not good. And the noodles are not handmade. These two things are enough to make me go eeeehhhh....  Good place for cheap eats, but if you're on a quest to find good ramen, this isn't the place for you.

This place is still five stars in my book. I came back and got their famous cold noodle ramen with yuzu base. It is quite possibly my favorite thing to eat in the world. I'm a little biased because I like citrusy flavors, but it's definitely a great summer meal.  There's no broth that comes with it, and the noodles are chilled, but full of flavor. You can order it vegetarian, or the normal way which still comes with a few slices of tonkotsu, and some other vegetables. I would definitely recommend it to those who love cold noodle, and for those who love ramen and want something different.

Yum! This is a great location similar to monta ramen but in a more convenient location for me.  Had the miso ramen and it was amazing! The flavor was there, a nice sized portion, and pretty cheap! Well under $8 per bowl. The service was great and had a nice atmosphere. Will be back!
Absolutely heavenly silky noodles in slightly salty broth with tender fatty pork good enough for the most discriminating asian palette.

Love this place!  The pork belly bowl is fantastic... Melty pork belly and rice - what more could you ask for?  We also tried the little sandwich things as well and aside from feeling like I was poking the Stay Puft marshmallow man they were delicious.  This location was much easier to get into than the Spring Valley - even at 7pm - but just as scrumptious.  We will definitely be back!

I was so excited to finally eat here because everyone goes on about this place but......As a self proclaimed ramen expert....it's just ok :( they gyoza had way too much garlic, the portion of noodles is too small, n being completely empty was saying something. The good side is they cook the eggs perfectly n this is such a clean restaurant.  If I'm craving ramen for maybe lunch when I won't eat that much ..I'll give this place another try

This is the second location of Monta (in Henderson). Always had a great experience at the original one off Spring Mountain Rd, so I expected this to be the same.  We were lucky that there wasn't a wait when we showed up.  The service was very quick and friendly.  Since we cane as a group, it was easy to order multiple items off the menu.  Some of the items ordered included:   Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen - pretty good (adding egg made it better) Gyoza - excellent Fried rice - something about it didn't taste that great...mediocre at best Pork Belly Bowl - great flavor Chicken Karaage  - ok Shishito Peppers - great  Overall, the place is decent,  but I still prefer the one on Spring Mountain Rd.

Wow, this place was great!  When it's raining buckets and it's cold outside, nothing hits the spot like some good ol'fashion Ramen.  If you follow my reviews, you know that I like ramen and can be kind of picky. Well, Monta Chaya did not disappoint.  I ate around "old people" time (aka 5 pm) and there was a wait. However since I was a solo diner and didn't care if I was at a table or counter I was seated pretty quickly.  Fun Fact - If you're at Disneyland and you don't really mind riding separately from your girlfriend/boyfriend/parole officer, then jump into the single rider line and you'll get through faster and soon be enjoying the singing from creepy animatronic children from various countries while you're stuck on a boat.  Anyhow, the menu selection is simple, it's just two pages with photos.  It's mainly Ramen and a handful of side dishes such as fried rice, calamari, pork over rice, etc.  I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen (Pork with pork broth) and a small bowl of marinated pork belly with ginger and green onions over rice.  Fun tip - spoon some of the ramen pork broth into your bowl of pork belly and rice as you eat. It keeps the rice and pork juicy and infused with the goodness of the pigs that have given their lives for your cause.  The noodles were perfect, not too soggy and just the right level of al dente. Al dente in German means delicious noodles that aren't soggy.  Monta Chaya missed out on that fifth star because unlike other ramen places it didn't include the seaweed as standard issue like at Hokkaido Santouka (Costa Mesa) and the chashu slices were smaller. However the prices for the amount of food you get is pretty reasonable. I'll definitely look to be back if I'm in the area.  https://youtu.be/CQUb-uVEO4E

We tried it yesterday for a late lunch and then AGAIN today for a 7PM dinner, yeah it really is that good. We really like this place compared to other Japanese noodle places in Henderson, the noodle portion is a decent size and I would think you would order the extra side of noodle portion if you are really in need of a noodle belly bomb. The broth is perfectly seasoned and you have  several choices to choose from as well as extra toppings. We suggest you try the crispy rice appetizer, it's crunchy rice with spicy tuna on top, very unusual and very delicious I didn't really like the soft white Chasu buns with the pork in them, but my wife did and apparently it's a favorite of many others. I tried the Kim Chee fried rice and it was well done and not too oily or overly spicy. Also I went outside the box and tried their cold noodle dish and it was to me the best thing I ever ate in 2014 and will probably order that dish more than the hot soup dishes that usually gets me overheated. (not in spice, but in warmth) but I guess that is the draw to have some hot noodles in the winter time. The drinks are served in cans with a side of ice, but hopefully they will have a fountain to serve from later since a per can charge for soft drinks can add up on the refills. Also some flat screen TV's on the walls would be very welcomed during sports time, but then again maybe not since the place is small and people are usually always waiting for a table, so probably better for people to eat and leave right away to make room for others. The wooden benches are kind of uncomfortable, but as I said, they want you to eat and make room for other diners, so eat eat eat and go go go!  Prices are very reasonable, the food is tasty and not overly salty, lots of flavors involved here, really good eats! The odds are we will be back within the week, very well done!
My favorite ramen shop.   Amazing Chasu pork.   Awesome thick wavy noodles.   More space to eat!!!!
The food is good but then the waitress, not so much. She didn't  pay attention to my order and she looks like her mind is on somewhere else.

I recently checked out Monta Chaya in Henderson, and was truly impressed. There was a bit of a wait (20 minutes) when I went on Saturday night, but hey, that's when everyone wants to go out to eat, right?  Very happy that they have VEGETARIAN RAMEN on the menu, which I think is a fairly recent development. My bf was able to slurp to his heart's content. The veggie ramen had a soy milk base (weird for me but he liked it) and had sprouts, corn and tomatoes on it. We tried two veggie apps, the daikon salad (very good--definitely recommend) and the shishito peppers, which weren't much as they were just spicy peppers with a miso sauce on them.  Loved my tonkotsu ramen. It was super creamy and hearty. The broth was full-bodied and up to par. Noodles perfectly cooked. Wish I had remembered to order an egg on top! They cost extra.

Last week, it was a little chilly, so I thought it would be great to get ramen. There's so many eateries on Eastern, I figured that there had to be at least one Ramen place along this strip. And low and behold, it is the ever famous Monta!. I have now been to three Monta ramen houses and I have to say, the broth here is thee best!  For some reason, the ramen seems less expensive at this Monta location. I ordered the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen which was only $6.95. For another $2.25, I added nori and egg. And as always, I needed their house made gyoza. I just couldn't finish it all, so it was great having it for dinner.  You just can't go wrong at Monta. Great food, fast and friendly service, nice atmosphere. This place deserves their 5-star.

I just left there with a couple of my friends. It was unbelievable they said that their computer went down so they messed up our order . Honestly people who came way after us got their order . We kept on reminding them but all they gave us was were working on it. After an hour of waiting for noodles, we decided to pay for our drinks  and appetizers and leave . Can you imagine being hungry, cold, and ignored. Sorry but I am going back to Shoyu where you're always welcome and appreciated.
A solid ramen chain through and through.  Always busy and you will get served quick.  Just don't make the same mistake I did and get the kimchi fried rice.  It's nasty to be honest.

I have been to most of the ramen places on Spring Mountain and Tropicana but still come back to Monta Chaya. Started going to the Monta on Spring Mountain, however this location is more convenient.   I find the broth to not be salty and you have several selections pork, chicken or both for your ramen. The roasted chashu pork served with the soup simply melts in your mouth. The chicken karaage and fried rice are delicious too.   Although bigger than the Spring Mountain location, you will always find a line at prime times. Good news is, they are fast at turning tables. Fresh ingredients, extremely consistent, expertly prepared equals a quality experience every time.

Prepackaged Ramon noodles are used here. I sat at the bar around the cooks, and I saw them. I thought I was getting the real deal here, but if you are looking for hand made noodles this is not the place to go :(
I come here all the time for ramen. They're very consistent with the quality and flavor their ramen and that's always a plus =)

Some of the best Ramen in LV.  In Ramen, the broth makes it for me.  The tonkatsu is meaty and hearty with a hint of the fat from the pork that it's made with.  Very lovely.  The ramen is consistantly good and never over cooked.  The pork belly rice is wondeful with the sweetness and saltiness one would ask for with this kind of dish.  Best ramen place on this side of town hands down.

This place is worth trying if you are craving cheap, decent quality ramen in the dessert. I got the miso ramen since it was highly recommended by the other Yelpers and it was a good choice. The only thing that I didn't like was the slight eggy taste of the broth which I never really experienced with all the ramen places I have been to. The two slices of pork was good but it was basically all fat and barely any meat. I don't really like eating fat, but I make certain exceptions and ramen is one of them. The only downer is it was all fat which was kind of boring in terms of texture since it was all slimy. I would come back to try the other dishes and hopefully it will be an even better experience. Give this place a shot because the prices and quality of the food is worth it!

A bit salty for my taste but still one of the most flavorful bowl of ramen yet.  Earl and I shared the cod roe bowl, and each got our own bowl of ramen. -Earl got the shoyu ramen with an order of chashu pork and nitamago -I got the tonkotsu shoyu ramen with an order of chashu pork  We both agree that my broth tasted more delicious than his shoyu broth, but the thicker noodle in the shoyu bowl tasted better than my thinner egg noodles.  Halfway through my bowl of ramen, I was stuffed, so Earl ate the rest of my ramen.  The chashu pork was nice and tender.  I think next time I will not order the extra pork because it was too much for me.  We sat at the bar and had great service.  The place is small, but seats more than its prior location.  I am definitely glad that it moved to Eastern because it is so much closer.

Delish! I just had the fried rice (take home) for breakfast and I could go for seconds quaint and calming atmosphere, very friendly staff, all food made to order, and please try the fried chicken app. The ramen my fiend created as absolutely delishious as well, Im really looking forward to my next visit

I was in the mood to try something a little different.  So I asked the waitress, about the noodles.  There were so many choices, so she helped me choose one.  I also wanted to try a couple of other things.  So once I got my food, I asked for seasons.  (I really only wanted soysauce)  But she gave me like 5 things.  Some powder, one looked like mashed garlic, soysauce, and a couple of other things, I have no idea what they were.  So it was too funny to me, because I didn't know what seasoning was suppose to go with what dish.  So I kinda just threw a little of this, and a little of that in all the dishes I got.  And it worked for me.  I really enjoyed my food from here.

This noodle place is hands down my favorite in Vegas. The service is always outstanding and the food is delicious! I am always impressed when walking out of here. The quality of food, and especially the water is top notch. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone!

They put crack in the broth.  They have to... The best places in NYC don't compare to this place.  The broth is so rich and thick, without being syrup.  I need to quit my job and move to Vegas, for no other reason, than to eat here more often.

This restaurant was packed when I came in for lunch. Despite how busy the restaurant was, the food arrived quickly and the service was great. I ordered the kimchi fried rice, which was delicious and inexpensive. Overall, this is a restaurant that I would recommend for anyone who wants something cheap and delicious.
Wow...... what an AWESOME place! The food is fantastic . Found a new place for some ramen.

I ordered take out today. I got the tonkatsu ramen with nori on top and pork buns. She informed me that the ramen noodles came uncooked for the to-go orders which was fine. I figured it would be like pho where you pour the broth over it and it would cook. This was not the case. Now I'm left with raw noodles in thick flour-y broth even after trying the microwave. It was my fault for not inquiring more but I didn't think my food should have needed instructions.   Secondly, the pork buns were good but not as traditional pork buns. They are closer to a pork sandwich with their inclusion of lettuce and mayo. Good, but if you're a fan of traditional pork buns then sit this one out.  All in all I will try sitting in the next time as I'm sure the ramen is better when it is properly prepared.

One of those Can't-believe-I-haven't-reviewed this place deals. Everytime I've come in they've never ceased to disappoint. I'm glad I don't have to drive as far as Spring Mountain to get me some satisfying ramen. They're always prompt and on point with their service. Their menu is pretty straightforward, no frills with a few appetizers and fried rice to get the ball rolling. Cute, casual and modern decor, the place seats probably 30 people. Tables are filled with the appropriate accoutrement Montas always a soild standby for that quick bite, casual date or getting rid of that lingering cold!

The best Japanese Ramen house ever!!!!! The customer service is awesome!!  The food is always great.... Takeout orders are available as well. The restaurant itself is a bit small so be prepared to wait 5-10mins before being seated.... Totally worth the wait!!! If you like Ramen I highly recommend giving this little restaurant a try!!!

Was in vegas for EDC and my lil bro suggested this place for yummy ramen.  Being that it was a bajillion degrees outside, I had no idea why my friends were craving ramen. Anyhow, the reviews looked good so we decided to check it out.  Upon arriving I saw that they had other, really affordable options, available. Instead of killing myself with super hot ramen, I went with the Pork Belly Bowl, and that was a good choice.  For less then $7 you get a big bowl of delicious, fatty (but not too greasy), perfectly salted, steaming hot bowl of thinly sliced pork belly over soft white rice.  Served with lots of green onions and an array of sauces on the table, the meal was simple and yummy.   Personally i couldn't get enough of how delicious the pork belly was. Perhaps since it was cut thinly, even though pork belly is normally overwhelming, the pork belly here was just the right amount of fatty.  I mixed my bowl with sesame oil, a little bit of soy sauce, pickled ginger, and mixed in so garlic paste that was reserved for the ramen (best choice ever).  If I'm ever in Vegas again, I'll definitely visit this little joint and probably give the ramen a try.

I ordered the veggie ramen. It lacks in flavor, the umami factor is missing. But it doesn't have to be that way. An easy fix if they used the vegan chicken boullion cubes you can find at Smith's or Sprout's, I use when I make my own soups. I'll have something else next time. Atmosphere and presentation is A+. Good prices. I wont give them a lower rating because I feel they deserve another shot.

Ramen time!!  I think both locations are pretty much equidistant from my home, but I find myself coming here more.  The food is more or less the same at both Monta's but upon dining in yesterday (9/24), I noticed the ramen was a little less salty.  This is not a bad thing!  Before it was a bit much.. I do enjoy salty foods but man does it taste much better.  My fav here is the mentaiko bowl but I most certainly get down on some noodles, especially the yuzu cold noodle and the shoyu ramen (no pork chashu, topped with nitamago instead).  Whether I go for cold or hot depends on the weather or my temperment, but I'm usually a cold noodle eater most of the time.  Flavorful grubs and the price isn't too bad.  Plus, if you are a hungry like me, you can always opt for more noodles if you have some ramen broth left over - kaedama style.
Dude, this place is lovely. Great design. Great, no wait, AMAZING pork, even better ramen. If you don't enjoy this place then I'll question your sanity.
Maybe I was just really hungry or sick with the flu that made my ramen here taste really good. This place hit the spot. I will come back here. It reminds me of a spot I always go to in LA.

i like this location better than the spring mountain. they have more stuff on the menu. i love trying new items. this time i had Shishito pepper and kimchi for app. i did not care for the shishito pepper much. kimchi was good. next i had the Chashu Bowl. that was delicious. the staff was friendly, rest was clean. the food came out quick. i will def be back for more!

Since the infamous closing of Noodle Cha Cha, I have been searching the depths of Yelp to find a good Ramen spot within the Henderson area.  Fortunately, I found Monta Chaya on Eastern.
