The layout is small-mid size, clean, with wood decor. Obviously their specialty is Ramen, so their menu is predominately Ramen based with appetizers like gyoza and karaage. I usually get the Miso Ramen and it's legit.  If you want to add extras (like a boiled egg) then you're gonna pay extra.  No complaints, I'll be back again.
Great price for great meal! Every dish can be completely customized to your liking and the service is fast. The only problem is the dinning room is small so it gets very busy.

I had something at Monta Chaya that I've not even seen at other Japanese restaurants.  Cold Noodles.  We got them vegetarian style, which just meant without meat.  You get a big plate of cold ramen noodles with either yuzu or sesame sauce, and it is topped with veggies like cucumber, onion, seaweed, other things I either couldn't identify or don't remember.  We went with the yuzu and I loved it, but we'll try sesame next time.  We also shared the takana fried rice and some salad that was awesome.  The takana was great, but I want to try the kimchi fried rice next time.  Those are pretty much the only vegetarian options since this is mainly a ramen place and all the ramens have meat-based broths.  But, I'd still go here every time I'm in Vegas from now on because even though they only have a few vegetarian dishes, the ones they have are AMAZING.  Great prices, the whole meal for two people was $20.

A godsend for South Las Vegans. No more will we have to drive the 15 minute route to Chinatown for a noodle fix. No more will we have to fight off bad drivers for parking. Here,we have found home.   Monta Chaya is conveniently located off the 215 on Eastern,making it a central location for our brothers and sisters in Green Valley,as well as not too much of a commute from Silverado Ranch dwellers.   The service is quick and efficient - I have never waited more than 10 minutes for my food,and the wait staff is always polite and - to an extent - authentic in their Japanese roots.   The food is decent quality - slightly greasy and could use bigger portions,but my biggest issue with their menu is its limited scope. Yes,it's a ramen place,and they serve a few rice topping bowls,but missing some Japanese house staples like chicken cutlet (tonkatsu).   All in all,it's not a bad place for a late night meal (closes at 11pm most nights),which makes it a good late post-gym alternative if you don't want to cook.   Long. Live. Monta.
My most favorite place to eat...if you love Ramen you'll love this place...it's a small place but its bigger than Manta Ramen on Spring Mountian but just as good,,same owners I believe, same menu.

RAMENNNN so close to where I practice yoga. Glad there's one more spot for me to pig out before I go try to balance my body weight on one toe.   I came here last week with Dana S for some good times, great oldies, and good ramen soup. I had the Miso and it was delicious. It also took about 2.5 seconds to get to us. Delicious and fast, what more could you ask for? It is also pretty cheap--$8 for a giant bowl of soup is none too shabby.   The restaurant only seats about 30 people, and the waitress was kind enough to ask somebody to move so that we could sit together. Come later in the afternoon so that you don't have to wait forever for a spot to sit during the lunch rush.   New restaurant in my rotation!

This is a review of the Eastern location (I've been to both in Vegas). I liked the decor, it's larger - or at least less crowded - than the location in Chinatown. The food quality is great, service was quick, and everything was clean. My only complaint would be that the Chau siu portions are not that large. I would definitely return, I guess I don't need to eat that much meat.

I honestly like this place but they have a lot of flaws they have only 2 pieces of meat in ramen and the pork belly is the best item here but seriously charge for anything extra you want!!! One dollar extra for hot sauce and 3 dollars for extra broth? Wow seriously you have to charge for every thing this is ridiculous! California ramen is better I think I'm going to have to try a different place that doesn't charge for every little thing next thing you know they lol be charging for chopsticks
I literally crave this ramen! If I could go there every day I would!  Great food, great prices, and friendly wait staff. Couldn't ask for anything more!

Really good Japanese ramen! I love how they have one near me in Hendertucky (Henderson) cuz I live far from the strip and another one in china town near the strip. So if you are ever visiting Las Vegas and are staying in the strip during your stay, go to monta! It is really close to the strip on spring mountain and Decatur of china town.   Although the venue is really small, make sure u call ahead of time to set a reservation and know a time frame when to get there so you don't have to wait in line. The place is popular and always busy. If you can, go in a small group or by yourself so u can experience the great food they have with no hassle. Sitting at the bar is preferred! You can also see them cook in front of you.   My favorite dish is the tonkotsu shoyu ramen with extra seaweed, extra chashu, and egg. Also their side dish spicy fried rice. The menu is cheap and you can order extra additional sides to your ramen bowl for good price too. If you can't finish your meal, they provide you with take out to go.

Love the Miso Ramen. I asked for two orders of eggs because they are so delicious. My husband and I have been twice and will definitely be back again soon. The restaurant is small, but way worth the wait.
It was a very good ramen for a reasonable price.  Thin noodles in thick Tonkotsu soup with good chasuu pork.

Best Ramen ever in my opinion...and i mean EVER! The chase melts in your mouth and I've never found any other place like it. They have great appetizers such as Spicy Tuna on crispy rice, calamari, and my favorite - pork belly buns. If you go at the right time, the wait won't be long. But please note: They are closed mid-day for break. My favorite ramen to order is Shoyu Ramen and/or the Garlic broth ramen with the wavy noodles. You must definitely go here!!!

Everyone raves about this place so we finally went with friends and honestly I was unimpressed. It's not that anything particularly bad stuck out but I was disappointed since everyone rants and raves. I didn't like the mushrooms that come on top of the ramen. I think my biggest com ain't is that they charge extra to include chasu, egg, green onion, etc. my favorite ramen place in town, Ramen Sora, includes these with different ramen types and overall is cheaper for a larger portion.

This place was great. The ramen was fantastic! The prices for add-ons seemed a wee-bit high, but definitely the food was good enough to mitigate any negatives of having higher priced add-ons.  I ordered the tonkatsu ramen, which I was very pleasantly surprised by. The broth was thick; seems like a lot of restaurants are serving the tonkatsu ramen with a more...shoyu'esque broth nowadays.   Call ahead and make sure there is seating though! VERY small dining space with VERY limited seating. Be prepared for a lengthy wait.  Would I come back here? Yes Would I recommend to others? Yes

Always come early on the weekend if you don't want to wait a long time in their small entryway where you always feel like you are in someone's way.  The seating situation is fairly small like most noodle houses.  This is the first time we did not have to wait for counter seating on a Friday night since it opened, which was awesome!  Great quick service and tasty food as always.  The pork buns are so devine.  I do not know how they make those soft rolls, but I want to!  We both went with the shoyu Ramen this time and shared an order of extra noodles.  Perfect.

My first time having ramen.  I am amazed!   Everything was had so much flavor.  The miso was really good.  The broth is so good you'll be wanting more noodles lol.    I will drive from LA for this every weekend
Our go to noodle stop! Perfect every time. Fast, friendly service. I usually have to daikon salad, crispy rice and Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen. My son and husband love the calamari and chasu bans.

this place is just as amazing as the original Monta!  I'm pretty simple and went with the shoyu ramen which was delicious as always. I usually prefer the thicker noodle. my brother went with the tonkatsu (sp?) ramen and the crispy chicken. I never order much else off the menu but the chicken was bomb!  I have to say, the ambience and space in this one is better since it is much more open. also the staff here is great, they actually interact with you more. our waiter had a great personality. I didn't get his name but I loved the fact he had some witty things to say. made me think less about how I had to go back to work.

This place had so much potential, but it's hard when your establishment is crammed to fit guest inside, you won't seat anyone unless the party is present, your service is horrible, and you charge for refills.  Don't get me wrong, the food was excellent, but we were ignored and wanted refills.  The place is so small I don't know how you could have ignored us.  Look at my photos to see the typical Asian culture mentality - charge per canned soda ridiculous prices.  Yes, I said CANNED.  Sigh...  What really upset me about this visit was the lack of service and waiting nearly 20 minutes to be seated.  Another 10 minutes to take our order, another 10 to get food.  Won't be back, sorry.

So disappointed. On our most recent visit here, I had to remove two stars because I was upset by their customer service. After placing a pick up order, I immediately called back to make a correction to one of my five items and the staff wouldn't allow to make one change because they advised the cook was already making the order. I realize I had made the error, but there was no attempt by the staff to right a service failure, or even negotiate the change even when I offered to get an additional menu item. In addition, it was very obvious the host/server's tone was very annoyed I had even requested the change. Regardless, if we had a pick up order or dine in order, and mistakenly ordered something we didn't like/want, I would expect the establishment to at least demonstrate empathy and replace the order - especially if the order was not even served yet!

The food is amazing!! The Takana fried rice is my absolute fave. They jave the best Pork out of all the Ramen houses I've tried. I go to both locations and this one is best. I just wish they were closer to home.
Monta Chaya has officially closed! (At least at this location.)  A sign on the door now states they will be moving (pic attached). Hopefully management actually updates us this time!

For all you Monta Chaya lovers... Good News!!! I just saw their awning go up for their new location. They relocated to Eastern and Richmar right next door to Woof Gang bakery and the Gluten Zero Bakery. Doesn't say when they will open but my guess is soon! Anybody know more?

I have to give this place two stars, it's not because of the food but service. Every time I come here they are so packed in such a tiny building the servers seem to ignore you. I usually order it to go because of this problem. For having two locations and both having the the same problem, one would think it's time to expand get off the corporate greed hire more employees and expand your business if the food is great people are going to continue to show up recognize the growth and deal with it because it's very obvious the food is delicious people are showing up however the long waits and cramped quarters are eventually going to drive business away.
Better than average but good value.. but they forgot my fried rice order.. second time here first time was fantastic..

We had an excellent dinner here last night! 3 of us were able to sit at the bar without any wait (it was about 5:15). Service was great. The food was simply to die for. Between the three of us we had pork ramen, pork belly bowl, Takana fried rice, pork bun appetizer, and gyoza. We enjoyed every bite of every item. I can't recommend Monta Chaya more highly. If you've been thinking about going, go!

I had the veggie ramen, and it was great. Only issue was the leeks in the dish were so overpowering to the point where I couldn't quite taste the noodles as much. And I love the noodles. The broth is soymilk, and it's also quite overpowering. Besides that, I had a tomato in mine, and some corn sprinkled on top. Mine friend loved hers, though!
Wait staff is very kind when you walk in everyone says hello. Service is fast and the food is reasonably priced we loved it and we will go back

Since the night i pulled into this town with all our belongings in a truck we went out to eat here and never stopped we love this restaurant  and yes its always busy but worth the wait. When they closed for a little while withdraw set in lol. The unfortunate  part is the bowls got smaller and they are closed mid day when id love to go with my son when get he gets out of school... i used to order the miso with extra noodle but no need now since the portion has gotten smaller. I didnt mind paying extra  because the size was perfect but oh well.. go back to old bowls! We still love this place and service is friendly well always keep coming in

Here's what I can say. This is the second time I've came here and it's been packed and I couldn't eat. That's a great sign. On a Thursday at 800pm the restaurant was full and 6 people waiting. All good signs. Smelled amazing and the people dining all had things that looked good. Can't wait to actually eat here lol.

I was a fan of their old location off Spring Mtn and I'm still a fan after trying this new location.  The food is a copy and paste so if any of you reading now didn't get to try it at the old location then you're not missing out on anything.    I was hungry on a random night and decided to come to my favorite spot in Vegas, 215/Eastern, and asked anyone if they were hungry too.  I ended up with a party of five and contemplated whether or not we would be able to sit down and eat at Monta Chaya because if anyone who has been to Monta Ramen before knows that they are always backed up with customers.  This place was not busy!    I ordered what I had last time to compare which was the miso ramen and extra noodles.  My friend ordered a pork belly bowl so I didnt have to order that last night.  Everything tasted exactly how it was served on Spring Mtn, which is a plus!  The rave about the old Monta still lives on with Monta Chaya, the place is still small but we didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes to be seated.  The waitress was the same from the old location but it sucks they still serve tea out of a can.  At least it's a safe bet that the drink will be clean hehe.  But do come in here if you've never tried Monta Ramen before.  Monta Chaya might have just bumped herself into my Seven World Wonders of 215/Eastern!

I love this place!!! It's so good. The ramen alway comes out perfect. My only complaint is that the service is a little slow. There were three open tables and five open seats at the bar and the waitresses were so caught up and stressed they didn't care about ppl waiting. I get it when it's busy. Still worth a try and worth the wait!

This is hands down my favorite authentic ramen place for Vegas. Even though there's almost always gonna be a wait, it's worth it. I've never once had a bad experience at this place and the service is also amazing. This is going to be my favorite ramen spot in the city for a very long time.

Ramen is what they do and they do it well! It's the same as the Monta in Chinatown, although with an appetizer menu that might have a couple more items. Noodles and broth are great. Very freindly service with food that hits the spot!

Monta is good. There is one place I'd choose over Monta but I won't name it.  Monta is always busy! Is it unfair to like it less because of that? Probably! I don't frequent them because of this so.. Yea..  Anyways their ramen is good. The price is about average for Vegas.   They have excellent sides though. Their Gyoza, Calamari, and fried rices are all amazing! I'd return for these before the ramen.  Idk if I had an off day here but my ramen mostly tasted of salt. No real depth of flavor. I had the one that's pork and chicken broth.  I'd go back but definitely not my first choice for ramen.

I have had the original Monta on my bookmarks for, like, ever, but if we were driving all the way to Chinatown, my husband never wanted to get ramen. Yay for Monta Chaya, right down the street from us! The atmosphere inside is very austere - hip and asian-feeling! It's small, probably seats about 20-25, but we didn't have to wait on a Thursday night. Prices are good. $7 for a bowl of ramen, a little extra to add eggs/more bean sprouts/extra pork/etc. Most importantly, it's good! We had the pork tonkatsu, pork miso, fried rice, and the fried spicy tuna (I think that's what it's called). Everything was really good, and we were so full we didn't even finish it all. I'll definitely be back, and will bring the kids!

First time and wasn't disappointed.  Located right next to Gold's Gym, it's the obvious place to go for your post-workout carbs.  Met here with friends Ian A, Sugi S, Shirley B, and Terri R after a session at Gold's.  We were immediately seated and got our orders in.  Ramen Sora and Fukumimi are my only other ramen joints that I have hit out here in Vegas.  So far, I would still have Sora as my favorite with Monta coming in at a very close second.  Others may think differently, but this is my review and it's my opinion.  My ramen of choice at Monta was the Shoyo Ramen w/two extra eggs.  This is my favorite type of ramen...silky, thick, and the broth was perfect.  The eggs were cut in half, which gave the extra taste and protein. Taste of my ramen is very similar to what you get at Sora. I didn't try anything else because I was trying to save room for dessert.  Come to think of it, I didn't even finish my ramen.  The rest of the group ordered a mixed bag. I'm sure it was good for them too because everything was demolished.    The restaurant itself is small, like Fukumimi.  This wasn't huge deal because it wasn't busy at the time.  But be warned, it got super busy after we left. Overall, I have to give Monta 4 stars because of service, quality eats, and close to one of my gyms.   Shoyo Ramen:  http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=6LwMtLgpCwomsUr33D20yg&userid=y3FcL4bLy0eLlkb0SDPnBQ  Ladle Time:  http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=6PsmOnbsmGNG5u4lUW6U-A&userid=y3FcL4bLy0eLlkb0SDPnBQ

You like Monta in Chinatown? Then you will like it here too.   Same menu as they have in Chinatown, same fast service, and same good food. Great lunch option if you work nearby like me. This location is newer than Chinatown and is super clean and has a very nice build-out to it. Ill be back for sure, and if you haven't come by yet give it a try. 2 thumbs up
I heart the pork belly bowl. Enough said!
here goes the most boring review ever...you ready?   It's Amazing

The PHO was great and the Crispy Rice with Spicy Tuna was very good. The environment was great and the food was great as well. The service was ok are waiter Lina of fell off so another waitress started checking on us. Besides that is what very good and very recommended.

NO. Just NO. So may options in this town to be wasting your time and money here:  : Small_ You will wait and wait and wait unless your one   Pricey in terms of giving you a NORMAL sized Ramen. (Sora, Jinya)   Small portions   They charge you for EVERYTHING. Egg, onions, etc...   They lie about the prices. (Everything on the menu is NOT what they will charge you.  Importantly: They are ALWAYS on the BUSY BUSY attitude. (No real acknowledgment of service) more like a job. Most importantly the BROTH. Seriously no flavor. I like my Ramen with a unique flavor or options of meat and spices....All that (spice) is on the table with no labels.  Ramen can be great and enjoyable. (Great Broth with Buttery noodles, Meat with Broth) Almost Heavenly done right! My I dont understand Monta when there is sooo much good Ramen in Las Vegas.

A long time ago, I enjoyed the original Monta Ramen. It was my first ramen experience. As I explored more ramen places and revisited Monta, it fell out of my favor (although I haven't bothered to update my review). However, Monta Chaya earned a shot at redeeming its sister because another Yelper, I believe Christopher S., said that I should the miso ramen. Yes, the miso of Monta Chaya, not OG Monta.  So this was actually my fallback after my original plan fell through due to insane crowds. I managed to work my way over here around 7:30pm on a Monday evening and found a pretty busy dining room, but with just enough vacant seating for me and the party ahead of me. While waiting to be seated, I was able to appreciate the larger dining room and the brighter decor in comparison to Monta 1.0, while still keeping the clipboard waiting list that we all know and love.  The miso ramen ($7.25) with no add-ons took at least 15 minutes to come out, I suppose owing to the busy restaurant and the popular appetizers that I was watching the cooks assemble from my bar-style seating. The broth was enjoyable overall and not as salty in flavor as the typical miso ramen dashi, but it reminded me of a miso soup typically served as an appetizer a little too much. The best miso broths that I've enjoyed have more layers of flavor. The chashu pork was pretty fatty and probably is still the standout of their ramen. The noodles weren't noticeably overcooked, which would have been an automatic negative considering the standard of good ramen even in Vegas. The kikurage was also good, but the bamboo shoots were lacking in flavor and juiciness, probably due to being taken from a can or rehydrated.  I did enjoy the miso ramen overall, enough to order it again or even to try the tonkotsu of Monta 2.0, but there are definite weaknesses that dissuade me from recommending this as anything more than a neighborhood ramen restaurant. Fukumimi Ramen and Ramen Sora are certainly still my favorites.

You have to try the buns! They are my weekly indulgence, and they are an ancient cure for hangovers!!!   The noodles are amazing, along with everything else on the menu! Highly recommended. The staff are always professional and attentive. I am so lucky to live nearby.

Really good ramen. It was 8:30pm and the place was packed and had a half-hour wait. It was worth it. The cost is pretty reasonable and the food was excellent. A great little ramen shop that is worth giving it a try.

Shoyu ramen (basic ingredients), daikon salad, fried shishito peppers.  I enjoyed the ramen over all, but the noodles were rather ordinary--just a bit better than store-bought cooktop ramen, and for some reason they were rather short--no long slurps needed. The broth wasn't too salty for me, the pork was nice, and it's a good-sized bowl.  The salad was tasty.  This was my first time trying shishito, and I didn't know how most of them are mild, but you will randomly find a hot one.  I think there were three that were spicy, with the last one on the plate being hottest. I enjoyed them.

Ok here's the deal.... NBD, but I'm the #1 regular at this spot.  When I go there today, it will mark my 40th checkin in 3.5 months.  That being said, it doesn't really matter if you eat there or not because I am single-handedly keeping the lights on.  OK but if you're interested in how good it is (besides the fact that my calculated annual expenditure for ramen at Monta is literally four thousand dollars).... just go and try it.  Or don't.  For all your ramen are belong to me!!!  Love this place.  The food, SUPER friendly service *every* *stinking* *time*, it's fast, inexpensive, and just yummy as all hell.  So get out and try this place, because I'm seriously considering just buying the joint and hogging it all to myself....!
They are closed MON-FRI 2:30-5 but SAT-SUN 11:30-11, REALLY WISHING IT WAS SAT or SUN to get my Ramen on..... Guess I'll find another place in the area.

If you are a fan of Japanese ramen and you're in Las Vegas..this is the place to go! Monta Chaya is located in south Las Vegas, so its only minutes away from McCarran Airport/the Las Vegas strip / and Henderson residents.  We had a party of four and went to Monta around 10pm. Our server was Joseph and he gave us excellent service.. His knowledge about the food and the restaurant make us want to return here..everything we ordered was made perfect...

Amazing!!! Tried to go to this place 2 days prior but was on a time crunch and it was so busy we couldn't wait... so when we had more time we went back. We went there with a large group at 1200 and had to wait a little bit but well worth it! I got the spicy ramen and added egg, seaweed, onion and garlic ... it hands down the best ramen I have had.  Also had green tea- only bummed because it was in a can and nit refilled .. but it still tastes good. Also order the goyza also good!   Recommend to get there early because this place seems to be always packed! I will for sure go back next time I visit Vegas.

Love this noodle restaurant. I used to live in Japan for two years and loved eating ramen there. This place knows how to make ramen the way ramen is supposed to be made! I love the Miso and Shoyu the best, but all are quite delicious. For sides, I recommend the kimchee fried rice and bbq pork buns. All quite tasty. This location isn't as busy as the one in Chinatown on Spring Mountain, so whenever I am in the area I make an effort to stop by.

This was my very first Ramen house I've ever experienced and so far I've been coming back for years. After all these years I'm now going to review this place.   Off the bat, when you walk in it's a pretty small restaurant like any typical ramen house. So simple and cozy. Sat down ordered right away.   Appetizers  Kimchi fried rice ($3.95) was so tasty, not salty at all. Calamari ($3.95) was different from your usual calamari with the cocktail sauce and lemon, but this one had a Japanese tempura batter with a sweet and vinegary sauce which was good and light.  Drinks I've only gotten the green tea (Hot) $ 1.75 which was in a can and was already hot. That was interesting to me because I've never had a hot drink in a can, but I did see that in Japan they have vending machines with hot drinks. It's a Japan thing I guess. I LOVE IT!   Ramen  Tonkotsu and Miso ($6.95)  Both Ramens were 5 stars!!!! I can't get enough of this. I can't even explain how tasty it is. Not at all salty and seems very light. I always get Nori ($.75), Nitamago (egg) $1.50, corn ($.50), and butter($.50) as my toppings! Soooooooo yummy. The broth is PERFECT  So why the 4 stars? Well I gave it a 4 because a few times we've gone, has been a 30 to 45 min wait and I mean it's not their fault that it's so good and a lot of people want to eat there, but try thinking of investing in a bigger place. I had to drive far to eat at another ramen place which this place is 2 mins away from me.   Overall still my favorite spot for some good ramen!!!

Couldn't taste the miso in the miso ramen I ordered and the gyoza had a strange bitterness to it. The chashu was good though, and just melted in my mouth. My boyfriend ordered the kuro ramen and was happy with it.  The staff was very friendly and accomodating and service is fast. The interiors are also nice. Wouldn't mind going back to try something else.

I like how this location is much closer to me and less busier than the original location. Plus their pork belly bowl melts in your mouth and is always a nice side dish with a bowl of tonkotsu shoyu ramen.
Small and quaint! Big on flavor the best ramen I've had outside of Japan. They open at 11:30 be there by 11:00, Sit at the bar. This place is a secret no more, line out the door by 12:00.

I usually get the Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen w/ the seasoned hard boiled egg, corn, butter, and kimchi on the side...it's perfect for this chilly weather. Their pork belly is absolutely delicious! The buttery fat is flavorful and cooked perfectly. They serve it over rice with pickled ginger, which adds a delicious contrast with its sour crunchy goodness.  They are always busy, so be prepared to wait; especially on a Friday or Saturday night. I've waited over an hour before. They need to make this place bigger. That is the only reason why they get 4 stars instead of 5.

Embarking on the trek from South Summerlin to Henderson solely to grub down is a major sign that I LOVE the food here. I have been for several Saturday lunches; it's pretty popping. I've never waited over 15 min and trust it is well worth it . We order the Miso Ramen (add egg,$$), Chasu Pork (OUT OF THIS WORLD),  Gyoza (handmade), and fried rice. We also get a few orders of ramen to go as it heats up nicely for a few meals over a chilly week. Just make sure to place the noodles into a separate container. Now I'm hungry ....

Being from San Francisco/ Bay area in Ca, ramen is tough to beat anywhere else but this place knocks it out of the park.  Absolutely love their ramen and fried rice.  The kimchi fried rice is super good.  Cooked to just the right texture of rice filled with flavor.  The ramen is perfectly chewy and the soup really hits the spot on a cold day! The place is a bit small ans gets crazy busy during nights.  So heed the warning of the other regulars who reviewed on here and go ahead of time to enjoy your dinner!!

Extra noodles, extra egg, extra meat, another egg and seaweed. That's not too much is it? Yes, yes it is... But I'm still going to order it. Monta ramen is a cheap, filling lunch with such a low base price you don't feel guilty about adding extra toppings (Unless you're a guy that's only survived on top ramen, then maybe this is expensive). Once you have non-99 cent ramen, you'll never be able to go back to those horrible styrofoam cup noodles.  Don't be turned away from Tonkotsu... Just think of it as a deeper flavor than the plain shoyu or miso. Always order tonkotsu :)  The cold noodles they serve is called hiyashichuuka in Japan and they're just as good as the ramen bowls. If you don't feel like eating the super salty ramen bowl, stick to this. It's lighter on the stomach and you won't be drinking gallons of water afterwards.  Monta is as authentic of ramen as you can get in LV. Having lived in Japan, it's not the best I've had, but it's not the worst either. My only complaint is how salty it is. Consider ordering your broth with lower salt. If not, you'll feel horrible afterwards and will need one of those gallon water jugs to quench your thirst. Parking is easy up front and there's a Japanese shop next door to get some snacks for dessert :)
Very good and great price.  Had no idea where they were but I will be back. Very busy so you know it's not just me that likes it.
My Japanese and Chinese students recommended this place. They have awesome hot tea in steel cans. I had the Miso bowl of Ramen. Delicious! I will be back for sure.

Wow! Just wow! After all these years of eating ramen from the top ramen container and now I know I've been doing it terribly wrong. This place and their ramen noodle operation is legit. I would suggest the totkonsu ramen with pork, mustard leaf. I just haven't had really good results with their order on the phone you pick up because something always seems to happen it's not ready or someone else got my order it's kind of frustrating to be honest with you because I really enjoy this spot and one of my favorite places to go but I'm reluctant to order out. Beware if you go in to eat it's the size of a closet so you're going to be rubbing up against people you don't know if you go in there for a quick bite to eat that's why I always eat out.

Monta ramen is probably one of the founding fathers of ramen to hit the Las Vegas area.   Previously, i would frequent the spring mountain location and wait half an hour to be seated and try their delicious ramen; however, this was many years ago.  I was excited that they were opening up a new location in an area not really known for great food spots (Henderson area).  This location is probably slightly bigger than the old location but still not that big.  Getting straight to the point, I really don't like the ramen here.  The broth is consistently thick and oily and quite too often am I downing my water to combat the saltiness of the ramen.  You can ask them to cut down on the salt content but it really doesn't make a difference.    Overall: The broth is really thick and oily making it difficult to get that warm refreshness comparable to having a nice hot bowl of pho.  If you want good hip ramen thats not salty, oily or thick I would highly recommend going to Jinya.

I'm not that much into noodle houses, but I really enjoyed this one. I've been here twice and each time my dish was delicious! The staff is awesome too, really friendly and attentive. I recommend taking a date here.The place is cute (^.^) and quiet enough for couples to talk and enjoy themselves.

hubby and i took our cuzzen here ...lunch time of course theres a waiting time. you have to sigh in...i understand...but noone there to say how long. then we when we were called in ...the hostess/waitress- NO smile on face, didnt understand a word what we were asking and got our order wrong. never came by to check on us. i had to call each time to ask for more water. their dishes were too salty or just too much base for the soup. their sister restaurant was a little better BUT i dont think they understand when i ask for extra soup base or extra hot water. oh and i cant get my soup without noodles or replace it with extra negi with an extra charge. all in all...havent stepped back into a Monta anything since ...coz we found Ramen Sora!!!

Been coming here for a while now and out of all the ramen spots I've tried this is the only reasonably good ramen spot here in Vegas. Food is good & always hits the spot, service is fast & friendly. They have two locations one on Eastern & one on Spring Mountain and the service/food is the same. Will definitely be back.

Ramen is always a good pick me up. The miso ramen here is my favorite. I have also had there fried rice, but who are we kidding. Who goes to a ramen place to order rice? haha  A friend of mine questioned me when I introduced him to ramen. "Why would you go out to eat ramen when you can buy a packet at the market for a quarter?" WELL, lets just say he regrets that statement after eating here and we have been back several times.

My sis who lives in Henderson recommended this place for ramen.  I'm from Hawaii where ramen shops are literally in every corner.  I've tried them all.  Not to say that I am an expert or anything but I do know a good bowl of ramen when I see one.  The restaurant is kind of hidden so you could walk past it if you weren't paying any attention.  We came by for lunch around 12 noon on a Wednesday.  It is a small restaurant probably seating around 20 or so people.  We had to wait till everyone in our party arrived to be seated at a table.  Which was kind of ridiculous because there wasn't anyone else waiting other than ourselves.   They could have started our drink and appetizer orders while we waited for our last guest to arrive.   When we finally got around to being seated and placed our order, we got fried calamari, chashu buns, shoyu ramen, pork belly bowl.  The pork belly bowl was pretty yummy.  It is over rice and is so flavorful that it made my tastebuds happy.  The shoyu ramen was your basic bowl of ramen.  It's decent, no complaints here.  I wasn't too fond of the chashu buns tho.  After having chashu buns from Bachi Burger, a burger joint nearby, nothing compares...now that's what I call yummy goodness!!!  Monta needs to take some tips from them.    Overall, I felt that service was ok.  Food was good, the pork belly bowl is probably their prized dish.  I would most likely order that the again the next time I visit.

Been here three times. The first time and second time I went the service was good. However, the third time I came here was all wrong.  I finished my water before food came out. When my food came I couldn't even drink (no water). I placed it on the side hopefully a server will see. My friend offered his water and I killed it. Server passed by refilled his water that was almost hidden and left mine in the corner not filled. My friend offered his drink twice and they didn't even refill after I asked. Had to ask twice. Hopefully next time I go. Service would be better. Food is still good.

2nd branch of Monta Ramen.  Exactly like Monta in terms of food, with a few appetizers that I've never seen being served at the Spring Mountain location.  Same flavorful broth, same generous noodle portions.  It's slightly bigger and cozier than Monta, but I'm not sure how full it gets because I've never eaten here during peak hours.  They're also closed in the afternoon, from 2:30-5:00, which is a bit of a bummer.

Tasty ramen and great menu items. Small place with small menu but good food. Prices are pretty reasonable.  Finally another Monta! The other location is always packed so its nice to have another option. This location needs to perfect the taste like the other Monta has.
Amazing flavor one of my top fav ramen places in town. Had the shoyu ramen with goyza appetizer... Delish!

A great ramen spot in Henderson! I came in for dinner with a friend and we both enjoyed our ramen. It's great to have an excellent local ramen restaurant for times when I don't feel like driving to Chinatown.   The restaurant is not very large inside so we had a short wait for seating on a weeknight. There is a sign in sheet at the door where you add yourself to the waiting list and specify a preference for table or counter.   The employees were on top of their game. Everyone was working hard to keep up with the steady stream of customers. The employees were on top of tracking the waiting list for seats, refilling drinks, and delivering food to the tables quickly. Everyone we encountered was friendly as well.   My friend and I started with Green Tea, Crispy Rice, and Shishito Peppers. The green tea was served hot in a can which was a first for me. It was not the best green tea I've ever had, but it was pretty good. The Crispy Rice had great flavor and the crispy rice held together great making it easy to eat. The Shishito Peppers were delicious as well and had a nice sauce on top. Only a few peppers in the batch were hot, but for the most part it was a mild pepper.   Both of us went for the Spicy Tonkostu Ramen and it didn't disappoint in taste or spice. I loved the broth and couldn't get enough of it. The broth is more milky than some of the other ramen spots I've eaten at and I enjoyed the difference. Everything inside the bowl was delicious as well. The noodles were tasty, the meat was tender, and the egg was perfectly prepared.

As my friend Gayle Y says... who goes to a ramen place to order fried rice?!   ME! Lol. I always get the fried rice.. I just love the combination of pork belly with rice and green onions. I do like the tonkotsu and the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen though. Prices are pretty fair (~$7-9), seating is limited, and parking can be limited. Longer wait on weekends.

I freaking love this place, I go there every time for the pork belly bowl and it never fails to satisfy a craving. Great little hole in the wall, family friendly atmosphere. Gets a little busy on the weekends but if you want some simple Japanese food than this is your place. Their ramen is also pretty amazing, the amount of food that you get for the price is a darn good deal. 10/10 would recommend

My buddys are local and hit this spot up on the reg. Went in for some eats on a Saturday nite. There were a few parties ahead of us yet the food looked delicious so we gladly waited. Oh what a mistake that was. Wound up getting food poisoning. (Yes it was in fact from the bowl I got here and not via alcohol or any other food. We were at home the rest of the nite. This was all I had to eat / drink last night besides water.) Never again. Fair warning for you Yelpers.

Treat your taste buds with Monta ramen!  This is definitely one of the top ramen shops I've ever been to.  I was staying in the strip with my friends when we accidentally came here instead of the Monta ramen shop in Chinatown.  It turned out to be an awesome experience.  We started off with pork buns.  The chashu pork is balanced well with fat and meat.  The bun is soft and everything melt in your mouth.  The tonkatsu-shoyu ramen.  Two thumbs up.  My friend also raved about the tonkatsu with black garlic oil.  I added extra chashu pork and an hard boiled egg.  Pretty soon I reached ramen nirvana.  The fatty chashu pork was well seasoned and  flavorful.  If you are still hungry, go for the pork belly bowl.  More fatty pork mixed with scallions.    Come to Monta ramen for your ramen cravings.  If you are staying on the strip, this is 20 minutes away versus the closer one in Chinatown.

"Gomenasai" (sorry) should be the phrase that's yelled out instead of "irasshaimasu".  "Gomenasai, we're still too small to accomodate large parties."  "Gomenasai, you have to wait 40+minutes when it's busy to be seated." "Gomenasai, we opened a second location and still subjecting you to the same wait hype crap of the other location." "Gomenasai, we only offer canned sodas." "Gomenasai, there are only 2 servers working the floor and will ignore your pleas for water refills."  I wasn't in a big hurry to try the ramen here, especially after experiencing the ridiculous wait of the other location that's smaller than my pantry. I don't think the ramen is that good to put up with the hassle. When we were finally seated after much confusion on the part of the hostess that only prolonged our purgatory, we ordered the fried rice, miso and shoyu ramen with nitamago and nori.  The noodles were ok, but I prefer the noodles from Shoku (but not their salty broth), the pork was tender, albeit slimy and fatty but strangely good. The broth was ok. It would have been nice to see a spicy miso on the menu. The fried rice was good and had the nice hibachi flavor and gone in about 3 spoonfuls. Food overall was ok, but waiting 40 minutes in a cramped space is not the right way to start off an experience. I know, it's how most ramen houses are, but it's annoying. Gomenasai.

Honestly very upset this place is closed. It was mine and my boyfriends all time favorite ramen place in the area. But it's been closed for basically this entire year, last time they were open was like March of 2017. Never gave any notice either. Just all the sudden closed. Reasoning on door was suspicious as well, claimed remodel and now moving locations? CONVINCED they closed because health care violations, frequently found dirty glasses and bowls or plates of food and even left over marks on forks. Tables were almost always sticky. Service is slow and thus makes the facility crowded and wait was always 20+ minutes

Tried this place again after having a craving for some noodles, I don't know what changed but the ramen was delicious, packed full of sodium but it was oh so good! Highly recommend to anyone looking for a good, cheap meal. The pork belly boil was also amazing for anyone who doesn't like soup.

One of THE best Ramen in Las Vegas.  I've been coming to this location since it opened. It's a lot closer to where I live than the Monta on Spring Mountain by the strip.  I always order the Shoyu Ramen and add the nitamago (egg), it is my absolute favorite! The service is always fast and the ramen comes out steaming hot and delicious.  If I'm extra hungry I'll order the gyoza for an appetizer which is very good, comes out fried.  If you want your broth to be more flavorful, for a little extra you can request for the black garlic oil and/or the spicy red paste. Both are fantastic and you can add to your liking.  I've tried to venture out and try different Ramen, but I honestly believe nowhere compares to Monta. I always find myself wishing I had just gone to Monta instead.  The only negative thing about Monta is the wait. Since it's such a small restaurant (as is the one on Spring Mountain) there usually is a wait whenever I go. Anywhere from 15 min to 45 min. Good thing the ramen is so tasty here - it's always worth the wait!
I cannot get enough of eating at Monta. Both locations are excellent. Eastern location is larger.

I love Monta Ramen but their lines are so long and wait time is just plain aggravating. This location is south and between the 215 and 15. its much more quiet and still the same great quality. We had the black garlic oil with our ramen. The soup is exactly the same as the Monta Ramen!
Amazing ramen, made me ask myself wth was I eating at home lol. So much flavor it was best. I purchased the pork and chicken flavor and I recommend this place to anyone seeking ramen

Great ramen, the best we found in vegas so far. Especially cold yuzu noodles - are my favorite. Ok a cold day as today, however, I've had miso ramen. It was pretty good. The place was packed around noon on Sunday. Service is good. The only issue was excessive waiting - first for a table, then for food. But the food was worth the wait!

Always busy throughout the day, if you need a ramen fix here is the place to be!   They have variety of soup base favors to choose from and toppings to add on. Parking is a hassle because it's in a plaza and there's lots of stores around

Love this spot! I always order the Miso Ramen which is creamy & delicious and really perfect if you're feeling under the weather. I add 2 slices of extra pork & corn which makes it extremely filling along with all of the noodles! My only complaint is that both times I've ordered the gyoza (potstickers) some are cooked more than others. The meat inside some gyoza was bright pink which immediately turned me off, and this has happened BOTH times I've ordered them. Now I know better and just order fried rice on the side instead.

This place has some excellent ramen, I enjoyed the shoyu ramen. It has good broth and noodles, plus the price was right. Only thing was it didn't have much seating, but a lot of good food places don't.

Amazing ramen! Great customer service... We bring out 2 1/2 year old toddler all the time, they are accommodating and friendly - always remembering to bring her a small bowl and plastic spoon! Food is awesome! Best fried rice and ramen in town!

So happy they opened up this location. There wasn't a crazy long line like the one on spring mtn and we went there on a Saturday afternoon. In fact, there was no wait at all and we were seated immediately. Their ramen is delicious and full of flavor. This place hit the spot and will definitely be my new ramen go to place.

A clean, intimate, and delicious spot to satiate your ramen appetite. The creamy miso broth tasted excellent with the long, chewy, hair extension-like noodles that accompanied it. Portions are generous and I had trouble finishing it all. A bowl alone is inexpensive, but the additional toppings are egregiously expensive. A soft boiled egg or green onions will cost you $1.50 each. So that $6.95 basic bowl could cost upwards to $10+ if you go World Star on toppings. Just sayin'. The green tea was sadly served via can and not homemade. Oh well, I've always left satisfied and inflated with happiness.
Fast service Tasty broth Delicious fried rice, that I was supposed to take home but ended up eating with the bowl of ramen haha carbs on carbs!

Joe is an excellent server. His customer service is awesome. He always has a smile, is very friendly, and knowledgeable.   I love eating at Monta Chaya. The food is great. The price is just right. The staff is friendly.   I recommend the miso ramen, the pork belly bowl, and the fried rice.   At times there can be a nice long wait but in my opinion that's a good thing. That just means that the food is good and they are doing something right. Especially since there are a lot of returning customers, myself included.

Ummm wow, noodle galore.  All these East side noodle joints...I'm in heaven!!  We were on our way to our favorite Japanese store to pick up some Hamachi Kama and Char Siu, when we see Monta Chaya.  We seriously put the brakes on and said, "Is this a dream?!"  Ooh my, but it wasn't.  Monta is in our hood, with the classic bowls of ramen and then some!  Jesse N. and I went semi all out, haha.  I say semi because we could of ate more.  We indulged ourselves in Chasu Buns, a mini Mentaiko Bowl, and I had the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen with Kim Chee and Nori on the side.  Ooooh weee!  Love the decor and the atmosphere, looks like they already have a few regulars too.  How did I miss this?!    Chasu Buns I must admit, wasn't as appetizing as my ramen or Mentaiko Bowl.  It could of been more on the steamy/hot side, that was my only complaint, still give it a go.  Mentaiko Bowl, eggs and rice, I'm talking fish eggs and rice to get your appetite going and top it off with the delicious tasting ramen that most Las Vegas Yelpers love?!  Sweeeet!    Great side to this is this place can fit a little bit more people than the Spring Mountain location.  We luckily didn't have to wait, but I did pass a sign in sheet by the door.  My noodle lovers, its a must go!

Decor: modern Asian lunch counter. Apps: chicken karaage was 90% fat and gristle; the gyoza tasted just like you'd expect. Condiments:  The soy sauce on the table was quite frankly the saltiest either of us have ever tasted.  No sriracha sauce, but they offered their own version for a dollar.  Ramen:  The miso and tonkatsu ramen broth had very good flavor and the noodles were cooked properly.  The chashu was nothing more than fat held together by collagen.  Pretty gross.  Overall, this is a ramen joint and the ramen is good.  The proteins were horrible on our visit.  We might give them another shot for the noodles.

Just as good as the original Monta but with even more menu items.  They have quite a few appetizers and I have tried many of them.  Both of the salads are great, a daikon one and a cabbage one.  The shishito peppers are yummy and the karrage is good.  Not as busy as the other location so you luckily don't have to wait as often.

I have never been to Monta Ramen, just to preface.  I noticed when this place was being renovated as I am regularly shopping at Japan Creek Market.  I finally visited last night for a late Sunday dinner by myself.  There are purse hooks underneath the bar which is AWESOME!!!  I ordered the cold noodle (Hiyashi Chuka) with yuzu sauce sans pork, the shishito peppers, and the mini mentaiko bowl.  I also ordered hot tea, which was the can of tea listed under cold drinks, heated!  Very Japanese-drink machine-like.  I received the shishito peppers first, which were deliciously charred in a miso sauce with sesame seeds sprinkled about.  I enjoyed this dish very much, and it is a good price.  Next, I got the mini mentaiko bowl.  The mentaiko was very fresh, and the bowl was covered in my favorite vegetable, green onions, plus shredded nori!  I added some shichimi, sesame oil, and soy sauce to this and mixed everything in the rice.  Lastly, my hiyashi chuka was delivered to my spot at the bar.  I did not realize at first that it had pork on it (my picture was taken before I realized it) - oddly enough, the pork looked somewhat like shiitake mushrooms, albeit large ones.  I asked the server for a plate and removed the pork with a spoon onto the plate - the pork had been cold and was not moist or drippy so it was not worth sending the dish back.  The noodles were presented with shredded cucumber, tomato slices, seaweed, bamboo shoot, bean sprouts, and shredded egg crepe strands with sides of karashi (Japanese mustard) and benishoga (pickled ginger) in a yuzu sauce.  The sauce is OISHI!!!!  I finished my shishito and mentaiko and started working on the noodles when I got some bad news about my brother in the hospital and no longer felt like eating.  The servers brought me some water and helped me package up my meal to take home.  I really appreciated the kind service.  I get to enjoy my leftovers for lunch today.  I will definitely return.  Credit card minimum is $10.

Most people who know me well would say that I am OBSESSED with noodle dishes of any kind, and ramen is on my top 3. I can literally enjoy a bowl of ramen (or two) every single day and not get tired of it. However, my experience at Monta Chaya was not as heavenly as I had hoped.   I ordered the tonkatsu/shoyu broth and although ramen is traditionally pretty salty and high in sodium content, this was too much for me. The broth was so unbelievably salty that I couldn't even enjoy the noodles in the bowl. I've had tonkatsu ramen and shoyu ramen in ramen-yas in LA, NYC, and Vegas, and I must say... here their broth is a bit too thick and heavy, the saltiest of them all! Basically, I ALWAYS get double the noodles at ramen-yas. This time, I had no desire to order kaedama.   I've always spoke highly of the gyoza at the original Monta on Spring Mountain Rd., and I was excited to order some during my visit to the new location; however, the waitress informed me that the new gyoza is deep-fried... :*(, so I chose to live without it. When I saw a plate of gyoza being delivered to another table, I saw that it's definitely nothing like the amazing gyoza served on Spring Mountain. That's a real shame! The gyoza in the original Monta is NUMBER ONE in Vegas, in my book.   The karaage was a HUGE disappointment. The breading was bland and the chicken inside was stringy. The steamed pork buns were "O-K". We've had much better ones in various Chinese restaurants.   The other big negative is that they do not offer one spicy-flavored broth. To me, there are very few things that are more incredible than a large bowl of spicy ramen, especially when the spicy is done right (cough, ramen sora, cough cough.)  All in all, I know Monta and Monta Chaya are huge hits in the Vegas ramen-eating community, and I can respect and understand why; however, it is not my cup of tea. I would go to the new Ramen Tatsu for my tonkatsu broth cravings and Ramen Sora for ... pretty much everything else :).

I finally got hungry around 1pm and just like the first-to-review person, I also missed the lunch rash. Because who wants that?  I was happy to discover that they are serving Hiyashi Chuka. It's every bit as good as the OG Monta location on Spring Mountain. The service was quick. Sitting at the counter, I was able to see the guy making my dish right in front of me. He apologized for the wait, but it really wasn't much of one.  My only possible gripe is that I could have sworn the dish said $7.25 on the menu; I was charged $7.95. Not worth complaining about, so I just paid cash and left.  I'll be back, especially since this is a good lunch distance for me. Just no rash, please.

Really excellent ramen, somewhere in my top 5 ever.  My husband said it was his #1 in Vegas.    My miso ramen was on the lighter end (compared to, say, a typical tonkatsu) but really flavorful.  The chashu here is too fat-to-meat ratio for my taste but prepared perfectly, it has a good flavor and was not tough or old.  Salt level was just right for me.  His kuro ramen was also great, not too oily, just right.  Could have had just a touch more garlic.  We were both a little surprised at the very thin noodles, but are okay with them.  I was a bit annoyed that there was nowhere near enough broth for kaedama to be possible.  Basically they only sell what I would consider to be a "small" ramen (or maybe right between a small and medium).  But I will be back for sure.
Me and my husband go to Japan several times a year and monta has been the only ramen spot that actually tastes authentic to the real deal

Staff were so friendly! I work in customer service so I know how customer service can make it or break it. It has the ability to convince the guests to return to your business. Our server was very energetic and kind and did not forget to check up on us. Both our server and even one of the chefs said thank you for coming and good bye once we were finished with our food. It made the ramen taste that much better! ;) Will definitely come back again. I was very pleased that Monta opened up in the area!

That was VERY good! My wife and I tried two different Ramen. Both were very tasty and satisfying. Servers even brought out a small bowl so that our 2.5 year old could enjoy...which she did!   Crispy rice topped with spicy tuna goodness also made my belly happy.   Everything was clean and friendly; my kind of place!

This place is great! the only reason why i am giving it a 4 star rather than 5 is because the place is so small that sometimes the wait time is long.. BUT totally worth the wait ! & also one star down because of the slow service ! the last time we went there, we only saw our server when it was time to get the check..  They definitely need to improve on that.  Other than that, everything is great.  Great price, great atmosphere, great quality of food !

Oh man, even when you're not craving ramen, it is SO good that you won't stop thinking about it...until you have more ramen. First of all, difficult to locate, but they've literally been open for a week, so I'm sure a sign is coming soon. Seriously though, everyone has still managed to find it! Anyway, a couple notes: very small spot and they will only seat you if your whole party is there, so plan ahead! Ruben and I joined our friends and their kids to dinner. We ordered a bunch of items and shared bites.   I ordered the Fried Calamari and Charshu Bans from the Chaya menu. The calamari is very lightly breaded and fried, then served with a delicious Japanese broth. So, so good. The Charshu Ban was just okay for me. Weirdly served with a leaf of Iceberg lettuce? Anyway, for my main entree, I got the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with their "thick, wavy noodles" (normally comes with their thin noodles, but I asked if I could order it with the thick noodles and they were more than happy to accommodate!). I wasn't feeling adventurous enough for toppings, however, I really enjoyed adding the condiments available at your table like sesame seeds, vinegar, and most importantly, the spicy sesame oil. A fabulous addition of flavor and the right amount of spice to your broth! At our table, there was also the Miso Ramen (I'm torn between this broth and the Tonkotsu Shoyu), Fried Rice, and Pork Belly Bowl. All really, really good!  Anyway, food was quick and service was wonderful. Everything was on point and it was such a lovely experience. I can't wait to have another bowl!  UPDATE: Of the three major ramen houses in the valley, I prefer Monta's thick, wavy noodles, Tonkotsu-Shoyu broth, and chili oil for an extra kick. Ramen Sora is a close second with a superior Miso broth.
Wow, I had the worst food poisoning after having the cold noodle plate & flashed fried Japanese peppers. I suspect it it the cold noodles. I hope others have been luckier!

This is my most favorite place to eat now. The service is so quick, so even when you don't get seated right away, you never have to wait long. Then soon after you order, your food is out. I take everyone I know here. I eat here so much I wish they had punch cards for bowls of ramen lol

I'm not an experienced Ramen diner, but this was delicious.  My only knock, which only stopped me from a five, I'll talk about later in my review.   I had the Spicy Tonkotsu and Karage (fried chicken pieces).    The broth was amazing and so full of flavor.  The noodles were a little different and I liked it.  I've only been to a couple of other Ramen restaurants and the noodles tended to be more plump and soft.  These were slightly thinner and more al dente which I actually think works better.   The Chashu (braised pork) in the soup was amazing!   The Karage was good, pretty much what I've had at other places, but they didn't offer any sauce with it.  Now, I don't know if it's standard to offer sauce or if that's more for us Americans.    Service: My first issue was when I arrived.  Nobody from the staff greeted me and each time someone came to the waiting area they just acted like I wasn't there, so I basically just stood around for a few minutes.  There was even a guy at the host stand when I arrived and never said a word to me.    I work in the industry and you need to at least say, "Hello, we will be right with you" so I know you've acknowledged my existence and I'll get seated.  I apparently got there right before the lunch rush, so it was on the verge of getting busy.    My server wasn't great, but there was another server who checked in on me and did more than my actual server.  Because I'm not really experienced with Ramen, I don't know a lot about ingredients, the sauces on the table, etc... The server made me feel so rushed I couldn't even get any questions in.  She also got my Ramen order SLIGHTLY wrong.    Look, it gets super busy in there, I get it.  That doesn't mean you should rush your guests.  I would have given five stars.

Walked in got greeted, sign in !   This place is so small . This will be my second time coming back here waiting . I'll wait it out to give it a try .   Hopefully the wait till be worth it .   Got seated at the bar after 15 minutes .   Ate Shoku Ramen & I wanna test this one out .   SERVER: Mariah   Mariah is VERY sweet & nice ! She knew everything about what the menu was !    Kitchen was very clean . The chef's used gloves like OTHER restaurants should be using , is GLOVES !   Ordered the spicy tonkotsu w/ Ni Tamago .   Krispy Rice: Mmmmm ! 110% bomb ass rice.   OMG , the wait was worth it ! This is BOMB ! I will be back . Mom fried rice was on point ! The server Mariah herself was on point . Mmmmm !

Finally!   I love that Monta Chaya is just within a 5 min radius from where I live and work! I had the pork belly  bowl today and all i can say i s yum! I also tried the karaage - it was nice, crispy and freshly cooked but I think i'll stick to the ramen, chiarsu or pork belly bowls for lunch and leave the karaage and the rest of the Chaya offerings for happy hour over a drink or two.

5th week it's been open and we have gone every week! Same owner as Sushi Mon, Goyemon & Monta Ramen and just as good. It's not as busy yet but just wait as it is just a matter of time till you have to wait at all hours. If you get extra noodles for your leftovers you can also get extra broth and they will put it in 2 containers so your noodles don't get soggy.

Service was fantastic! But the food, for the price I expected a lot more. Had the Sriracha fried rice and  it was tasty but for 6.95 that's too small a portion for rice. Rice is cheap. That size dish should of been 4.99. Had the pork ramen it was tasty and the size big enough and tasty but it came with two slices of pork which was advertised so yes it was good but I felt for the price??? Not enough value. Also order the vegetarian soup. I should of read more carefully.  It's noodles in soy milk. Felt like we were eating cereal with noodles and corn.  Two thumbs down on the vegetarian option. The vegetarian option did not taste good. Again the rice and pork ramen was tasty. Also those where the lowest quality chopsticks you can get. However I feel I did not get enough value for what we spent.

I had been waiting to try this place from all the reviews on here.  Honestly, it was good, but not "knock my socks off" good. I have had better.   I met my friend here and when I arrived, we were seated upon my arrival. The place is not big at all, but you're not crammed in one area either.  Space is just right.  And it was clean.   The lady who was our server was very kind and took our drink order in no time.  Service was quick and personable.  Within no time we placed our orders and had our ramen.  I added nori to my bowl, which cost .75. Some other places I have been to offer a wider selection of vegetables, which is what I would have like to see.  My standard bowl was just with mushrooms, bamboo shoots and green onions.   When you're done with your bowl, and you want more ramen, the charge is $1.50.  Of course I had to get more because I love ramen! They bring it to you in a separate bowl, and you dump in into your broth. Pricing is not decent.  My friend had a bowl, Gyoza and I had ramen, fried rice and extra noodles, and our total came out to $27.   All in all I would go back because this place is relatively close to my house.  Will definitely hit the spot.

I can never go wrong with Monta when I'm craving ramen! Tonkatsu shoyu is a must try! The broth is heaven and their pork is delicious! I always get a side of eggs and corn. The place is small and seating is limited. The wait ranges from 3-10 minutes sometimes.

Monta is one of my favorite ramen houses in Vegas. When I heard they opened a new on right by my house, I was extremely ecstatic. It does not disappoint either. All the broth has body and the right amount of flavor. I can even order take out and eat it at home. The steamed buns are magical as well. The staff are friendly and your meal is ready very quickly too. Five stars..

I forgot to take a picture of my ramen, that's how good it is! Haha!   Their calamari is great, Lightly coated, crisp yet tender! Their kimchi was average.   I had a miso ramen and I loved how flavorful the broth was, yet I did not seem tired after eating the whole bowl!

I'm not really a soup person which is basically all they have but I loved it! Everything was great and service top notch. I'll go again soon and that's something to say since I never eat soup noodles or any of that normally.

Ok so....went back to Monta and ordered another soup amd a Pork Belly bowl.  Soup was good...hit the spot.  I'd been craving ramen and this was really good...and the pork belly bowl was soooooo good!! Monta Chayahas redeemed themselves.  We'll be back!

Just tried the spicy tonkotsu. Yummy! Not too spicy, just enough heat to keep you warm. You gotta try it for yourself.  This place isn't set up for a bit crowd keep your parties to no more than four. Good place to sit at the counter.
This place is awesome. It's tiny but worth it to get some noodles!!! Yum!!! Been her twice and service is awesome.

Stumbled upon this place and decided to give it a shot. As a Ramen fiend that has been to the best LA and Orange County have to offer, I would say this Ramen can hang with the top spots.   The Tonkotsu Ramen was a good size and broth was delicious. My only complaint would be the noodles are a bit thinner and straighter than I prefer. The Chatsu was soft and melted in my mouth.   The Gyoza was bangin'.   I'll be back next time I'm in Vegas.

Eureka! we found gold!! Drove 5 hours to Henderson/Vegas from San Diego and came straight here based on 1) Yelp suggestion 2) Ramen craving. It was such a wonderful decision! We arrived right when they opened so we were seated by friend staff right away. You may expect some waiting time if you're here on peak hours. Since we were running empty from our trip we had appetizers and a ramen each... try all the appetizers and definitely do not miss the Chasu bans and calamari!! So great!!  I really enjoyed the bar seats as the guys in the kitchen are on it! One guy stares at the clock all day making sure our ramen bowls are warmed before fille with the goodies and the soup..oh man the thick delicious soup and the wavy thick noodles ... we came back here again before we left the city, just to make sure we don't miss it too much until next time.  Thank you to the (seriously) friendly staff at Monta Chaya for warming our souls on these cold windy days of Las Vegas!

This way our first time eating here. It is a very small place and because of that we had to wait a little bit as we have a child that requires a highchair. The service was excellent and the food was really good. If I have to give a critique I would say the pork dumplings could be crispier but that is just my taste.

First time at this location. I've been to the Decatur & Spring Mountain location before and was delighted to know this location opened up in a separate part of town. We got there around 6:30-7pm and there was about a 15 minute wait. We signed in the wait list and it was packed. Luckily we didn't wait too long before we got seated. We ordered ramen and didn't opt for any of the appetizer options(although we will next time). The waitress was very attentive and refilled our drinks without us even asking. The ramen was delicious. I ordered the tonkatsu, with corn (extra) and extra noodles. The extra noodles were in a separate bowl. I added it to the tonkatsu and it filled the bowl just enough for me to enjoy it. I definitely realized how much more often I need to be coming back to eat here.

Maybe I'm just over my ramen phase, I don't know, but this last visit I was very unsatisfied. This time I ordered gyoza and spicy tonkatsu ramen. The gyoza was overly cooked on one side and completely undercooked on the other. When you bit into it, a ton of liquid ran out, and it tasted like it had ZERO salt. I drenched it in my gyoza sauce mix, but it didn't help.   My ramen was okay. They put too much of the spicy sauce in it so it made the broth super thick, heavy and salty. It really tasted like spicy tomato soup. I left wishing I had gotten pho instead. :(

WOW!  If you are liking noodles, and needing a fix of real Ramen, this is truly a great place! I have had Ramen in Japan, China, Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand, and I must say that I really enjoy the Ramen at Monta Chaya.  Service - 5 Star - The staff here are consistent, friendly, kind and very much professional. They are busy, but treat you like family, help manage your expectations as it is a busy, small and crowded restaurant.  I have been here about 5-6 times now and it is very consistent.  Ambiance - 5 Star - Small, open kitchen, enough room for perhaps 22 people on tables and then perhaps 8-10 at the bar.  Typical small Ramen place but the perfect blend of size and coziness.  Ramen when I learn to eat it in Japan is all about waiting to sit down, ordering your food, eating and slurping while hot, drink all the soup, and then wipe your brow, thank everyone and leave so the next person can sit and enjoy. No socializing here!  Food - 5 Star - Rather than discuss their Tonkatsu Ramen, Shoyu Ramen, Miso Ramen, I am just going to talk about the two things that count the most:  The noodles and the broth.  a. Noodles - Perfectly timed cooking on the noodles. They have truly perfected the temperature and the al dente texture of the noodles. I say this is perfect because you barely notice the noodle. It is both delicate and substantial at the same time.  b.  Broth - The noodles do not interfere with the broth which is amazing. Lightly flavored, but full of taste. Nothing is overbearing, it is simply just ichiban. What enjoy about the broth is that it is well balanced. Not one ingredient is overpowering the flavor and to achieve this delicate balance is awesome!  c.  Other stuff - 5 star - They have cold noodles, extras bits and toppings, extra noodles and of course really great appetizers.  The kaarage and the gyoza are really fantastic.   I have to say, besides the great ramen, I really enjoy the staff here. They make you feel welcome and part of the family and that makes me want to keep coming back and bringing more people!  GK says, check it out.

Talking about authenticity, their dishes tasted exactly the same as what I had in Tokyo, Japan. The Chasu rice bowl looks fatty but the taste is just fantastic! Highly recommended. The miso ramen I had is good too but just a little too much salt. Still, this is still a great place for lunch and the staff is very friendly and attentive.

I've"ve been somewhat dissatisfied with the old Monta at spring mountain/Decatur due to its inconsistent quality as well as recent health inspection issues, so I was looking forward to seeing how the new place on the other side of town would be like.  I heard that it was next to Japan Creek, but as I drove by, I did not see any signs anywhere, but I was surprised to find out that the restaurant was virtually full of customers.  How did they find out?  It was nice to see that the new place is about the twice the size of the old place.  The menu was virtually identical, but with additional "chaya" offerings such as chicken karaage, daikon salad, hakusai salad and such.    I tried chicken karaage, which was very well done, hot, juicy and tasty.  I liked the daikon salad as I love anything daikon, but it reminded me more of daikon sunomono, and was slightly heavy on vinegar taste as I was expecting more of a sweet sesame dressing kind of thing, but I still liked it.    I also had fried rice, but this was mediocre at best.  It was way too oily IMO.  Well done fried rice should be dry and not wet, as a huge firepower from the grill should burn off the oil as you swing the rice into the air as you mix it in a wok.  I think the chef doesn't have the fried rice cooking mastered yet.  As a matter of fact, quite a bit far from it.    I had tonkotsu ramen and it was virtually identical to that of old Monta.  Not too fatty, but cloudy white tonkotsu broth was better done than the old Monta plagued by inconsistencies in recent months.      I like this place.  I just wish they've opened it in Summerlin instead of Henderson.

Staff was super rude , gave me raw dough for my to go order after I waited 30min after I called in and arrived 20min after I called my food in , horrible service and I wasted my time and dinner gettin raw dough which I never received before with my to go order never coming here again

I've been to a couple Ramen places but I always go back to Monta. When their first location was at Spring Mountain I was always making excuses to make the drive, but ever since this location has opened, I hardly ever go there now.  I have had all of their three Ramen choices plus their specials (kuro, spicy tonkotsu) and I've never had any complaints. It just depends on the day and the reason why I came there (meeting up with friends, quick bite after work before heading home) so I never have a set choice. But no matter what, I am never disappointed.  I like the staff, especially Joe. No matter how busy they are they will always say hi. I know what to expect when I come in and always leave satisfied.

I am so happy to have a good ramen shop so close to my house! Now I don't have to use so much gas. I'm a regular at the Japanese market right next door to it and a few months back I saw them doing construction of Monta Chaya everyday, so you can only guess at my anticipation for it to open. Let me tell you, I was not disappointed one bit.  Sat down with my brother after a long day of work and just wanted to have a good bowl of Tonkatsu-Shoyu ramen and maybe a little extra something something. The waitress, I believe Mariah, was very helpful with telling me what was good. So we went off her recommendations and got Ramen, Kaara-age, shishito, and bbq pork steam buns. I really love this Monta now .

I like the food but it can be a little salty (which is expected with ramen) but I noticed a few mild inconsistencies. It's also very small so they can have long waits. However I still come back. It's one of the better ramen places in Las Vegas! I still recommend it.

As of yesterday (Tue, April 16), their sign is up! Woooraaaay!  This time I tried Hiyashi Chuka (Cold Noodle) with Yuzu dressing. Healthiest noodle item, in my opinion. Yuzu dressing was very refreshing but it was bit sweet for my taste. I crave this cold noodle even if it's chilly winter night. :D
Excellent bowl of ramen. Eggs perfect. Broth deep and fatty. Pork excellent. Great and super reasonable.

My husband had the miso ramen and I had the spicy miso ramen. They were both good but the portion is small. We also ordered karage which was even a smaller portion, just 4 small pieces and Asahi beer. All in all, the wait was short on a Friday night and food tasted good.

Service here is amazing! The staff was so friendly! My date was 30 minutes less, and they checked on me to make sure I was doing okay haha  The ramen- delicious! Basic selections to choose from. I like how the menu actually tells you what's in your meal. Other ramen places I've been to have somewhat confusing menus.

Bomb!   I honestly love everything here so I can't even pick a favorite. I absolutely LOVE, LOVE the pork belly bowl. I hate anything with fat on it but this bowl is so amazing, like really really amazing. Kimchi and Takana fried rice are bomb. Calamari and Daikon salad (extra dressing on the side) are bomb, and my fav ramen bowl is Shoyo ramen!!!!!! Can't forget the ramen.    Only thing is that it takes a while to get into the doors during dinner because it's a small restaurant. And they have a minimum of $10 for cards (I hate that)!  Did I mention the pork belly bowl is bomb??

Okay... This was my very first time trying Ramen. I love Pho and eat it all the time so I had to try this place. I was REALLY REALLY disappointed! The calamari is BLAND! There is no flavor what so ever although the presentation is nice. I forgot which Ramen my cousin ordered for me but it had the one with pork. Okay,... The pork meat was ALL FAT! Couldn't even eat it cuz it was so slimy!GROSS! The soup had flavor but everything was just BLAND! There wasn't any flavor when it came to eating the soup with the noodles.OH! And Whhhut?! No veggies in the soup? I think i'll stick to eating pho instead. BUT, I will give this place 1 star for pretty presentation and nice customer service. I wont go back here though.

Usually get a Ramen but my friend ordered Crispy Rice topped with spicy tuna, Fried Calamari, Mini Mentaiko bowl, and Chashu Buns-steamed pork buns. All great. I will definitely try new things on my own next time.

Came here a couple weeks ago. Pretty small and cozy spot. I am told it is bigger than their other ramen spot, Monta Ramen. I don't know, they both seem pretty small. It was fairly empty on this Monday night. So we were seated right away. Service was very quick and friendly. While perusing the menu, a special posted on the wall caught my attention, so I went for that. Call me a sucker for sometimes wanting to try items you wouldn't typically get to taste. I forgot the name. It was a black garlic flavored ramen. It was a nice, hot bowl of blackness woo. Slighty smoky and bitter but savory and not too overpowering. Also had the Takana fried rice. Can't quite describe the flavor of the rice, but it was good. I really enjoyed those two items. Sad to say I live across town and Monta Ramen is alot closer, I might not frequent this place as often as I'd like. Still if I'm in the area, it would definitely be a consideration.

So... excellent ramen. Currently closed for construction. With only a note on the door. They couldn't be bothered to actually make and leave a message on their own voicemail. I would normally give this place 5 stars for their food but sadly, they seem to be overwhelmed with business or inept with how to use an answering machine. This has resulted in countless people driving over and wasting their time. Currently we are starving and just wasted about 30 minutes driving to order our food (due to any sort of outgoing message on their machine).
