I've only had ramen a few times in my life but this place makes me want to change that lol. My experience here was great. Staff was friendly, the environment was clean, and the food was awesome! I will definitely have to stop by more often for my ramen fix! I do have one gripe... what's with the weird hours lol.   Definitely recommend trying this place out

Rudest motherf$&'. Came in early so I can order a lot of food but they won't let me.   if one person, not allowed to sit in a table. If the servers are real Japanese it will be ok, but there Chinese so as usual, rude.

I've said this before about the other location but the broth here is sooo good and the pork is sooooo tender never rubbery never dry falls apart.   The gyoza is ok, I wish they had a better dipping sauce for it.  And finally the staff is on point. When we were there last, after they took out order they checked on us twice making sure everything was good and the check came swiftly.... I wish they had dessert:(

Monta Chaya falls #3 on my list of preferred ramen joints in Vegas and one of the last on my list in all the ramen places ever tried. I've had ramen coast to coast and there is nothing really mind blowing about this place. It really boils down to comfort, convenience, and a quick meal.  My go-to has been the sho-yu ramen, which is comprised of a clear broth of soy sauce and chicken stock. Not too salty at all! Usually, I am miso ramen kinda gal, but the miso and tonkotsu ramens here are a bit disappointing. At first the $6.95 price point seems like a steal, but after adding toppings (egg $1.50 and nori $0.75)...it becomes $9+  Two pieces of chashu come with each bowl of ramen and I must say...it is on the small size; however, it is buttery and melts in your mouth!   Ramen is the perfect remedy for hangovers, colds, and rainy days. When the ramen craving hits, you can find me at other joints for sure. Thank you Monta Chaya for hitting the spot after an indecisive drive down Eastern Ave. Definitely, cured my hangry-ness.

If you're in Henderson and looking for good ramen, this place hits the spot. It's a small space with limited seating so get there before the lunch and dinner rush hours. Their service is speedy and the food is authentic and flavorful. My favorites - the gyoza (crisp exterior and the meat is full of the right seasoning/spices), kimchi fried rice and the tonkotsu shoyu ramen. Make sure to add the egg!

I've been to a couple of great ramen places, ippudo, ajisen, etc. and since i was so tired of buffet casino food, I have this place a try.  I ordered the tonkatsu shoyu ramen.  the noodles had a nice bit, but the broth was very salty.  it didn't have that 'creamy' rich texture (gelatin) i was expecting.  except for it being salty, it was rather bland.  it's $7 for the pretty bare bones version, 2 slices of pork.  you basically have to pay for egg, seaweed, corn, extra pork, etc.  for las vegas, i suppose it's okay but doesn't compare at all to the great noodle houses of japan.

The definition of Chaya in Japanese means "cafe that serves small meals", but there is nothing small in the flavor and oomph of the meals in this prominent noodle house.  I've had ramen in Chinatown, but it doesn't taste anything like the ones at Monta Chaya!   Tonkotsu Ramen which is Ramen that has a thick broth made from boiling pork bones, fat, and collagen, its stewed for many hours. The soothing rich and creamy pork broth is heaven is a bowl.    If that doesn't tickle your fancy, which would seem hard to imagine get the Kuro Ramen,  its Black Garlic Oil, Pork broth, roasted garlic and thin noodles. The garlic wraps the pork flavor like a warm blanket.    Unfortunately, with this unbelievable food comes the inconvenience of waiting +20 min. for my name to be crossed off the list but as the old saying goes "its worth the wait." It's actually not that bad waiting, I usually walk over to the Japanese market next door to view sweet goodies. Prices they charge is very reasonable considering the quality is off the chain.  Definitely put this place in your bookmark!  Monta Chaya is a legitimate noodle house!

I love ramen! This is one of the best ramen places in Vegas/Henderson. It's even better now that it is so close to my house. This location has a few more items on their menu than the location in Chinatown. My favorite is the Miso ramen or the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen...it depends on which type of noodles I'm craving. Sometimes I do add in takana mustard leaves to my ramen. If I'm hungry a side of steamed gyoza or Kim chee fried rice is delicious!  If its 100+ degrees outside and you want something refreshing, the Hiyashi Chuka with Goma Dressing hit the spot.  The service here is excellent! My drinks are always filled and the staff is very friendly.
Best Japanese Ramen place in Henderson. Every time I asked my kids where to eat for lunch on weekends, Monta is the #1 pick.

I consider myself a ramen expert. Love it! Coming from Japanese heritage I know my stuff. Only two people know ramen better then me, MY FOLKS. LOL We went to this place with my family and inlays, since we were in Henderson.  Located right off Eastern and the 215. Came here with the whole family at 5:15. Party of 9. We were able to get seated without reservations. This place is pretty small so you need to get there early. Legit Japanese ramen house. We ordered the gyoza, fried rice, kimchi, shoyu ramen, tonkotsu ramen and the shoyu-tonkotsu ramen. DELICIOUS!  Everyone loved the food. My folks said it was "top notch". That's a thumbs up from old Japanese people. Says a lot! Prices are very reasonable. Definitely  order the fried rice as a side to compliment the ramen.

I'm in love with this awesome restaurant Wonderful Ramen, I have to say THE BEST in Las Vegas!! Good prices, clean and relax atmosphere, awesome waiters and complements to the nice chef!! Would recommend this place to everybody out there looking for a great experience.
Pork buns were tasty a little on the fatty side but good. Ramen was good seems like the broth on spring mountain is better but overall nit bad. The service was good. Place looked clean.

I've been to Monta Chaya twice now & have enjoyed both trips immensely. The 1st time I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen with nori & this last time I decided to try the Shoyu. I def prefer the Tonkatsu & really wish I had gotten that again. The Shoyu while tasty, is lacking the richness that the Tonkatsu has. I actually left still feeling a tad hungry!  Along with the ramen, we ordered the spicy tuna on crispy rice both times & OMG, I dream of that stuff. 4 pieces just isn't enough to satisfy my craving & even if I had an order of it everyday for a year, I would still prob crave it.

After trying the Miso Ramen at their original location, I again confirmed that I am not a ramen person. It just doesn't do anything for me, doesn't appeal to my taste buds. So at this location I decided to go with the Pork Belly Bowl and also the Crispy Rice. The pork belly was decent and the crispy rice was GREAT. Also tried the fried rice and it was alright also. Maybe for ramen lovers this is the place for you, but for people such as myself, bleh! Customer service, however, was good. They were super friendly!

I used to think this was the best ramen in vegas, but Sora ramen completely blew this place out of the water.  The place is near eastern and serene inside the plaza containing at&t, golds gym and dennys. The inside of the place is set up like most ramen places, small tables and a bar where the chef cooks. All the furniture are wooden. This place is really casual and gets all types of people coming in from the gym, school, and just ramen cravers.  I never really had to wait for a table and their customer service is somewhat decent. Refills on water are sometimes late, but its better late than never. As for the wait time on food it feel almost instant.   The downpart of this place is it's food. I ended up ordering the tonkatsu ramen...and there is where sora starts beating the crap out of monta's standards. The broth from monta is very lacking and has no distinct taste at all. The portion of the ramen isn't so generous, as me and friend finished the whole bowl we still felt hungry. So those are my major gripes about it. One good thing I can say though is their pork is absolutely delicious.   And honestly for the price you're better off going to sora. I always get extra seaweed and at monta they only give you two extra seaweeds, while at sora they give you a bowl full.

the odd thing about this place is I like every dish I tried so far except for their ramen, the cha shao are too thin and small, soup teasted too salty. I recommend the pork belly bowl and the radish salad. unlike other ramen place, they have a lot of small side dishes.

My husband and I eat at the establishment on Spring Mountain since it's close to my home. My husband was on the other side of town and decided to phone in a pick up order to bring home. I dont really care for their ramen, but their pork belly has been my favorite. When my husband got home and we sat down to start eating I took a couple bites of the pork rice & immediately told my husband it tasted different than the one on Spring Mountain. He took a couple of bites and agreed. Later on that night my husband was rushing to the bathroom several times. He was like that until 4 a.m. I woke up the next morning not feeling well. Went to work & ended up getting sent home due to throwing up in the garbage can in my back room. Low and behold FOOD POISONING.....  I will never be able to eat at either location ever again... what a disappointment...

Awesome Monta now has two locations.  Little wait the Spring Mtn with all the same great ramen, and service. Every time the family is back in town Monta is a must stop, and will keep on coming. Hands down best ramen restaurant I have ever had even in all my travels. Keep growing.

*praise hands* My husband and I love this place. He was stationed in Japan for several years and is always looking for a great Ramen spot. We've found our favorite at Monta Chaya. I get the shoyu ramen with corn and butter and he gets the miso ramen with egg and kimchi. Broth is perfect. Fried rice is delicious as well as Gyoza. Service is quick and the waitresses are always attentive. Wish this place was closer but definitely worth the drive!
Ramen was so so goood. It was delicious for a cooling November night. Sorta too full for the clubs but we managed. The wait can be slightly long, so account for a wait time.

Was recommended by my boss and it was amazing. Had the shishito  peppers to start and they were covered in a delicious sauce. Had the miso bowl as the main course and it had a ton of flavor. Giving only four starts because of the slower service with only having two waitresses for the entire restaurant (half star) and the chashu slices (pork) were fairly small (half star). Will be back when in town again.

Absolutely love this place.  After trying their sister store on spring mountain, i was ecstatic about their being one much much closer.  Even though there isn't a ton of seating, somehow the longest wait I've ever had here has roughly been 5-10min.  (maybe I'm just coming at odd times?).  Either way, the ramen is great for my taste buds.  I don't have a ton of experience with ramen, never been to japan or any of that good stuff, but in the end I know what I like, I'm happy as a fat kid with cake when I come here ^_^
Perfect ramen, perfect service, we visit often. Love love love this place!!!

I'm not a saucy type of person but I do love soup! I haven't tried much ramen places but this place is number one for me. My go-to is usually the shoyu ramen and I've never been disappointed. There's a server there who makes dining in much more enjoyable but I forgot his name. =P   This place is always busy and you're lucky to get seated right away. I haven't been there in awhile but I usually get my ramen fix every two weeks.
Had steamed buns, kimchi fried rice and shoyu ramen for lunch. I'll def be returning. The broth and noodles were on point. The service was fast and the atmosphere was authentic.

Maybe, I'm just not a huge ramen fan since I can make it at home but I thought this place was okay. Service was great and our food came out fast. I just feel like their lacking flavor and they need to add dishes with more personality. My ramen noodles were cooked perfectly but definitely wasn't a fan of the Tonkatsu Shoyu broth. I loved the stick on wood they had for their refrigerator and front door. Never seen that.   PROS: Prices are cheap, cute place, perfect noodles CONS: Food lacks personality and flavor
Very very disappointed with the takeout. Probably never coming back since there are plenty of other competent ramen places in the area.

Just ate here tonight for the first time. We had to wait a few minutes to be sat, but nothing too long. I would say the ramen was above average - we got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen and the broth was delicious. The Chashu Bans (Pork Buns) were tasty, but I've had better. Our server was very knowledgeable of the food and we were very impressed. Also, at the end of our meal, the lady apologized to us over and over for us having to wait maybe 10 minutes, which we thought was very sweet of her. All in all, I would rate this a 4/5 because while the food was only above average, the customer service was phenomenal! I would definitely come back just for the service! Thank you!

Addicted. I've never had a bad experience & I'm a huge fan of adding the spicy sauce. Really, it makes it 100x better. Almost all of my friends have loved it too. The one that didn't was just jelly that I found it first. Tommy, I hope you're reading this.  Non-ramen recommendations: Pork Belly bowl & shishito peppers.

This is one of my new favorite places to eat!  I sat at the bar and enjoyed talking to other guests and watching the chefs work their magic. I ordered the miso ramen, added egg and requested spicy on the side so I could control the heat. It was pure heaven. The broth!!!  It's amazing! The pork was so tender and delicious. I will definitely be back many times! Love this spot!  What a great addition to Eastern's restaurant row.

We're quite the Ramen eating family and I was a tad disappointed that there was no other meat option other than pork...where's the chicken?  Anyway, it could be that we are use to more options but in comparison to the worst and best Ramen place we've been too, this is average. I would try another place before coming back here. I tried the butter in the Ramen, first time by the way and they do charge you for the butter, it's a side item. I didn't see what the hype was about, it didn't change anything for me.  The three (3) is because it didn't taste bad, it was fine, just not anything exceptional.

Chris and the girls love this location.  I think its ok.  The miso broth is amazing but there is not enough in the bowl. I would like a bowl full of piping hot broth, but this is not gonna happen here, the broth dont even cover the noodles. Been there 3 times already, dont count on it...  The ramen are a bit chewy to my taste and that's because they are not made in house but store baught... yikes, at that price the least they could do is to serve fresh ramen.  Also I love seasoned eggs but they are always served cold instead of warm, I dont get thst either...  We tried the mini pork sandwich and my question is... where is the meat?!!!  This place is just ok, definitely overpriced for the size of the portion and the quality of the noodles.  Also, absolutely no free drink refill.
I've been here a hundred times and it just keeps getting better and better! The ramen is just too delicious. Everything melts in your mouth. Keep it up monta!

Nice & busy Sunday afternoon. Cute little spot in the Golds Gym parking lot. Ambiance was cozy enough. Service was very good & attentive! The gyoza was my fav! The ramen bowl with the pork & miso broth really hit the spot!! I'll be back soon!

Forgive me, Yelp, for I have sinned. I am not one of the many dedicated followers from the original Monta who followed them to the Southeast. I am not even a big ramen fan.   Yet with each new ramen house that pops up, I find that I am beginning to change my mind. Okay, Monta is one of the better places in Vegas. It definitely gets bonus points for the broth not being overly salty and the noodles having a nice al dente texture. The karaage is tender, juicy, and seasoned to perfection. The one item that I would recommend above all else would be the pork belly bowl. The fatty rich meat to rice ratio is perfect.   The best part is that everything is so reasonably priced that you could try a variety and not break the bank.

My favorite ramen place to go! I'm always confused as to why every ramen place is so small, which leads to such a long wait. But the ramen is definitely worth the wait.   Customer service is amazing. The server we had was very friendly, funny, and on top of things (water filled constantly, checks on us multiple times, the good stuff). Five stars to him!   I ordered the tonkotsu shoyu ramen with corn (yum yum!). The broth is a bit creamy and I loooove it. I top it with the spicy seasoning and oil (cus I don't wanna pay extra for the spicy paste -- the seasoning and oil is just as good, lemme tell you) and a little bit of that garlic stuff - DELICIOUS! I'm drooling just thinking about it lol.   Get the crispy rice, too. It's like... deep fried rice topped with spicy tuna -- you won't regret it.

What can I say my favorite place to have ramen ...not to mention I come here once a week ...I've tried other ramen but none of them beats monta ...I really love the flavor of the broth ..my favorite is tonkatsu shoyu with thick noodle also have to say the service is here is great especially joe if u haven't tried this place then u should
Excellent place! Awesome ramen! Good spot for lunch, delicious every time! Try everything with tea and a beer.

Came here a weeks ago for a trip to Vegas and since it was a chilly night ramen sounded perfect. The 2 for $5 Charsiu buns  is what attracted us to this place. They were yummy, I wish there was a little more meat to them but flavors were delish!   I got the Tonkatsu Ramen, the broth was very rich, creamy and savory. I don't like bamboo shoots in my ramen I asked them to emit it, it comes as a standard topping. It was a very simple ramen, it doesn't come with an egg either, it would be $1.50 to add. It's nice that you can add whatever toppings you like but I wish some of them was standard.   My husband got the Tonkatsu Ramen with the black garlic oil, and he enjoyed it very much compared to Jinya version. The flavors were delicious!   For both ramens, it was a little on the salty side, not sure if you can ask to not make it as salty. The noodles were cooked perfectly! If you're in the area, give them a try!

I would give Monta Chaya's ramen 3 stars originally but I had to knock it down to 2 stars due to a horrible customer service experience.  I've been to Monta Chaya quite a few times throughout the year and the ramen is decent to fill a craving when you're in Henderson. I've tried the Tonkatsu and Tonkatsu-Shoyu ramen. The broth is thicker than I would like but the noodles and hard-boiled egg were decent. The Chashu pork is tender but has a little too much fat unfortunately. I've also tried the Takana Fried Rice but I preferred the regular Fried Rice more! The Takana Fried Rice left me with a strange after taste. The price for the ramen is reasonable, starting at ~$7.   The service time to get the food is a bit slow but for some reason, it always takes a while to pay my check (10-15 minutes) even when actively asking the waitress for the check. The lack of customer service at Asian restaurants doesn't bother me usually but my last visit at Monta Chaya was just ridiculous.    My boyfriend and I were waiting at least 15 minutes for our check that never came and we had to walk up to the front desk to see what was going on. We found out - not through the employees - but from another customer that the waiter accidentally switched our credit cards and charged us for the wrong orders. None of the employees really explained to us what happened. After standing and waiting another 10 minutes for our refund and correct check, we had to ask for the receipt of the refunded charge. We pretty much were left hanging for another 10 minutes, asked for our receipt yet again, only to see that the manager was continuing to work on other table's checks. So he was fine making us wait even longer despite making a charging error and making us wait for so long already! We ended up just giving up and walking out since it was clear they weren't going to help us any time soon.   TLDR: Ramen is average but the bill was charged wrong and ended up having to wait 35 minutes for our check and a receipt that we never got.  The poor customer service we received makes us shudder at the idea of going back and experiencing it again.

This is my top choice for ramen in Henderson. Similar to the Chinatown location, space is limited, so choose your dining time wisely or be prepared to put your name on the list. Our most recent visit was on a Sunday afternoon around 3 PM and was without wait probably because most don't want to have a hot bowl of noodles in triple digit weather, but that doesn't scare us at all.  You can consistently count on a delicious bowl of ramen from this restaurant in the Mon group. The spicy tonkotsu with egg and butter added came out in less than five minutes. The broth was flavorful with the spice level being just right, but I wasn't impressed with the chasu itself as it was sliced thin and had toughened up. My wife had no complaints with her miso. After about 15 minutes after ordering, the gyoza was delivered and was fried with a crisp flat side to add texture, but I had to douse them in soy sauce as the fillings weren't seasoned that well.  Service was friendly and timely with the server repeating our entire order before sending it back to the kitchen. Don't forget about the $1.50 kaedama if you're in a extra noodle mood. For the drinkers, there is a small selection of sake and Japanese beer. If you want to use your credit card to charge the meal, there is a $10 minimum.  I've had both the shoyu and kuro versions which were both delicious and would recommend if those are your preference. I've always stuck with the ramen with every visit, but the cold noodle and any of the bowls are on the agenda for upcoming meals.

Had high expectations from all the great reviews from Yelp.   I know Ramen places tend to be salty (though I've eaten at a few places that weren't), and this was no exception.    If the ramen and the meat was flavorful, I couldn't really tell because the salt content drowned out all the flavor. I had the pork and chicken soup base and my gf had the chicken soup base. Both were equally salty. I even added a bowl of hot water to my soup and it was still salty.. Ugggh!  And the two slices of pork I got in my soup was literally more fat than meat.  And now I'm feeling so thirsty..    Definitely not one of the better places for ramen.   I will not be returning.

Sometimes the first time for anything can go awry...like pulling your first loose tooth, popping an ingrown hair, or your first cavity search.  And I've had a lot of bad ones...but I stopped into Monta Chaya and tried out the kuro ramen because the big old piece of laminated paper said "brand new on the menu".  Oooooooh shiny paper!  The kuro ramen came out smelling and tasting amazing!  The garlicky broth and buttery noodles couldn't ruin this virgin kuro eaters experience.  It was so popular, my lady damn near inhaled half of it (I should've ordered two).   But I also recommend ordering the pork belly bowl and crispy rice tuna roll if it's offered.  The pork belly bowl is a staple but the crispy rice tuna seemed like a monthly special.  I remember ordering something similar to the tuna at another restaurant and it was three times the price and not as delicious.  Anywhoo, eating the kuro ramen was a highlight for me in 2013 and totally makes all the cavity searches worth it.

Friend and I needed a new Ramen place. Shoku Ramen Ya was pretty terrible, so we chose the next closest place on Bing - Monta Chaya.  We were blown away by how excellent and flavorful the food was. Menu could be considered small, but it's actually the perfect size. They have great service, but a small staff can result in some delay or confusion during the crazy dinner rushes. Comfy atmosphere, and music is modern, so you are saved from what I call 'lame-ass classical asian stringed instrumental music'.   If you don't want to wait to eat this awesome food,  go before 7:00PM. NOTE: They are CLOSED 2:30 - 5:00 PM to prepare for dinner. Don't be that guy and write a bad review because they're closed when you get there because you're ignant.  We highly recommend the Tonkotsu Shoyu and the Spicy Miso for your entrees/ramen choice. Add in that famous orange spice and you're good to go. Keep in mind that one bowl is a lot of food to tackle before ordering appetizers. 1 appetizer per 2 people is best if you have an average appetite.   Speaking of appetizers- they have a nice selection of flavor-filled appetizers which will enhance your experience. We highly recommend the Gyoza/Pot Stickers and dipping them in your own soy sauce concoction. The Calamari and Pork Belly Bowl are also fantastic choices.   KEEP IN MIND THE FOLLOWING WHEN ORDERING GYOZA: They start frying Gyoza when you order them. 50% of the time, you may receive your Gyoza at the same time or after you get your ramen.  The place is a bit small for the amount of business that Monta Chaya gets, so busy times are a bit chaotic, especially considering they usually only have two servers (no busser) for their 4 four-seater tables, 2 two-seater tables, and a 10 person bar. Doesn't sound like a lot, but the same two people that serve everyone have to buss all those tables and the bar.   I've learned all this from becoming a regular and going here countless times. If you follow my tips to eating here, you will have a wonderful eating experience nearly every visit.  Thanks for being the best, Monta Chaya!

2nd time here; hoping it had improved based on all the recent positive reviews, but again so terrible; if you like lukewarm salty one note broth with skimpy toppings(which of course cost extra) come here.  With all the great ramen places in LV, don't waste your time here.  As I left, I wanted to tell incoming diners to go somewhere else...it was that bad.

I'm not really a ramen fan but I wanted to try this place since they just opened recently and I heard about them on Yelp Talk so we decided to give them a try. We came around 9:30 PM last night and were greeted immediately by the waitstaff.  The restaurant is small and I think I counted five 4-top tables and there were plenty of counter seatings. They have an open kitchen so if you choose to sit at the counter, then you'll be able to watch the chefs preparing your food.  For our appetizer we decided on the chashu bans which is like a pork belly bao. We both liked it a lot, it was very tasty. We both ordered the Miso Ramen and added extra pork and a hard boiled egg. I liked the ramen but I think next time I will not add the egg. I got full halfway through and believe me, I tried forcing myself to finish the whole bowl but it was just a little too much for me. My boyfriend had no problem finishing his bowl.   The place is very clean and the staff was great but there is one con that i would like to mention and that is the hand soap. I always wash my hands before I eat and I noticed that the hand soap in the restroom had a very strong scent. Whenever I would lift my chopsticks up to my mouth I would smell the strong soap scent still lingering on my hands. I would have liked a nice floral scent instead.  There is not a sign for them yet but they are located right next to Japan Creek in the same shopping center as Golds Gym.

Having just eaten at the Spring Mountain location....I must say Monta Chaya is definitely the newer, sleeker model.  The decor is a little more modern, a whole lot more spacious, and the seats at the bar are more comfortable. Also no seating nazi....I was seated without my whole party being present =).  Of course my first thought is to check the kitchen, there better be a Japanese chef in there!  Okay, this place is legit, the man cooking up the noodles is the right ethnicity.  This location brings back memories of the glory days of Monta in Chinatown.  The pork belly was nice and tender and the broth was not overly salty.  If I still lived on this side of town, I would definitely be a regular.  Also, they have karaage, shishitou, chashu buns, fried calamari, hakusai salad, and daikon salad.  So expanded menu and cleaner....that's always a plus in my book.
Decent ramen but not my favorite. The chashu is very inconsistent in quality. The rest is good and it's close to home which makes me a regular.

I'm not really a big fan of ramen but this place was delicious! It's either a hit or miss when it comes to ramen in my opinion. Besides that, this place topped it for me! Everything was perfect! Spicy tonkotsu all day!! I wish they had spicy miso though but it's okay. Customer service was awesome! I didn't catch the guy's name that helped me and my brother but he was very open, funny, and helpful. Which is great because most servers always look so stressed out or plain unhappy. So kudos and much respect to the server to helped us! If you want to eat at a cute little ramen place you should definitely come here!
So good! I come all the time for the Kuro ramen- yum!! All their apps are also great,  I suggest the Daikon salad!

This is a cute, small Japanese "fast food" Ramen restaurant. The buzzing atmosphere reminded me of my time in Tokyo: the crowd is young and laid back, the food affordable and the servers easy going and fun. A huge drawback are the very limited options for vegetarians. To add insult to injury, there is almost nothing a vegan could order (the salad is probably the only safe option). I totally argue that a restaurant in this day and age (in the western world) should be inclusive and also cater to vegetarians and vegans. Provided they will add a few more vegetarian (or at least fish options) dishes to the menu, I will certainly be back and give it a try again. My friends really enjoyed the food, by the way.

A little bit MSGish but otherwise great tasting, especially the mixture of tonkotsu/shoyu broths.    Been to both locations and the services are always pleasant.  It does get really busy during lunch and dinner time so time it wisely.
Decent grub at a decent price. Always packed and the staff is friendly.

The Black Garlic Oil Ramen hits the spot on a cold night. I like how the soup isn't that salty and has a good garlic flavor that is not overwhelming. The sliced black fungus provided a great crunch with every bite. Definitely a good bargain at $7.95 for the bowl.  The pork belly rice was on the sweet side. At $5.95 for a large, it has a good amount of pork belly. It was a bit too sweet for me.  The Takata Fried Rice was a bit too salty for me.  I actually mixed the pork belly rice and Takata together and it tasted alright combined.  Even though it was a Tuesday night, there was still a wait out the door. But the line did go pretty fast and we were seated pretty quickly.

I haven't been to Monta Chaya for awhile... I had a huge craving for their Pork Belly Bowl! I'm so glad that I decided to call in for an order of it... Oh how I missed this flavorful bowl of porky goodness!!!! The thinly sliced pieces of pork belly was so tender and melt in your mouth yummy in my tummy awesomeness!!!! I can't express how much I love pork belly!   Monta Chaya also has great ramen! My personal favorite is the Tonkotsu Ramen... Sooo good!!! The Calamari is also good... Monta Chaya is my go to Ramen place especially since it's just 10 minutes away from me... Great location! Customer service is also on point... Lurve this place!!!

I went there because I was in the area at 11:30 a.m. shortly after they opened. The one downside was that it was packed. Other then that, the service was super friendly, and fast. I ordered gyoza and spicy ramen with egg.   The ramen wasn't as spicy as I would have liked, but it was still good. The eggs were well seasoned and the pork was cooked excellently. Not overdone.  The gyoza was one if the best I've seen at a restaurant. it was seared but not overly crunchy. I will be going back. A lot.

Good ramen place. All ramen seemed cheap when we looked at the menu to realize any additions cost money - the boiled egg, the seaweed, etc - it ends up being about $10-12 depending on what you add. While this is mot expensive, I just felt it was a little deceiving. However, the broth was delicious and I would be back anytime for some more.

I love the OG Monta.  So you can believe when I learned that there was one closer to my home, I did flips.  A homie told me about the new location, in addition to the new items on the menu.  The new spot was well decorated, a little fancier than its predecessor, and similar to the decor at Shoku Ramen-ya and Fukumimi.  I am still find of the simplistic set up of an authentic ramen shop.  Nevertheless, the decor is not the reason for my visit, I'm here to slurp on some sizoup.  The bowls seem to be be done up a little more as well, a bit more flair than the original, am I wrong?  I was saddened to learn that they don't serve hot water, as strange as it seems.  My trick is to order extra chashu and noodles with a cup of hot water to dilute the saltiness of some of the broth blends.  But the pork belly baos were a nice touch as well as the mini ikura bowls.    The staff looks like the same as Sushimon and Goyemon, after all, they are all owned by the same person.  Staff is always friendly and the chef are always close by and visible.  It's hard to screw up ramen, and this place does it just right.  I still prefer the original, but I can't complain with no lines at the new location.  Close by is Japan Creek, so I assume that there will never be a shortage of chashu I hope.  That is the first place I found where you can buy frozen chashu and hamachi kama.  Always good to burn off some calories by taking a nice walk in the store after a nice meal at Monta Chaya.  Cross advertising baby!!!  Overall, same great quality and service with some slight differences that may be intentional to reach more of a main stream market.  The place is found in an established area of the southeast and strays away from traditional conservative decor from the original, but that is alright with me.    Remember the movie Mr. Baseball starring Magnum PI?  Well you can find me slurpin up a storm like Mr. Baseball if you ever catch me at the spot.  Be easy yall!

BEST RAMEN I'VE EVER HAD.  Yes, I said it. Coming from SD, LA, and SF...as a new resident to LV, this is my go to spot for my ramen craving! (I also love that I basically love that I live down the street from it!).  Their broth is so flavorful and savory. The noodles have great texture and done just right where other places skimp out on the noodles. Their pork chashu is well done as well.  I also love how you can customize your ramen; I always get extra chashu, nitamago, and sometimes kimchi on the side.   Also, the place doesn't get that crowded as their sister location in the eastside...god that place is ALWAYS crowded it seems.  Also, the servers already know me as a regular! hahahah  Definitely a fan.

What else can I say, THIS is the Monta to dine in! More menus, roomier atmosphere, and convienient parking compared to its Spring Mountain location.   The calamari alone is the sole reason to get down here! Everytime I stop by, I ALWAYS order it! So if you happen to be in this area, (in Arnold's voice) GET DOWN HERE!!!

This is the spot for Ramen in Henderson.   Pros: Quick and always friendly service. Affordable menu, and everything on the menu is great!!!  Cons: Seating area is small so you will probably have to wait a little, but this is part of the experience.  I have been to this place half a dozen times, and it is consistently amazing. Everything we have tried on the menu is awesome. Just a few highlights are the Mido Ramen with egg, Steamed pork buns, Kim chi and the Pork Belly Bowl. This is one of the only restaurants I know where I want to try everything on the menu. This is definitely one of my top 10 favorite local places!

Ramen season is in full swing when fall comes around.  If you are in the mood for some noods in Henderson, Monta Chaya has got what you need.  I like to sit at the counter, especially since I've been dining solo on my work lunch break lately.  I show up right when they open at 11:30am so I know I'll get seated immediately, order, and eat in a flash.  My go-to order is the Tonkotsu Shoyu with egg, butter, and corn added.  The service is quick and the soup is comfortingly delicious.  I'll definitely be making lunch plans here often, especially as the weather gets cooler.

Monta Chaya and the original Monta on Spring Mt. are two of my all-time favorite restaurants.  Some days I will wake up craving a big hot bowl of ramen and a bowl full of fried rice.  I usually get the Shoyu Ramen with extra Chashu (pork), the regular friend rice and an order of Gyoza.  The Daikon Salad is also really good.  I never thought I'd be craving radishes, but it's super tasty.  The service is always quick even when they are really busy.  I have recommended this place to many of my friends and relatives and they always want to go back.

We drive across town for this amazing ramen!  The best vegetarian ramen in Las Vegas, tried several others that do not come close to Monta Chaya!  Salmon & Crispy Rice appetizer is a must! BEST VEGETARIAN RAMEN!

Don't bother me...I'm soaking it all in.  Omg, I love Monta. It's so delicious I felt like singing from atop the nearest mountain.  Except it was 100 degrees in Vegas so I'll just tell it on Yelp.  Hubby and I have both been to the smaller Monta location on Spring Mtn. Rd.  When I noticed this one pop up on Yelp on our way into Vegas, we just HAD TO re-route our GPS to grab lunch here first.  As luck would have it, we arrived about 5 minutes before opening where there were already 3 or 4 parties waiting for the sign the flip.  I enjoyed this location so much more because it was bigger, less cramped and you weren't made to feel like you need to slurp down your (yummy) noodles and get the hell out.    The noodles are just as tasty...the thick sticky broth made me hear angels sing.  My only complaint is that they don't give you very much broth...but I guess we're really just here for the noodles.  As the broth cools, it gets thicker and does a really good job of hanging onto the noodles.  In this respect, I think it's different than the broth at other places.  We also ordered the daikon salad.  This dish elevated the lowly turnip into a crisp, refreshing masterpiece, garnished with these crispy little rice ball bits.  Karaage (fried chicken nuggets) was also very tasty.  I ate mine with a lot of crushed garlic.  Hubby really appreciated me doing so.  Finally, we also ordered my 2nd favorite thing - the takana fried rice.  At this point, I could only manage a few bites but it still hit my lofty expectations.  A few hours later, I enjoyed the leftovers as a wonderful cold snack.  Yum.  As mentioned, service wasn't frenetic and indifferent like the other branch.  These people were allowed the luxury of being friendly and nice at a leisurely pace.  They even checked in on you to see how you were doing.  If you haven't had Monta, come give it a whirl!

I really love this place! It is small, so on busier nights prepare to wait - we have waited about 45 minutes before, but I personally think it's worth it. It's only slightly larger than their Spring Mountain location, but I think this location normally has a smaller crowd and shorter wait.  Once you're seated, the service has always been very fast, and you get your food very fast as well. It has always consistently been very good food, and I take everyone visiting here. My favorite is the Tonkotsu or the Spicy ramen with a side of gyoza.   Honestly, the only thing I would change about this place is a larger location, since when it's busy you're a little cramped and seated very close to your neighbors. Otherwise - it's perfect!
This is the only place me and the wife eat ramen at. Great environment, friendly staff and excellent pricing.
I always get the shoyu ramen with extra egg and pork. The food is delicious and the service is fast. Just wish they had a bigger restaurant.
Not a bad thing on the menu. They keep it simple so they can focus on the quality and flavor. It does not suck.

Love love love their Tonkotsu-shoyu ramen with extra chasu and egg. The broth tastes amazing. Also like their fried rice which is unlike other places.  Always busy and be prepared for a 10-15 min wait in peak times.

The less-crowded little sister to Monta on Spring Mountain.  Actually I think I like this one better because there is more seating and you're less likely to die in a fiery car crash in the parking lot like at the other location.  Seriously it's like bumper cars over there.  Dozens of asian female drivers in one place...you know what they say...female driver = no survivors.    Anyhoo, visited this restaurant on Saturday 10/01/2016 at 1:30PM.  $29.90 got us two bowls of ramen, two soft drinks, and an order of fried rice.   I got the shoyu ramen and added an egg and corn.  The chicken-based broth was very good and nicely salty.  The chasu was tender but thin and fatty.  I like to sprinkle Shichimi on mine and make it a little spicy.    Their fried rice is alright...it wasn't very warm and had very little pork.  I prefer the version at Sora because it's served hot and teeming with salty little nibbles of tender porky goodness.    We ordered a side of white rice for my boy but the nice waitress never brought it.  She never came back to check on us so I ended up just sharing with him.  Had to ask them to take it off the bill but it was no biggie.    Overall it was a wonderful lunch and I much prefer it to the Spring Mountain location.
Best ramen i have tried in vegas, service was great and they are very friendly. this is now the place were i bring my relatives and friends who visits us every now and then.

Meh.  Maybe this place is good for Vegas standards, but it taste like crap compared to what I had in Cali.  It was a bit too salty, just as the other reviewers said.  The gyoza, fried rice, and crispy rice were good.  But this a ramen place and it should've been the best thing on the menu.

*Thumbs up* The ramen is just as good as the Chinatown location. I've tried them all, but I always come back to the miso ramen with extra chasu. It doesn't skip a beat. The location looks slightly larger and obviously newer, with a bit more elbow room. I like this area of the town and would consider moving here for Monta!  *Thumbs down* Although the fried rice was decent, I would skip their other dishes and strictly save room for the ramen. The calamari was bland and disappointing, which got lost and soggy in the broth. The pork buns were sad and not worth the money. Save your stomatch and money for TWO bowls of ramen!

Stopped in here Thursday night around 6:40pm. Upon pulling into the parking spot, we spotted a group outside the doors. Hmmm....looks like it could be a long wait. We almost left. But I decided to check it out, and found we were the 2nd party of 2 on the list and opted for counter or table. We were seated within 5 minutes. Way better than the Spring Mountain location where we have had to leave 4 or 5 times due to long waits.  The inside has more seating, probably 10 two tops, and counter space for another 12.   Menu is similar to Monta Ramen. I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen ($6.95) and as memory serves it was just as delicious. Extra pork chasu (I know my spelling sucks on this but too lazy to check) for an extra $2.50,   Service was good, friendly and quick. Two people working the tables while the crew of 5 in the kitchen area.   So happy to have this option close by. I like Fukumimi as well, and these two have a definitely different broth style, so its nice to have more choice on the east/south side of town.

Can I take this moment to kick myself in the butt for taking SO long to try this place out? I'm currently working in Henderson and often find myself buying food from the In-n-Out located right across the street so HOW DID I MISS THIS PLACE?!  I know there are other ramen places in the Valley which MIGHT be better, but I have never been to those places so this place currently takes it for me! I've always been a fan of ramen. I've never had ramen at a restaurant before unless you count the saimin they serve at Hawaiian places. If I had to picture Japanese ramen - this would be it.  The restaurant is kind of hidden. The sign doesn't stick out too much since the surrounding stores have big signs so keep a look out. The restaurant is pretty small, but I've heard the location in Chinatown is a LOT smaller. The decor consist of wood chairs, stools, and tables. My boyfriend and I went with friends so they guided us on what to order. I got the Miso Ramen with extra pork and butter ~ so delish! I'm craving some right now.  I think we had a new waitress because she mixed up a couple of our plates, but that's not that big of a deal to me. I would rather had the server mix up plates at the correct table than serve our plates to the wrong table. All in all.. WE WILL DEFINITELY BE BACK. I might just start replacing pho as my regular hangover food to ramen, haha.

While the food is great the service is slowwwww! Walked in and a table opened up but did we get seated right away?? NO! We waited for at least 10 mins and neither of the girls acknowledged us! So I am trying to be all zen now a days and I just stand there looking at them. Finally we get our seat but once again there's a lot of waiting! It amazes that the one on Spring Mt. is so busy but moves so quickly...while this place was empty and moves so slowly. I might give this place another try, but if it's as slow as the last time I will be avoiding it.
Doing the take out thing today. Hopefully it will be just as good. Not the same as eating in, hope it is delicious when I take it home.  I am sure it will be.

We came in on a Monday night around 7pm and I was shocked to see how crowded the place was! Luckily there were still a few open tables, so my group of 7 was quickly accommodated. Since this was my first time here, I obviously needed to try their ramen, but I also read so many good things about the pork belly bowl. This left me in quite a predicament. Ramen or pork belly bowl? The answer was both!   After telling everyone about all the good things I had read about the pork belly, someone in my group finally offered to share a small one with me (thanks Courtney K!). So glad I got this because it was delicious! The meat was so flavorful and the ginger on top was the perfect touch!  As for the ramen, I got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu. The broth was rich and savory, and I was glad it wasn't overly salty. I really liked the chasu pork in the ramen- it practically melted in my mouth!  And oh my noodles! They certainly don't skimp on the noodles, so I was quite full by the end of my meal. Definitely $10 well spent!
Very small location expect wait times of 30 minutes to be seated.   The Ramen is delicious, services quick.  Parking is a nightmare

I just wanna live in it.   Idk how credible my review will be since I've only had ramen about 3 times in my life and all 3 times were at Monta.   The first time was with a group of friends and it was amazing.   The second time was the Japanese fest a month or 2 ago and third was today.   All 3 times I've loved it but the more I have it the more I notice the grease.   The second time I had it, I brought some home and stuck it in the fridge. Next morning it was solid. So much grease it turned to freaking Tonkatsu jello. You could slice into it.   Again tonight. I'm eating left overs and my lips are so glossy and greasy.   Idk if this is normal, like I said I've only had it 3 times and all 3 times it was Monta.   We tried the pork fried rice, pork belly bowl and gyoza and all of it was super tasty and amazing.   I'll keep coming back to clog my arteries 1 delicious bowl at a time.   Great price, enormous size, tons of add ins and nice staff.   I love Monta.

I love the ramen and the bun here. I'm not sure if Monta is a chain, but there are 2 more places in Spring Mountain. Anyway, this place is closest to my place, so my wife and I come here quite often. My regular dish is the fried rice and regular ramen... both are awesome dishes. They just barely have the new dish, I can't remember the name, but it's port-bun, really good. You guys should try.

Overall, this restaurant is great. I frequent monta about 5 times a month. During my visits, I have only waited a long time twice (30 min). The waiters are nice and were quick to seat me. There's a male waiter that is very friendly and always makes us laugh when we converse. The food is affordable especially for the amount, taste and presentation that comes with it. While everything sounds great, on two occasions I have found some "non-edibles" in my food. They were very apologetic though and quickly fixed the problem by offering a refund and extra dish. I will be returning soon despite those minor things because this restaurants food is addicting. Just keep in mind that the restaurant is very small though and not a good place to host groups.

I was about to write a review of Monta Chaya, but thinking about it makes me want Monta noodles. Now. So instead, I'm heading over there right now to get my fix. This is as good as the Spring Mountain location.

From the simple menu to the excellent service, this place deserves the high rating. The Tonkatsu ramen I ordered was amazing. The chashu is cooked tender and perfect, the broth is well seasoned and the extra chashu and egg I ordered made my meal well balanced and extremely enjoyable.

I love coming here! The service is always good. The food is always good and consistent. I normally have to drive to china town for ramen until I found out about this location. It's perfect for all the ramen lovers on this side of town. It's a small and quaint place. It always seems to be busy. I can see why!! I've never had a bad experience here and I don't think I ever will.

If you can tell from my previous reviews, I prefer not having to drive very far for delectable eats.  This place sits in a plaza that's nearby the local shopping centers and has ample parking. I ordered the Miso with nori and egg. It was a bit on the salty side, but delicious still. I was looking for a spicy miso option, but none was available. :(  I also ordered the cha shu bun and that was delicious since it was like a slider with the lettuce and sauce.   Great service and everyone was always smiling.

Best. Ramen. In. Town.  Everyone has their own opinion on ramen, but for me, Monta hits the spot. The first time I ever had ramen was at the one on Spring Mountain. And I was soooo happy they opened one on eastern which is closer to my house! Both places always never let me down. The staff is courteous and never miss a hello or goodbye. Though wait times can be ridiculous, it just shows you how good of a place they really are. The gyoza is really delicious. The dumpling meat is cooked and tastes good with the sauce they give you. Today we tried the steamed buns and it was TO DIE FOR. The sauce that was marinated on the pork was a hint of spicy and I don't know what it was but it was soooo good. I wanna put it on all my meat! Lol. It only comes with two, but I split it with four people. We each didn't want our portions to end. I could probably eat two of them and be full. We also tried the calamari which was crispy and marinated in a sauce so you didn't need to dip it into anything. Not amazing but not bad either. As for the ramen, I usually get tonkatsu shoyu. Their broth is tasty and the pork is cooked perfectly. I actually like eating the fattier parts, which is very yummy. I like to add egg, butter, and corn, but you can have it anyway you like. The little spice stuff they have on the table is a good little kick to add! And you can control how spicy you want the broth. I like to add sesame seeds for texture. The noodles are cooked perfectly, not too soft and not too hard. I don't like mushrooms so I ask for none and they're always very accommodating. The food comes out hot and pretty fast as well. They play newest music and sometimes they even play old hit songs which is a lot of fun cause it makes the atmosphere really fun. I love monta and will always recommend it for ramen!

Awesome place still. I go here at least once a week with my partner. Seriously, where else could you get delicious ramen starting at $6.95?  My go-to order is Kuro Ramen with thick wavy noodles and flavored egg. It's about $10.22 with tax. Slightly more expensive, but it's so damn good. I don't even look at the menu anymore because this is hands-down the best ramen they serve here. Super fatty and filling. If you're extra hungry, you can also add extra noodles too.  Service here can be spotty at times, but you can tell the kitchen staff is working non-stop. I've only seen service quality drop when the restaurant was super crowded. You can't blame them for that.   Overall, this place will always be my favorite ramen place in Henderson/Las Vegas. It's constantly packed during dinner hours, so you know it's a local favorite. If you don't like lines, try showing up when they first open or during the late lunch hours. They're typically slow when they first open too.
I've gone to this place multiple times every time I'm in the area... Our family favorite Ramen place here in Las Vegas. Service & Food quality! Great combo!

Been here a few times now and it's always good, friendly and clean. The broth is very tasty and portions are big :) If you're up for some ramen and can't drive across town this place is perfect. Only problem I see is that the place is only good for small groups, I'd stay under 4 people.

I went to the one on Eastern in Henderson in the Gold's Gym shopping plaza.  My friend took me there and she had the Summer Ramen Dish Special which was corn, tomato sauce and was really tasty. I had the cool noodles which was zesty and light for a lunch meal.  It came with the Yuzi lemony sauce. It was good eats! This was back in 2012 or 2013.
Favorite ramen spot in Vegas ! The food is beautiful and flavorful. Change nothing monta you guys are amazing !

I almost always get the Black Garlic Oil Tonkatsu Ramen. I eat it up and then always order the extra noodles for $1.50 to go and box up my leftover broth.   Then I add some corn, butter, nori sheets, and 2 soft boiled eggs for breakfast. These are things I usually have in the house. AMAZING. The noodles suffer a little being reheated but the taste is still divine.  Nice way to extend the magic.  There may be better ramen houses in LA, in SF, New York, or from memories of Japan. Really? Live in the now. Get over it. It's still good.  It's often part of a much larger routine where I go up the street to http://www.yelp.com/biz/henderson-china-foot-massage-and-reflexology-las-vegas and get an hour long reflexology foot massage. It's actually more of a full body massage than just your feet. Don't go if you don't want to take off your top. I can see in some of the reviews that people freak out over that. It's a massage. America needs to stop being so puritanical & squeamish. It's also hardcore deep tissue and they beat you up. You're sore afterwards in a good way like being sore after a gym workout.  This is why we eat ramen afterwards, to ascend into heaven and soothe the pain.

An impromptu date night landed us at Monta Chaya and we definitely left satisfied. The service was superb. The atmosphere and setting was just as great. Most importantly the food was awesome. I had the daikon salad and kimchee fried rice, both were delicious. I would give five stars had it not been for the basic menu and lack of fresh, hot green tea. Green tea from a can that has been heated and brought to my table along with a plastic cup just didn't cut it for me. We will definitely be back though. I'll just drink water. :)
